{"code":1,"isDone":false,"toInsertArticleList":[{"createdTime":"2020-09-06 10:59:24","updatedTime":"2020-09-06 10:59:24","title":"Drafts of a DHS report call white supremacists the 'most persistent and lethal' terror threat in the US: report","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/dhs-white-supremacy-deadliest-domestic-terror-threat-politico-2020-9","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f5393dc7ed0ee001e25db6a?format=jpeg\" alt=\"dhs logo\" height=\"512\" width=\"1024\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The Department of Homeland Security logo is seen on a law enforcement vehicle in Washington, United States on March 7, 2017.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://www.gettyimages.com/detail/news-photo/the-department-of-homeland-security-logo-is-seen-on-a-law-news-photo/649149526?adppopup=true\" target=\"_blank\">Samuel Corum/Anadolu Agency/Getty Images</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>A report from the Department of Homeland Security cast white supremacy as the greatest terror threat to the US, <a href=\"https://www.politico.com/news/2020/09/04/white-supremacists-terror-threat-dhs-409236\">according to Politico</a>.&#160;</li>\n<li>In three drafts viewed by the outlet, the department concluded that \"white supremacist extremists (WSEs) will remain the most persistent and lethal threat in the Homeland through 2021.\"</li>\n<li>The report comes as <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/barr-gop-present-antifa-major-threat-but-no-evidence-killings-2020-7\">President Donald Trump and some of his allies have</a> slammed violence at protests against racism and police brutality as a fallout of left-wing actors in Democratic cities.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>A report from the Department of Homeland Security cast white supremacy as the greatest terror threat to the US, <a href=\"https://www.politico.com/news/2020/09/04/white-supremacists-terror-threat-dhs-409236\">according to Politico</a>.</p><p>The outlet reported it viewed three draft reports by the department, all of which describe in similar language that white supremacy is the biggest threat ahead of other concerns from foreign terrorist groups and disinformation efforts from Russia.</p><p>The three drafts of DHS's State of the Homeland Threat Assessment 2020 were all produced in August, and describe white supremacy in a vague group of \"Domestic Violent Extremists,\" according to the report.</p><p>In a paragraph of \"Key Takeaways,\" the outlet wrote that the three drafts of the report do conclude \"white supremacist extremists (WSEs) will remain the most persistent and lethal threat in the Homeland through 2021.\"</p><p>The reports echo conclusions that have been longheld in US intelligence agencies in regards to threats posed by white supremacists but highlight how violent actors could capitalize on recent civil unrest across the country.</p><p>\"Violent extremists almost certainly will continue their efforts to exploit public fears associated with COVID-19 and social grievances driving lawful protests to incite violence, intimidate targets, and promote their violent extremist ideologies,\" the second and third drafts reviewed by Politico say. \"Simple tactics – such as vehicle ramming, small arms, edged weapons, arson, and rudimentary improvised explosive devices – probably will be most common.\"</p><p>The DHS did not immediately respond to Business Insider's request for comment.&#160;</p><p>Protests that began after George Floyd was killed in Minneapolis police custody in March dominated the streets in cities across the US for weeks in huge demonstrations against police brutality and racism.</p><p><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/barr-gop-present-antifa-major-threat-but-no-evidence-killings-2020-7\">President Donald Trump and some of his allies have repeatedly bashed</a> the protests after reports of violent incidents. He specifically <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/a-look-at-the-antifa-movement-trump-is-blaming-for-violence-2020-6\">blamed Antifa for the violence</a>, which none of the drafts referred to, according to Politico.</p><p><a href=\"https://www.cnn.com/2020/08/31/politics/trump-supporters-violence/index.html\">Trump dodged condemning violence from right-wing agitators</a> and even appeared to defend 17-year-old Kyle Rittenhouse, who faces homicide charges after a shooting that killed two at a protest in Kenosha, Wisconsin. Social media accounts that appear to be Rittenhouse's showed the teen is an avid supporter of police, guns, and the Blue Lives Matter movement, <a href=\"https://www.insider.com/kyle-rittenhouse-who-shot-kenosha-protesters-was-obsessed-with-cops-2020-8\">Insider's Haven Orrechio-Egresitz reported</a>.</p><p>Rittenhouse, who was seen with a militia group before the shooting, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-defends-kyle-rittenhouse-charged-with-homicide-in-kenosha-2020-8\">\"probably would have been killed\"</a> if he hadn't fired a semiautomatic rifle at nearby protesters, Trump said at a White House press conference last week.</p><p>Two top congressional Republicans echoed <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-thinks-violence-chaos-the-streets-good-for-his-reelection-2020-8\">Trump's bashing of violence in Democratic-run cities</a> with a letter demanding information from Washington DC Mayor Muriel Bowser on how the city has handled what they called <a href=\"https://republicans-judiciary.house.gov/press-release/republicans-open-probe-into-left-wing-violent-extremists-in-d-c-accuse-mayor-bowser-of-inaction/\">\"left-wing agitators,\"</a></p><p>\"Like other Democrat-run cities, the District of Columbia (D.C.) under your leadership has allowed radical left-wing violent extremists to commit senseless acts of violence and destruction,\" <a href=\"https://republicans-judiciary.house.gov/press-release/republicans-open-probe-into-left-wing-violent-extremists-in-d-c-accuse-mayor-bowser-of-inaction/\">Rep. Jim Jordan of Ohio and James Comer of Kentucky wrote in the letter</a>. \"By your inaction in response to their mayhem, these left-wing agitators have become emboldened to be even more aggressive and more dangerous.\"</p><p><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/barr-gop-present-antifa-major-threat-but-no-evidence-killings-2020-7\">Business Insider's John Haltiwanger previously reported</a> that data on extremism shows far-right groups in the US have been tied to dozens of fatal incidents, while Antifa, which is not a centralized group and has not been designated a terror threat by any US agency, has not been found responsible for any killings.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a 10:59:24","updatedTime":"2020-09-06 10:59:24","title":"A Florida congresswoman was blocked from visiting two USPS mail sorting facilities amid concerns for delayed mail delivery","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/congresswoman-blocked-from-visiting-two-usps-mail-sorting-facilities-2020-9","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f53a66a7ed0ee001e25db7e?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Debbie Wasserman Shultz.\" height=\"3000\" width=\"6000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Debbie Wasserman Shultz.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Samuel Corum/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Florida Democratic congresswoman <a href=\"https://twitter.com/RepDWStweets/status/1301875649678913536\">Debbie Wasserman Schultz said</a> that she was barred from entry to two USPS mail sorting facilities in South Florida.&#160;</li>\n<li>A spokeswoman for USPS said that they could not permit the congresswoman to tour the facilities because they \"were unable to set up the tour on such short notice,\" according to <a href=\"https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/congress/congresswoman-blocked-touring-mail-facility-postal-service-police-n1239359\">NBC News. </a></li>\n<li>Wasserman Schultz told <a href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/2020/09/04/usps-dejoy-wasserman-schultz/\">the Washington Post</a> that her visit was not a \"request\" but a \"notification,\"&#160; and added she was not made aware of any lengthy notification policies during her previous visits earlier in the year.&#160;</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>Florida Congresswoman Debbie Wasserman Schultz said that she was barred from entry into two USPS mail sorting facilities.</p><blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet blockquote\" data-lang=\"en\" data-cards=\"\" data-conversation=\"\">&#8212;Rep. Debbie Wasserman Schultz  (@RepDWStweets) <a href=\"https://twitter.com/mims/statuses/1301875649678913536?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">September 4, 2020</a></blockquote><script async src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"></script><p>A member of the Oversight Committee, Wasserman Schultz <a href=\"https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/congress/congresswoman-blocked-touring-mail-facility-postal-service-police-n1239359\">told NBC News </a>that it is her duty to look into the USPS facilities, as <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/postal-workers-are-squeezing-between-mail-parcels-in-dispatch-rooms-2020-8\">concerns for delayed mail delivery continue to heighten.</a>&#160; &#160;</p><p>Last month, USPS Postmaster General Louis DeJoy <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/louis-dejoy-says-cost-cutting-measures-remain-post-election-2020-8\">testified to the House of Representatives Oversight Committee</a>, which Wasserman Schultz is part of. <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/postmaster-louis-dejoy-testifies-before-the-senate-live-updates-2020-8#republican-sen-rob-portman-and-dejoy-broke-with-trump-to-agree-that-voting-by-mail-is-safe-and-secure-6\">Lawmakers have questioned DeJoy for</a> his various cost-cutting measures such as cutting overtime for postal service workers, cutting post office hours, and <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/pelosi-postmaster-general-no-intention-replacing-machines-mailboxes-2020-8\">displacing some mail collection boxes</a>, as delays in mail delivery cause <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/us-postal-service-delay-funding-crisis-mail-election-trump-explainer-2020-8\">concern for mail-in-ballots in the upcoming election.&#160;</a></p><p>To contend to these concerns and inspect the facilities, Wasserman Schultz arrived early morning for a 4 am tour of a mail processing and distribution center in Opa-Locka, which is within 20 minutes driving distance of Miami, according to The Washington Post. The Post reported that the parking lot entry was roped off with caution tape and local postal service officials told Wasserman that USPS leadership had ordered them to prevent her from entry.&#160;<br><br>Wasserman Schultz was denied entry again at 6:30 am when she visited a different sorting facility in Miami, The Post reported.&#160;</p><p>A spokesperson for USPS said that they did not allow the congresswoman from entering because she did not notify them with enough time in advance, according to NBC News. A congressional aid said that they had notified the USPS early afternoon of the day before her visit, and explained they intentionally requested on short notice for fear that facilities would hide problems during the congresswoman's visit, NBC News reported.&#160;</p><p>\"It wasn't a request,\" Wasserman Schultz told the&#160; Post. \"It was a notification.\"</p><p>The congresswoman added that when she had previously visited the facilities earlier on in the year, she was not made aware of any lengthy visitation policies, the Post and NBC News reported.&#160;</p><p>\"Denying Congress access to the facilities is denying the vital public oversight of our mail system,\" Wasserman Schultz told NBC News.&#160;</p><ul class=\"read-more-links\"><li>Read more:</li><li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/postal-workers-are-squeezing-between-mail-parcels-in-dispatch-rooms-2020-8\" data-read-more-link=\"\" data-e2e-name=\"read-more-link\">US postal workers reveal how 'ugly' their jobs have become under new leadership</a></li><li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/usps-watchdog-inspector-general-dejoy-vote-mail-problems-2020-election-2020-9\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noreferrer noopener\" data-qa=\"message_attachment_title_link\">This new report from the US Postal Service's internal watchdog warns that late ballots, bad envelope designs, and outdated registries could jeopardize voting in November</a></li><li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/us-postal-service-delay-funding-crisis-mail-election-trump-explainer-2020-8\" Democrats</a></li></ul><p>&#160;</p><p>&#160;</p><p>&#160;</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a border=\"0\"></img></a>\n</div><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/nG7KYEdZIlQ\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sat, 05 Sep 2020 15:44:43 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5f53a67b7ed0ee001e25db7f?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"9ea336bcb4926aa879b9681df2761fa2","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn36@2020_1/2020/09/06/02-59-44-442_8bb36d0e40497112.webp","destWidth":5333,"destHeight":4000,"sourceBytes":3113756,"destBytes":3113756,"author":"ichoi@businessinsider.com (Inyoung Choi)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f53a66a7ed0ee001e25db7e?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn68@2020_4/2020/09/06/02-59-49-871_2d1ad575f7277cc9.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn78@2020_1/2020/09/06/02-59-58-308_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=nG7KYEdZIlQ:WuY7lcLoyzs:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn58@2020_4/2020/09/06/03-00-00-992_e41faea6a45d2356.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=nG7KYEdZIlQ:WuY7lcLoyzs:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn95@2020_5/2020/09/06/02-59-49-704_1fa64607e2f8eea9.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn60@2020_6/2020/09/06/02-59-52-353_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=nG7KYEdZIlQ:WuY7lcLoyzs:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn47@2020_1/2020/09/06/02-59-45-463_604e702ed43c8fd4.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/nG7KYEdZIlQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn2@2020_2/2020/09/06/02-59-58-671_dd27e96c5442a5b5.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1599361164605},{"createdTime":"2020-09-06 10:59:24","updatedTime":"2020-09-06 10:59:24","title":"The pandemic exposed how the US economy is failing America's workers. Here's how we can fix those flaws.","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/workers-us-economy-covid-19-income-inequality-wages-healthcare-2020-9","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f515d257ed0ee001e25d66a?format=jpeg\" alt=\"essential workers coronavirus  1\" height=\"994\" width=\"1988\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>A worker disinfects shopping carts at a Publix grocery store in Florida.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Jeffrey Greenberg/Education Images/Universal Images Group via Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>At the beginning of the pandemic and throughout, we've clapped in support of essential and frontline workers.</li>\n<li>We can't stop there. There are four ways we too can help bolster our broken economy.</li>\n<li>Sarita Gupta is director of the Ford Foundation's Future of Work(ers) program.</li>\n<li>This is an opinion column. The thoughts expressed are those of the author.</li>\n</ul>\n<ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>Every evening at the onset of the pandemic, people around the United States clapped for frontline workers, an important public ritual that helped hold us together during uncertain times.</p><p>Our economy has collapsed in the months since.<a href=\"https://www.oecd.org/statistics/job-quality.htm\"> America ranks among the worst performers of all economically advanced countries when it comes to job security</a>, a reality that's been turbocharged by COVID-19. Millions who have experienced pandemic-driven job loss remain unemployed and without the support needed to weather the ongoing economic downturn.</p><p>As we approach Labor Day, a time to honor the country's working people, essential workers — who are<a href=\"https://nwlc-ciw49tixgw5lbab.stackpathdns.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/08/Low-Wage-Jobs-are-Womens-Jobs.pdf\"> disproportionately Black, people of color, immigrants, women, and other marginalized communities</a> —&#160; are being forced to choose between their lives and their livelihoods. A $300 decrease in weekly supplemental federal unemployment benefits has meant families already on the brink of financial ruin are now at risk of losing their homes and not having enough to eat. Meanwhile, <a href=\"https://www.cnn.com/2020/06/04/business/billionaire-wealth-inequality-pandemic-jobs/index.html\">billionaires have doubled and tripled their wealth</a>.&#160;</p><p>The economic fallout from the pandemic is shedding new light on the uneven economic realities faced by working individuals, families, and communities across the US.&#160;</p><p>This collective experience is teaching us that all workers are essential to a functioning economy—including grocery store clerks, delivery drivers, farmers, caregivers, and factory, food processing, and restaurant and transportation workers—as they are the ones who have kept this country alive, despite being denied basic benefits or a say over their conditions.</p><p>This is a signal moment, one that demands a transformation, not just a retreat to \"normal.\" Normal was devouring, unsustainable, and defined by decades of deepening inequality, rising precarity, and economic immobility.&#160;</p><p>This time of crisis is our chance to reimagine an economy that works for everyone. There are ways to not just clap for essential workers, but to clap back at our broken economy. Here are four issues that we must be advocates for, and the organizations that help us do that.</p><h2><strong>A decent standard of living&#160;</strong></h2><p>This means decent and fair compensation for work—a living wage—that enables all working people, regardless of gender, race, citizenship status, or ability, to meet their most basic needs. Wages have remained<a href=\"https://www.epi.org/publication/charting-wage-stagnation/\"> stagnant over the last 40 years</a>, despite a 70% rise in net productivity. Pre-pandemic median annual earnings for<a href=\"https://www.brookings.edu/blog/the-avenue/2019/11/21/low-wage-work-is-more-pervasive-than-you-think-and-there-arent-enough-good-jobs-to-go-around/\"> 44% of US workers was just $18,000</a> and almost<a href=\"https://www.epi.org/publication/wages-and-transfers/\"> 50% of government assistance in 2016 went to full-time working people</a> who fell below the poverty line.&#160;&#160;</p><p>We should follow the leadership of organizations like<a href=\"http://impact.jwj.org/by-the-numbers\"> Jobs with Justice</a>, the<a href=\"https://www.nelp.org/about-us/our-impact\"> National Employment Law Project</a> and<a href=\"https://onefairwage.com/\"> One Fair Wage</a> who have marshaled the collective power of working people across sectors to advance more just and fair compensation in places like New York, California, New Jersey, Illinois, Connecticut, Maryland and across sectors. Their work is a timely rudder for this moment.</p><h2><strong>Guaranteed access to healthcare, paid leave, and benefits&#160;</strong></h2><p>Before the onset of the pandemic,<a href=\"https://www.bls.gov/ncs/ebs/\"> one in four working people in the US</a>—approximately 34 million people—lacked paid sick leave. While just<a href=\"https://www.pewresearch.org/fact-tank/2020/03/12/as-coronavirus-spreads-which-u-s-workers-have-paid-sick-leave-and-which-dont/\"> 8% of working people in the top quarter of earnings lacked access to paid sick days, almost half of those in the lowest quarter faced the same challenge</a>. Additionally, growing swaths of the workforce, including those in gig, domestic caregiving, food processing, and farm work, did not have access to healthcare and other basic benefits, particularly among immigrant and migrant communities.&#160;</p><p>In the US, the pandemic is revealing how predicating an economy on a system that ties healthcare to employment and incentivizes limitations to paid leave and basic benefits impacts us all.&#160;</p><p>Coalitions like<a href=\"https://familyvaluesatwork.org/media-center/timeline-of-wins/\"> Family Values @ Work</a> and<a href=\"https://paidleaveforall.org/\"> Paid Leave for All</a> are making major strides in campaigning for and securing paid leave and sick days across the United States. <em>We need to build an economy that guarantees access to critical benefits for all working people and their families.</em></p><p>&#160;</p><iframe width=\"560\" height=\"315\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/MZAmuYLfZdU\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen></iframe><p>&#160;</p><p><em>&#160;</em></p><h2><strong>A robust care infrastructure</strong></h2><p>Care work is essential to a functioning and sustainable economy. Whether caring for children or elderly parents, growing numbers of workers need care support<a href=\"https://www.ted.com/talks/ai_jen_poo_the_work_that_makes_all_other_work_possible\"> to remain in the labor force</a>. Yet, it remains barely affordable and accessible to many working families.&#160;</p><p>Working parents in low-wage work have been found to spend up to a<a href=\"http://www.diversitydatakids.org/sites/default/files/2020-02/child-care_update.pdf\"> quarter of their annual income on childcare expenses</a>. Today, many working parents are struggling to manage dueling work and childcare responsibilities intensified by school and childcare center closings.</p><p>Care work has long been undervalued in the US economy, which lags behind many industrialized countries in its approaches to<a href=\"https://www.oecd.org/els/soc/PF3_1_Public_spending_on_childcare_and_early_education.pdf\"> childcare</a> and<a href=\"https://www.commonwealthfund.org/publications/surveys/2017/nov/2017-commonwealth-fund-international-health-policy-survey-older\"> eldercare</a>. Care workers themselves were<a href=\"https://www.nelp.org/blog/wage-hour-protections-for-home-care-workers-take-effect/\"> denied labor protections until just a few years ago</a> and still continue to<a href=\"https://www.brookings.edu/research/essential-but-undervalued-millions-of-health-care-workers-arent-getting-the-pay-or-respect-they-deserve-in-the-covid-19-pandemic/#:~:text=Home%20health%20and%20personal%20care,some%20form%20of%20public%20assistance.\"> face </a>low wages. Consequently, up to<a href=\"https://phinational.org/policy-research/workforce-data-center/#tab=National+Data&natvar=Public+Assistanceance\"> 42% of care workers have been found to rely on public assistance</a> for their food, healthcare, and cash needs.&#160;</p><p>We need a bold and robust infrastructure for caregiving that ensures working people can afford care. The<a href=\"https://www.domesticworkers.org/\"> National Domestic Worker Alliance</a> is demonstrating how this national caregiving challenge can be addressed through its<a href=\"https://www.domesticworkers.org/sites/all/themes/NDWA2017/images/LearnMore.pdf\"> Domestic Workers Bill of Rights</a> which has seen adoption in several states. Others like the<a href=\"https://nwlc.org/issue/child-care/\"> National Women's Law Center</a> and<a href=\"https://universalfamilycare.org/\"> Caring Across Generations</a> are articulating and driving bold visions for universal care.</p><h2><strong>Safe and healthy working conditions&#160;</strong></h2><p>Working people simply desire to conduct their work in environments where they can stay safe and healthy. Yet, this is not prioritized by many US employers where up to<a href=\"https://www.rand.org/pubs/research_reports/RR2014.html\"> 50% of US workers face hazardous or unpleasant conditions</a>. More recently, workers on the frontlines of the pandemic continue to find themselves working without adequate safety measures or equipment.&#160;</p><p>This is disproportionately experienced among workers who are Black or come from other communities of color. Recent polls indicate that up to<a href=\"https://www.epi.org/publication/covid-risks-and-hazard-pay/\"> 73% of Black Americans have worked outside their homes during the pandemic compared to half of white workers. Some 68% of those Black workers</a> working outside their homes were concerned with risks of contracting and spreading the virus. More importantly, Black workers were found to be<a href=\"https://s27147.pcdn.co/wp-content/uploads/Silenced-About-COVID-19-Workplace-Fear-Retaliation-June-2020.pdf\"> more than two times as likely than white workers to experience retaliation</a> by employers when they raised their concerns about COVID-19.&#160;</p><p>We need an economy that values the safety of workers as people and as critical drivers of economic activity; where working people have a collective voice in shaping their work conditions without fear of retaliation.</p><p>Workers with organizations such as<a href=\"https://united4respect.org/\"> United for Respect</a> are calling for changes that prioritize their safety and well-being amidst this pandemic. They are also experimenting around shared employer-worker governance models where workers can voice their concerns, including through<a href=\"https://www.fastcompany.com/90429425/how-a-few-former-toys-r-us-employees-are-leading-the-brands-comeback-and-putting-workers-first\"> the worker board they established at Toys \"R\" Us</a> following its emergence from bankruptcy.<a href=\"https://home.coworker.org/\"> CoWorker.org</a> is supporting workers in the tech, gig, and other sectors to collectively raise their voices and transform their workplaces.</p><p>The rampant inequality working people face is not a fire that will burn itself out. The decisions we make, the demands we deliver, will determine whether we recover or relapse, whether we withstand this crisis and prevail over those to come. Let's honor essential workers by committing to a fight to advance an economy that truly works for all. The future of work must be today.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a Edition.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Carlex Design</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Polish car-customization firm Carlex Design just dropped images of its latest offering &#8212; a lavish Land Rover Defender catered to the yachting community.&#160;</li>\n<li>Dubbed the Defender Yachting Edition, the SUV boasts a brushed-silver exterior and a custom interior with wood flooring.</li>\n<li>Carlex also offers a yacht-themed package for the Mercedes-Benz G-Wagen and the Mercedes X-Class pickup, which isn't available in the US.&#160;</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>Sometimes when you're on the road, you can't help but wish you were out at sea — traffic and the sound of the pavement miles away. Or at least, that's probably how the owners of luxury yachts feel.&#160;</p><p>Luckily, Polish customization company&#160;<a href=\"https://www.carlexdesign.com/en/\">Carlex Design</a> exists. The firm dropped designs for a yacht-themed Mercedes-Benz G-Wagen earlier this year, and now there's a new member of that lineup: the Land Rover Defender.&#160;</p><p>The Land Rover Defender Yachting Edition, which Carlex recently shared details and renderings of, is \"made for those who prioritise luxury, love sunny, marine style, and need off-road performance and reliability,\" the company said. On the outside, Carlex's new Defender gets a brushed-silver paint job, bespoke rims, and a spare-tire cover with an extravagant compass design.&#160;But it's on the inside where things get truly nautical.&#160;</p><p>Keep scrolling to take a look at the luxurious Land Rover Defender Yachting Edition.&#160;</p>\n<div id=\"slideshow\">\n\tPolish firm Carlex Design customizes both car and boat interiors — and, every so often, it mashes those two parts of its business together to create something wild.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f500fb8e6ff30001d4e6c2e?format=jpeg\" boat-themed custom cars. The firm also designed a Yachting-Edition Mercedes-Benz G-Wagen ...\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5e98b724c023207eb27a3863?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Carlex Design G Yachting Limited Edition\" height=\"1872\" width=\"3000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Carlex Design G Yachting Limited Edition\n<p class=\"copyright\">Carlex Design</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\t... with a similarly woody interior.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5e98b71a8427e911290d5f42?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Carlex Design G Yachting Limited Edition\" height=\"1628\" width=\"1395\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Carlex Design G Yachting Limited Edition\n<p class=\"copyright\">Carlex Design</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tAnd the company also created a Yachting version of the X-Class pickup ...\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5e98ca61dcd88c1cec5e01e7?format=jpeg\" alt=\"MERCEDES XCLASS YACHTING\" height=\"900\" width=\"1280\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Mercedes X-Class Yachting style package.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Carlex Design</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\t... complete with teak decking on the bed.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5e98b70dc023207e93182a47?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Carlex Design G Yachting Limited Edition\" height=\"900\" width=\"1280\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Carlex Design G Yachting Limited Edition\n<p class=\"copyright\">Carlex Design</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tCarlex didn't share pricing for the Defender Yachting Edition just yet. But considering the SUV itself will run you at least $50,000, the whole package won't come cheap.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f501169e6ff30001d4e6c3b?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Land Rover Defender Yachting Edition\" height=\"1562\" width=\"2500\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Land Rover Defender Yachting Edition.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Carlex Design</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n</div><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a 2020 11:47:00 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5f527e35e6ff30001d4e7318?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"a8227abc3e1cad36a482bd506c3c1e72","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn37@2020_2/2020/09/06/02-59-44-363_0c64c3af5abe1cf5.webp","destWidth":2082,"destHeight":1562,"sourceBytes":187060,"destBytes":187060,"author":"tlevin@businessinsider.com (Tim Levin)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f501169e6ff30001d4e6c3b?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn96@2020_6/2020/09/06/02-59-48-068_1818e0858b2fa508.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f500fb8e6ff30001d4e6c2e?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn11@2020_1/2020/09/06/02-59-46-218_c4ad1e56e550867c.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f500ef9e6ff30001d4e6c29?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn71@2020_5/2020/09/06/02-59-50-781_9bc50a2376a0f91e.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f5016497ed0ee001e25d278?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn85@2020_3/2020/09/06/02-59-57-427_e591a996e180673c.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f500f207ed0ee001e25d261?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn32@2020_1/2020/09/06/02-59-47-407_a97bbd8a77b0aba7.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f501745e6ff30001d4e6c4d?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn99@2020_5/2020/09/06/02-59-45-191_6a0709ffb8532ece.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f500faf7ed0ee001e25d264?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn60@2020_5/2020/09/06/02-59-44-301_82d79283856040c6.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f500f05e6ff30001d4e6c2a?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn46@2020_3/2020/09/06/02-59-58-019_b5d1e445057f651e.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f5016b0e6ff30001d4e6c49?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn93@2020_5/2020/09/06/02-59-56-788_a481fa09571f2519.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f50166b7ed0ee001e25d27a?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn30@2020_4/2020/09/06/02-59-55-006_a11ae3cae7723161.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f5016db7ed0ee001e25d27c?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn65@2020_6/2020/09/06/02-59-56-241_48ab241d302816e7.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f5016fbe6ff30001d4e6c4b?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn72@2020_6/2020/09/06/02-59-52-408_77137761e3823b32.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f5017277ed0ee001e25d27e?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn72@2020_6/2020/09/06/02-59-49-626_758ed5d93199855b.webp","https://i.insider.com/5e98b724c023207eb27a3863?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn30@2020_3/2020/09/06/03-00-00-205_7f87634c360a9e8b.webp","https://i.insider.com/5e98b71a8427e911290d5f42?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn24@2020_2/2020/09/06/02-59-53-288_0c9bc2ea91fad32c.webp","https://i.insider.com/5e98ca61dcd88c1cec5e01e7?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn7@2020_4/2020/09/06/02-59-48-106_c37bb60f68aa10ff.webp","https://i.insider.com/5e98b70dc023207e93182a47?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn31@2020_5/2020/09/06/02-59-53-140_84f4b55d691ee4a2.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn78@2020_1/2020/09/06/02-59-58-308_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=jN3VnpXJIc4:a2gOnENaWXg:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn80@2020_1/2020/09/06/02-59-45-827_8c0def4f726339b4.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=jN3VnpXJIc4:a2gOnENaWXg:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn77@2020_6/2020/09/06/03-00-00-181_25b50d7d38bc8003.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn60@2020_6/2020/09/06/02-59-52-353_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=jN3VnpXJIc4:a2gOnENaWXg:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn48@2020_6/2020/09/06/02-59-51-255_a2ab2bdf743c3267.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/jN3VnpXJIc4":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn4@2020_5/2020/09/06/02-59-52-894_767121756f61dd9f.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1599361164655},{"createdTime":"2020-09-06 10:59:24","updatedTime":"2020-09-06 10:59:24","title":"How to avoid making bad hires, and what to do if you already did","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-to-avoid-making-bad-hires-business-advice-2020-9","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5d85299e2e22af13a5592d75?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Queer employee upset\" height=\"3109\" width=\"4146\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>A hire with a bad attitude can spread negativity in the office.\n<p class=\"copyright\">MangoStar_Studio/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>A healthy, upbeat team dynamic is important for the well-being of any company, large or small. Unfortunately, sometimes just one bad employee can spoil an entire team's success.</li>\n<li>To avoid making a bad hire, grow your company slowly &#8212; don't rush into hiring anyone, and make sure they have the personality and qualities you're looking for.</li>\n<li>If you've already made a bad hire, do what you can to communicate with them to reach a mutual solution and see if the relationship can improve.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>&#160;</p><p>At the 2018&#160;Olympics in PyeongChang, <a href=\"https://www.reuters.com/article/us-olympics-2018-norway-medals/norway-win-38th-pyeongchang-medal-to-surpass-u-s-record-idUSKCN1G8057\">Norway</a> took home more gold medals than any other country.</p><p>But they didn't just win the most medals that year — they won more than any other country in a single winter Olympics<em> ever</em>.</p><p>The secret behind their success? No jerks.</p><p>\"We have a saying,\" Alpine skier Aksel Lund Svindal&#160;<a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2018/02/15/sports/olympics/norway-skiing-olympics.html?login=smartlock&auth=login-smartlocklock\" rel=\"nofollow\">told</a> The&#160;New York Times. \"There is almost no skill or ability you can have that is so good it allows you to ruin the social qualities of the&#160;<a href=\"https://www.entrepreneur.com/topic/team\" data-ga-category=\"autotag-linking\" data-ga-label=\"ai-metadata\" data-ga-action=\"/topic/team\">team</a>.\"</p><p>For Norway's men's ski team, keeping jerks at bay has allowed them to form a strong bond that improves their performance in competition: Every Friday, the team gathers for taco night. Their dynamic is so functional that they'll share hotel rooms — and even beds — while they're on the road. They share all of their tactics and techniques with one another freely, ensuring everyone is bringing their absolute best to the slopes.</p><p>&#160;\"If you have teammates who consistently lift you up, then the environment will make you happy,\" Svindal's teammate, Kjetil Jansrud, said. \"You'll work harder and stay motivated. You're giving yourself your best chance to win.\"</p><p>The same, of course, is true of the workplace. A healthy team dynamic is crucial to the well-being of the company. But that also means that one bad hire can collapse an otherwise healthy office ecosystem.&#160;</p><h2>The cost of a bad hire&#160;</h2><p>Bad hires are expensive on several levels.&#160;Zappos&#160;CEO&#160;Tony Hsieh, whose company boasts notoriously&#160;happy employees,&#160;<a href=\"https://www.forbes.com/sites/falonfatemi/2016/09/28/the-true-cost-of-a-bad-hire-its-more-than-you-think/#511156314aa4\" rel=\"nofollow\">once estimated</a>&#160;that bad hires cost the company \"well over $100 million.\"</p><p>But your bottom line isn't even where a bad hire hurts the most. In fact, chief financial officers rank bad hires' impact on morale and&#160;productivity&#160;ahead of monetary loss.</p><p>As the Norwegian men's ski team knows, an employee that doesn't fit with the company's culture can have a destabilizing effect on the whole organization.</p><p>In some cases, productivity across the board can decrease, since others need to work harder to meet targets and goals to compensate for someone who isn't pulling their weight. This increases the risk of driving your best team members out, taking their skills and knowledge with them.</p><p>They can also damage your company's reputation both outwardly and inwardly. Client-facing bad hires can permanently harm relationships with customers. Internally, word of mouth and review websites like Glassdoor allow employees to make educated decisions about where they want to work. Satisfied employees will often refer friends and colleagues to your company. If they're unhappy, though, they'll often warn talented, would-be hires to stay away.</p><h2>How to avoid making a bad hire</h2><p>Each&#160;employee you hire won't be perfect. But there are ways of increasing your odds of choosing a team that will go the distance.</p><p>Before you even post an ad, figure out exactly what skills you want a new hire to have. Create a job description that clearly outlines job duties and the experience needed to excel. A detailed outline will not only help attract talent that's actually right for the job, but it will give you a guide to stick to&#160;in order to avoid getting sidetracked.</p><p>As a bootstrapped founder, I grew my company,&#160;JotForm,&#160;slowly and carefully. This gradual growth has allowed me to figure out what I truly value. I've made some mistakes, but in the process of expanding from a solo venture to a company with over 250 employees, I've learned a lot about what to look for in a hire.</p><p>One of my main takeaways? Having the right skills is only a piece of the puzzle.</p><p>Throughout the interview process, look for what HBR&#160;<a href=\"https://hbr.org/2016/02/how-to-avoid-hiring-a-toxic-employee\" rel=\"nofollow\">terms</a>&#160;\"signs of civility.\" Asking the applicant how she managed past situations provides more insight than presenting hypothetical scenarios, like \"how would you handle…\" or \"what would you do if…\" and so on.&#160;Make your values known during the interview, and ask for examples of how their past behavior matches those values.</p><p>Zappos actually has two interview types. The first explores the candidate's abilities, experience, etc. But they also conduct another round specifically to determine cultural fit. To get the job, a candidate needs to pass both types.</p><p>Another helpful Zappos tactic is seeking references in unexpected places. When a candidate flies in for an interview, the company sends a shuttle to the airport. Company leaders will later ask the driver if the applicant was nice, or whether they were rude. No matter how qualified the candidate, the rude ones never make the cut.</p><p>Remember the Norwegian ski team? No jerks.</p><h2>What to do if you've made a bad hire</h2><p>Let's face it — sometimes, despite doing everything right, you wind up with someone who just isn't a good fit.</p><p>Don't beat yourself up: Only 19% of new hires are <a href=\"https://hbr.org/2018/08/what-to-do-when-you-realize-you-made-a-bad-hire\" rel=\"nofollow\">considered</a> completely successful. By 18 months, 46% are deemed failures. Yikes.</p><p>So what to do when you've mis-hired?</p><p>Rather than hoping that the person will magically change overnight, it's best to have a direct conversation with your new recruit. Share your concerns with them, and explore solutions that might satisfy you both.</p><p>If that doesn't work, it's time to evaluate the current and future expenses of hanging on to the hire. Has there been an increase in workplace conflict? Are other employees struggling to cover for them? Often, you won't even realize the extent of the negative impact the bad hire has had until you remove them.</p><p>If the relationship can't be saved, you can still make their departure as painless as possible. Work with your HR department and try to negotiate a plan that benefits everyone.</p><p>If parting ways with the employee is not an option, you can at least mitigate the damage:&#160;<a href=\"https://hbr.org/2016/10/how-to-manage-a-toxic-employee\" rel=\"nofollow\">Separate</a> them from the rest of the team by rearranging desks or holding fewer all-hands meetings. Christine Porath, an associate professor at Georgetown and the author of \"Mastering Civility: A Manifesto for the Workplace,\" refers to this as \"immunizing\" others.</p><p>\"You're trying to protect people like you would with a disease,\" Porath told <a href=\"https://hbr.org/2016/10/how-to-manage-a-toxic-employee\">Harvard Business Review</a>. \"You will hopefully decrease the number of run-ins and [minimize] the cognitive loss.\"</p><p>That said, it's important not to let one individual take up all your time and energy. Porath suggests surrounding yourself with supportive, positive people, and looking for meaning and purpose in your work.</p><p>\"If someone is draining you, build yourself up by exercising, eating right, sleeping, and taking breaks, both short-term ones, and [long-term] vacations,\" she <a href=\"https://hbr.org/2016/10/how-to-manage-a-toxic-employee\">said</a>. \"Being healthy and proactive is the one thing we know that buffers people from the effects of toxic behavior.\"</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5d85299e2e22af13a5592d75?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"4a42f2996e98168f33956e4102ca8c82","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn4@2020_6/2020/09/06/02-59-24-956_75b827575dda6e3d.webp","destWidth":4146,"destHeight":3109,"sourceBytes":341422,"destBytes":341422,"author":"insider@insider.com Tank)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5d85299e2e22af13a5592d75?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn4@2020_6/2020/09/06/02-59-24-956_75b827575dda6e3d.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn78@2020_1/2020/09/06/02-59-58-308_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=ye5YSteBD-U:881o3DNZC38:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn45@2020_5/2020/09/06/02-59-58-038_401417bcde713793.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=ye5YSteBD-U:881o3DNZC38:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn60@2020_2/2020/09/06/02-59-51-367_9a29b377b92e2470.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn60@2020_6/2020/09/06/02-59-52-353_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=ye5YSteBD-U:881o3DNZC38:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn61@2020_2/2020/09/06/03-00-01-602_8023a2c06932ae13.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/ye5YSteBD-U":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn23@2020_5/2020/09/06/02-59-52-043_e6228bbf7931e385.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1599361164653},{"createdTime":"2020-09-06 10:59:24","updatedTime":"2020-09-06 10:59:24","title":"Facebook takes down pages for right-wing group Patriot Prayer after one member died in a Portland altercation","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/facebook-removes-pages-for-right-wing-group-patriot-prayer-founder-2020-9","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f1f1c992618b946b63d3a06?format=jpeg\" alt=\"facebook\" height=\"3333\" width=\"5000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>In this photo illustration a Facebook logo seen displayed on a smartphone.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Photo Illustration by Rafael Henrique/SOPA Images/LightRocket via Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Facebook took down multiple pages for right-wing group Patriot Prayer and the group's founder, Joey Gibson.&#160;</li>\n<li>One of the members of Patriot Prayer was shot and killed during a protest in Portland, Oregon, last Saturday.</li>\n<li>A company spokesperson told Reuters that the social media platform removed the pages to prevent the spread of \"violent social militias\" on the site.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>In a move to counteract \"violent social militias,\" Facebook said it took down multiple pages that had belonged to right-wing group Patriot Prayer and founder Joey Gibson.&#160;</p><p>Patriot Prayer is a <a href=\"https://www.insider.com/what-is-patriot-prayer-joey-gibson-right-wing-group-2020-8\">far-right group based in the Pacific Northwest region</a> that frequently hosts pro-Trump rallies.</p><p>The group received national attention this week after one of its members was <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/one-shot-dead-in-portland-trump-supporters-blm-protesters-clash-2020-8\">killed during a protest last Saturday</a> in Portland, Oregon. The member, Aaron \"Jay\" Danielson, was shot during a confrontation between Black Lives Matter activists and pro-Trump supporters.&#160;</p><p>Patriot Prayer rallies <a href=\"https://www.splcenter.org/hatewatch/2020/08/31/what-we-know-about-patriot-prayer\">frequently feature appearances by members of the Proud Boys</a>, an antigovernment extremist organization that was designated a hate group by the nonprofit Southern Poverty Law Center.</p><p>Gibson, a right-wing activist who leads the group, has been organizing pro-Trump rallies in multiple U.S. cities <a href=\"https://www.insider.com/what-is-patriot-prayer-joey-gibson-right-wing-group-2020-8\">since 2016</a>. Supporters usually come armed to the rallies, which generally attract a lot of attention from counter-protesters. Rallies also frequently result in violence and street fighting, according to the <a href=\"https://www.splcenter.org/hatewatch/2018/10/15/patriot-prayer-again-brings-violence-portland-flash-march-downtown-rounding-out-weekend-far\">SPLC</a>.&#160;</p><p>Company spokesperson Andy Stone said Facebook removed the pages to prevent the spread of \"violent social militias\" on its site, Reuters <a href=\"https://www.reuters.com/article/us-global-race-protests-portland-faceboo/facebook-removes-pages-of-right-wing-group-patriot-prayer-after-portland-unrest-idUSKBN25V2UH\">reported</a> Friday.&#160;</p><p>Last month, Facebook <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/facebook-cracks-down-qanon-after-reaching-millions-people-2020-8\">announced an expansion</a> to its \"Dangerous Individuals and Organizations\" policy to include \"organizations and movements that have demonstrated significant risks to public safety but do not meet the rigorous criteria to be designated as a dangerous organization and banned from having any presence on our platform.\"</p><p>\"We are taking action against Facebook Pages, Groups and Instagram accounts tied to offline anarchist groups that support violent acts amidst protests, US-based militia organizations and QAnon,\" the company wrote in a <a href=\"https://about.fb.com/news/2020/08/addressing-movements-and-organizations-tied-to-violence/\">press release</a>.&#160;</p><p>Facebook did not immediately return a request for comment from Business Insider.&#160;</p><p>Since the inception of the Patriot Prayer page in 2017 and up until it got shut down, the page reached almost 45,000 Facebook followers, Reuters reported.</p><p>It's unclear whether Twitter and YouTube will follow in Facebook's steps. Patriot Prayer accounts on both platforms have tens of thousands of followers. Neither Twitter nor YouTube immediately responded to a request for comment from Business Insider.&#160;</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/facebook-removes-pages-for-right-wing-group-patriot-prayer-founder-2020-9'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a border=\"0\"></img></a>\n</div><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/2hY7rtKFoNc\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sat, 05 Sep 2020 18:36:00 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5f53c6cf7ed0ee001e25db93?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"fb2f7b1532f2d9efa1e0d72646d16619","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn3@2020_5/2020/09/06/02-59-50-927_d1dcd8d761ea2832.webp","destWidth":4443,"destHeight":3332,"sourceBytes":806934,"destBytes":806934,"author":"ydzhanova@businessinsider.com (Yelena Dzhanova)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f1f1c992618b946b63d3a06?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn31@2020_3/2020/09/06/02-59-50-336_cd5327a560684f4f.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn78@2020_1/2020/09/06/02-59-58-308_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=2hY7rtKFoNc:VjvcxzaTHsc:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn84@2020_6/2020/09/06/02-59-45-666_9d2764c60da8b957.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=2hY7rtKFoNc:VjvcxzaTHsc:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn28@2020_3/2020/09/06/02-59-49-141_049300e34a90fb48.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn60@2020_6/2020/09/06/02-59-52-353_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=2hY7rtKFoNc:VjvcxzaTHsc:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn78@2020_5/2020/09/06/02-59-53-602_348b1cbc03f64c92.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/2hY7rtKFoNc":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn41@2020_5/2020/09/06/03-00-01-427_2d70cc1cf62d03d5.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1599361164605},{"createdTime":"2020-09-06 10:59:24","updatedTime":"2020-09-06 10:59:24","title":"A record number of Black women are representing America in the US Open's singles draw","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/record-number-black-women-playing-us-open-2020-9","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f539fed7ed0ee001e25db75?format=jpeg\" alt=\"US open Serena Williams\" height=\"1333\" width=\"1778\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Serena Williams returns a shot to Margarita Gasparyan, of Russia during the third round of the US Open tennis championships, Thursday, September 3, 2020, in New York.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Frank Franklin II/AP</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Serena Williams, who holds 23 Grand Slam singles titles, will play against 2017 US Open singles winner Sloane Stephens for their third rounds this afternoon.</li>\n<li>The two athletes are part of the record number of 12 American Black women in the tournament, according to <a href=\"https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/tennis/2020/09/05/serena-williams-sloane-stephens-among-record-12-black-women-us-open/5722318002/\">USA Today</a>.</li>\n<li>Stephens said that seeing Black women \"leading our sport\" is \"amazing,\"&#160;<a href=\"https://www.reuters.com/article/us-tennis-usopen-stephens/stephens-sees-success-of-black-women-inspiring-new-generation-idUSKBN25V0ZJ\">Reuters</a> reported.</li>\n<li>Martin Blackman, the general manager of the United States Tennis Association's player development, told USA Today that expanded representation is a result of efforts within USTA player development.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>Serena Williams, who is seeking her 24th Grand Slam singles title, will play Sloane Stephens in their <a href=\"https://www.usopen.org/en_US/news/articles/2020-09-03/serena_williams_powers_into_round_3_of_the_2020_us_open.html\">third-round match</a> this afternoon at 2 p.m. EST.</p><p>The match between the two comes as the portion of American women in this year's US Open marks a step toward representation for Black women within the sport. According to <a href=\"https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/tennis/2020/09/05/serena-williams-sloane-stephens-among-record-12-black-women-us-open/5722318002/\">USA Today</a>, a record of 12 Black women make up 37.5% of the 32 US women singles or 9.4% of the overall 128 women.</p><p>Just a decade ago at the 2010 US Open, Venus Williams was the only Black woman in the women's singles draw, according to <a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/09/04/sports/tennis/us-open-black-players-serena-venus-williams.html\">The New York Times</a>. Her sister was out because of an injury.</p><p>Stephens, who won the US singles title back in 2017, told <a href=\"https://www.reuters.com/article/us-tennis-usopen-stephens/stephens-sees-success-of-black-women-inspiring-new-generation-idUSKBN25V0ZJ\">Reuters</a> that seeing more Black women in the sport can inspire the next generation of players.</p><p>\"Right now ... leading our sport on the women's side is African-American women, which is amazing,\" Stephens said, according to Reuters.</p><p>Hailey Baptiste, who was one of the women to get a wild card this year, shared a similar sentiment in <a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/09/04/sports/tennis/us-open-black-players-serena-venus-williams.html\">The New York Times</a>.</p><p>\"I feel like it's amazing to see so many girls that look like me playing in the tournament and the main draw,\" Baptiste told The Times.</p><p>Although representation has seemed to grow in the sport since great success from Black tennis players like the Williams sisters, this surge <a href=\"https://theundefeated.com/features/where-are-the-black-men-in-tennis/\">appears greater for women than men</a>.</p><p>Martin Blackman, the general manager of United States Tennis Association's player development who is also Black, told The Times that in the USTA training camps alone the Black participation rate is about 15% for girls and only 5-7% for boys.</p><p>Blackman also credits some of the success to \"the structure and stability of the USTA player development setup,\" according to USA Today. He also emphasized having programs that reach underserved communities like the USTA training camps.</p><p>Saturday brings a highly anticipated match as Stephens won against Belarusian tennis player Olga Govortsova on Thursday in her second round and against Romanian tennis player Mihaela Buzărnescu on Tuesday in her first round. Williams won against Russian tennis player Margarita Gasparyan on Thursday and against American tennis player Kristie Ahn on Tuesday.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a back up. Last quarter, wealth startups raised $1.2 billion in venture funding, up from <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/wealth-management-investment-tech-vc-deals-fell-q1-cb-insights-2020-5\">$450 million during the first quarter</a>, according to CB Insights data.</p><p>Rebecca Ungarino asked VCs and other big investors to nominate early-stage startups in the wealth management ecosystem that they see as up-and-comers. for the latest on layoffs for legal and consulting jobs, and a dive into the ecosystem of 13-F followers who are slamming a proposal to eliminate the quarterly paperwork for many funds.&#160;</p><p>Enjoy the rest of the weekend,&#160;</p><p>Meredith&#160;</p><hr><h2><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/nyse-direct-listings-plans-sec-investors-protection-legal-concerns-2020-9\">Why some big investors are bashing a plan to let companies raise fresh money through direct listings</a></h2><h1><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/nyse-direct-listings-plans-sec-investors-protection-legal-concerns-2020-9\"><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f3aca70ea6ce0002839aca5?format=jpeg\" alt=\"startup unicorn\" height=\"1000\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Plush Stuff unicorns on show during the Toy Fair 2019, at Olympia in London.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Kirsty O&#39;Connor/PA Images via Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure></a></h1><p>In late August, the Securities and Exchange Commission&#160;<a href=\"https://www.sec.gov/rules/sro/nyse/2020/34-89684.pdf\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"20\" data-uri=\"39494b13d972fb8e373e74f8ca901b09\">greenlighted</a> the NYSE's plan to allow primary direct listings, in which companies can issue new shares while also leapfrogging the costly underwriting process.</p><p>But an industry group that represents big-money investors like pension funds filed a last-minute attempt to thwart the NYSE's plan. They argued that new form of direct listings would allow companies to circumvent shareholder protections built into the IPO process and thus put investors at risk.</p><p>Yoonji Han talked with securities experts who laid out the critics' concerns about 'untraceable' shares and fuzzy liability. <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/nyse-direct-listings-plans-sec-investors-protection-legal-concerns-2020-9\">You can read the full story here.</a></p><hr><h2><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/epicor-planning-more-acquisitions-following-sale-clayton-dubilier-and-rice-2020-9\">Enterprise-software maker Epicor is planning a bigger M&#38;A push once it changes hands to Clayton Dubilier &#38; Rice </a></h2><p><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/epicor-planning-more-acquisitions-following-sale-clayton-dubilier-and-rice-2020-9\"><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f4fc125e6ff30001d4e6a21?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Steve Murphy\" height=\"421\" width=\"843\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Steve Murphy, CEO of Epicor\n<p class=\"copyright\">Epicor</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure></a></p><p>Clayton Dubilier &#38; Rice has agreed to buy Epicor for $4.7 billion from KKR, which had owned the software company for four years and expanded its business through acquisitions and new product launches.</p><p>And Steve Murphy, CEO of Epicor, told Casey Sullivan that CD&#38;R \"may have an idea or two about some bigger M&#38;A.\" He laid out companies that could be attractive: businesses with between $250 million and $300 million in revenue operating in manufacturing, distribution, retail, and automotive sectors. <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/epicor-planning-more-acquisitions-following-sale-clayton-dubilier-and-rice-2020-9\">You can read the full story here.&#160;</a></p><hr><h2><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/why-tech-companies-keep-adding-new-offices-while-working-remote-2020-8\">The Big Tech office isn't dead</a></h2><p><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/why-tech-companies-keep-adding-new-offices-while-working-remote-2020-8\"><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f46c4c5cd2fec00296a45fc?format=jpeg\" alt=\"FILE PHOTO: A 3D printed Facebook logo is placed between small toy people figures in front of a keyboard in this illustration taken April 12, 2020. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration\" height=\"2248\" width=\"4496\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>A 3D printed Facebook logo\n<p class=\"copyright\">Reuters</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure></a></p><p>While many large companies have been shrinking their office footprints, big tech firms like Google, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/facebook-signs-730000-square-foot-office-lease-at-farley-building-2020-8\">Facebook</a>, and Amazon are doing the opposite.</p><p>Growth prospects for tech companies have been getting even stronger during the pandemic. Most also believe that flexible working arrangements won't diminish the importance of offices for recruiting and collaboration. Dan Geiger and Alex Nicoll took a look at why giants like Facebook and Amazon keep gobbling up space while telling workers they can stay home. <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/why-tech-companies-keep-adding-new-offices-while-working-remote-2020-8\">You can read that story here.&#160;</a></p><hr><h2><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/effects-of-sec-proposal-on-13-f-requirement-investment-research-2020-8\">'Literally no one was asking for this, zero'</a></h2><h2><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/effects-of-sec-proposal-on-13-f-requirement-investment-research-2020-8\"><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f516db57ed0ee001e25d6b0?format=jpeg\" alt=\"sec rule change chairman jay clayton 2x1\" height=\"1200\" width=\"2400\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Shannon Stapleton/Reuters; Andrew Harnik/AP; Samantha Lee/Business Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure></a></h2><p>The Securities and Exchange Commission has proposed changing a rule in a way that would eliminate most investment managers' quarterly filings, called 13-Fs, which show equity holdings at quarter's end. The SEC said the change will allay expense-and regulatory-related burdens for small funds and protect investment strategies.</p><p>Bradley Saacks and Rebecca Ungarino Business spoke with executives, academics, and other industry insiders about how the proposal could change the institutional investment industry — and how it's being received.<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/effects-of-sec-proposal-on-13-f-requirement-investment-research-2020-8\"> You can read the full story here.&#160;</a></p><hr><h2>Layoff watch</h2><ul><li raising pay for people who remain, with firm leaders citing a 'fundamental shift' in working conditions: <a 2020 13:48:18 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5f47e5a6cd2fec00296a4972?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"f386b43ad3ea122608b982d9d20ea8b4","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn7@2020_1/2020/09/06/02-59-50-882_656e7eb99bdf4df6.webp","destWidth":2000,"destHeight":1500,"sourceBytes":348404,"destBytes":348404,"author":"mmazzilli@businessinsider.com (Meredith Mazzilli)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f3aca70ea6ce0002839aca5?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn82@2020_3/2020/09/06/02-59-58-425_b9d3cea2adb0d696.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f4fc125e6ff30001d4e6a21?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn58@2020_4/2020/09/06/02-59-54-430_709d680d165f3bd6.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f46c4c5cd2fec00296a45fc?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn94@2020_5/2020/09/06/02-59-59-633_8811557f3b9c08a1.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f516db57ed0ee001e25d6b0?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn29@2020_5/2020/09/06/02-59-55-923_ac1f7d8d94013a68.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn78@2020_1/2020/09/06/02-59-58-308_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=uHejBRGjvJ8:ezeLm3D-WHs:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn94@2020_3/2020/09/06/02-59-54-620_55130d03b698bd31.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=uHejBRGjvJ8:ezeLm3D-WHs:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn64@2020_6/2020/09/06/02-59-53-360_b54b1ca2b458db4c.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn60@2020_6/2020/09/06/02-59-52-353_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=uHejBRGjvJ8:ezeLm3D-WHs:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn81@2020_1/2020/09/06/03-00-00-134_141433d9b73169b9.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/uHejBRGjvJ8":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn25@2020_2/2020/09/06/02-59-58-720_582050d21facdefd.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1599361164662},{"createdTime":"2020-09-06 10:59:24","updatedTime":"2020-09-06 10:59:24","title":"Trump said retired Gen. John Kelly 'got eaten alive' as White House chief of staff after reports claimed he made rude remarks at the grave of Kelly's son","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-general-john-kelly-eaten-alive-arlington-cemetery-2020-9","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f4cd34d60bf1f00280796ba?format=jpeg\" alt=\"donald trump john kelly\" height=\"1348\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Donald Trump with his former chief of staff, John Kelly.\n<p class=\"copyright\">SAUL LOEB/AFP via Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>President Donald Trump said his former chief of staff, retired Gen. John Kelly, was \"eaten alive\" and \"unable to handle the pressure of this job\" at a Friday press briefing.</li>\n<li>The president's comments follow a&#160;<a href=\"https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2020/09/trump-americans-who-died-at-war-are-losers-and-suckers/615997/\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"044559009dcd518887c4107807c52b19\">Thursday</a><a href=\"https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2020/09/trump-americans-who-died-at-war-are-losers-and-suckers/615997/\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"044559009dcd518887c4107807c52b19\"> report from The Atlantic</a> that Trump skipped a visit to a World War I veteran cemetery in 2018, telling senior staff: \"Why should I go to that cemetery? It's filled with losers.\"</li>\n<li>The report also said Trump made uncomfortable remarks to Kelly during a 2017 visit to Arlington National Cemetery.</li>\n<li>As the two stood beside Kelly's son's grave, Trump <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-questioned-kellys-sons-sacrifice-on-memorial-day-grave-visit-2020-9\">reportedly turned to Kelly</a> and said: \"I don't get it. What was in it for them?\"</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>President Donald Trump's 2018 decision not to visit a World War I veteran cemetery in Paris has reignited tension with his former chief of staff John Kelly. At a Friday press briefing, Trump reiterated old claims that Kelly was ill-equipped for his post.</p><p>\"He was with me, didn't do a good job, had no temperament, and ultimately he was petered out,\" Trump said. \"He got eaten alive. He was unable to handle the pressure of this job.\"</p><p>The president's comments follow a&#160;<a href=\"https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2020/09/trump-americans-who-died-at-war-are-losers-and-suckers/615997/\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"044559009dcd518887c4107807c52b19\">Thursday</a><a href=\"https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2020/09/trump-americans-who-died-at-war-are-losers-and-suckers/615997/\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"044559009dcd518887c4107807c52b19\"> report from The Atlantic</a> that Trump didn't find it important to visit the Aisne-Marne American Cemetery two years ago, telling senior staff at the time: \"Why should I go to that cemetery? It's filled with losers.\"</p><p>Kelly, a retired four-star Marine Corps general and Trump's longest-serving chief of staff, attended the event along with other world leaders. When Trump received public backlash for his absence, he <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-blamed-john-kelly-wwi-memorial-trip-france-2020-1\">privately blamed Kelly</a> for telling him he could defer the invitation due to inclement weather, Washington Post reporters Philip Rucker and Carol Leonnig wrote in their book, \"<a href=\"https://www.amazon.com/Very-Stable-Genius-Testing-America-ebook/dp/B07WQQRMGP?tag=bisafetynet2-20\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"b0cae8b792d516edc0d3873a29e41e23\">A Very Stable Genius</a>.\"</p><p>\"I could've f------ gone!\" Trump reportedly told aides. \"I was willing to go! They're killing me for it!\"&#160;</p><p>Trump also <a href=\"https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2020/09/trump-americans-who-died-at-war-are-losers-and-suckers/615997/\">made insensitive remarks</a> to Kelly during a visit to Arlington National Cemetery on Memorial Day 2017, the Atlantic reported Thursday.</p><p>On the trip, the two stopped at the grave of Kelly's son, 1st Lt. Robert Kelly, who was killed in Afghanistan in 2010. While they were standing there, Trump <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-questioned-kellys-sons-sacrifice-on-memorial-day-grave-visit-2020-9\">reportedly turned to Kelly</a> and said: \"I don't get it. What was in it for them?\"</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f517031e6ff30001d4e7039?format=jpeg\" alt=\"President Donald Trump speaks with retired Marine Corps Gen. John Kelly at Arlington National Cemetery\" height=\"2333\" width=\"3500\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>President Donald Trump speaks with retired Marine Corps Gen. John Kelly at Arlington National Cemetery.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Photo by Aaron P. Bernstein/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>Sources <a href=\"https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2020/09/trump-americans-who-died-at-war-are-losers-and-suckers/615997/\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"044559009dcd518887c4107807c52b19\">close to Kelly told&#160;The Atlantic</a> he initially thought the president was commenting on the selflessness of America's service members. Later, they added, the retired general came to believe that Trump didn't understand the idea of personal sacrifice.</p><p>Kelly has stayed mum on the incidents at both cemeteries after declining to comment to The Atlantic.&#160;The White House <a href=\"https://twitter.com/JuddPDeere45/status/1301644886115057665\">called the reports</a> \"just another anonymously sourced story meant to tear down a Commander-in-Chief.\"</p><p>But there have been prior reports of tension between Trump and the retired general.</p><p>Kelly previously <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/john-kelly-illegal-trump-interactions-french-kissing-chainsaw-book-2020-8\">compared having to refuse Trump's requests</a> to \"French kissing a chainsaw,\" according to New York Times correspondent Michael Schmidt's book, \"Donald Trump v. The United States: Inside the Struggle to Stop a President.\"</p><p>\"Kelly has told others that Trump wanted to behave like an authoritarian and repeatedly had to be restrained and told what he could and could not legally do,\" Schmidt wrote.</p><p>In 2019, the Wall Street Journal <a href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/embarrassing-leaks-led-to-clampdown-on-trumps-phone-records-11569710889\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"b816bd16b55d5fd12efda7f9c5c3120a\">reported</a>&#160;that Kelly <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/john-kelly-trump-calls-world-leaders-sensitive-information-2019-9\">used to mute the phone line</a> during Trump's calls with world leaders to tell him to stop discussing sensitive information. Then in February, Kelly <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2020/feb/13/ex-white-house-chief-staff-john-kelly-speaks-out-against-trump\">defended a key&#160;witness</a>&#160;in Trump's impeachment inquiry, retired Lt. Col.&#160;Alexander Vindman.</p><p>Shortly after, Trump <a href=\"https://twitter.com/realDonaldTrump/status/1227986935240691712\">blasted Kelly on Twitter</a>.</p><p>\"When I terminated John Kelly, which I couldn't do fast enough, he knew full well that he was way over his head. Being Chief of Staff just wasn't for him,\" Trump wrote. \"He came in with a bang, went out with a whimper, but like so many X's, he misses the action [and] just can't keep his mouth shut.\"</p><div
