href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=JFQxQzPvWr0:soK7YAWv1Mc:V_sGLiPBpWU\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=JFQxQzPvWr0:soK7YAWv1Mc:V_sGLiPBpWU\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=JFQxQzPvWr0:soK7YAWv1Mc:qj6IDK7rITs\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=JFQxQzPvWr0:soK7YAWv1Mc:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=JFQxQzPvWr0:soK7YAWv1Mc:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\"></img></a>\n</div><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/JFQxQzPvWr0\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sat, 05 Sep 2020 16:57:15 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5f4cd3537ffa48002894d16e?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"e46c1a582be3cbf39f69385c8b4da852","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn23@2020_5/2020/09/06/02-59-51-007_e9deef36a8b23709.webp","destWidth":1796,"destHeight":1347,"sourceBytes":98302,"destBytes":98302,"author":"insider@insider.com (Aria Bendix)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f4cd34d60bf1f00280796ba?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn20@2020_4/2020/09/06/02-59-53-779_fb3f1a02d8ed6ea5.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f517031e6ff30001d4e7039?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn4@2020_3/2020/09/06/02-59-49-047_da4787dc85d8442d.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn78@2020_1/2020/09/06/02-59-58-308_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=JFQxQzPvWr0:soK7YAWv1Mc:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn22@2020_5/2020/09/06/02-59-59-716_9d38f8eee7af7399.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=JFQxQzPvWr0:soK7YAWv1Mc:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn10@2020_3/2020/09/06/02-59-56-689_050f5d26c500ce85.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn60@2020_6/2020/09/06/02-59-52-353_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=JFQxQzPvWr0:soK7YAWv1Mc:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn22@2020_4/2020/09/06/02-59-55-726_e24e2902bcbed7bf.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/JFQxQzPvWr0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn100@2020_6/2020/09/06/02-59-46-234_0b529685d36de809.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1599361164605},{"createdTime":"2020-09-06 10:59:24","updatedTime":"2020-09-06 10:59:24","title":"The director of 'Friday Night Lights' made a documentary about how Ford and the UAW pulled together to fight the coronavirus — here's the story of how it happened","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/peter-berg-made-documentary-ford-uaw-fighting-covid-19-2020-9","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f52a4e4e6ff30001d4e73f4?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Ford Ventilators\" height=\"1333\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Ford has produced 50,000 ventilators.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Ford</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Director Peter Berg worked with Ford and the UAW to make <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?time_continue=4&v=lYHgV2u1T2Y&feature=emb_logoemb_logo\">\"On the Line\"</a>, a short documentary about the company and the union's joint effort to <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/ford-3m-ge-produce-respirators-ventilators-coronavirus-2020-3\">produce millions of face masks and other protective gear, as well as 50,000 ventilators,</a> as the coronavirus pandemic was raging in early 2020 and <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/gm-ford-fiat-chrysler-shutting-us-factories-coronavirus-2020-3\">Ford's factories were shut down</a>.</li>\n<li>Within weeks, Ford and the UAW devised a plan to bring volunteer workers to facilities to produce the urgently needed medical technology, using existing Ford materials and manufacturing expertise.</li>\n<li>Rory Gamble, the UAW's president, had been on the job only a few months when the pandemic crisis hit.</li>\n<li>\"He flawlessly rose to the occasion,\" Hackett said of Gamble's determination to keep the UAW membership safe while also fighting the virus.</li>\n<li>\"It's an example of the very best within us, as a country, as workers, and for Ford as a company,\" Berg said.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>&#160;</p><p>When the coronavirus pandemic hit the US hard in March, Ford and every other major global automaker had to shut down production, taking the unprecedented step of idling assembly lines nationwide to protect workers from COVID-19.</p><p>At the same time, as the virus ripped through American society, sickening thousands, hospitals faced shortages of protective gowns, gloves, face masks and shields, respirators, and — for critically ill patients — ventilators.</p><p>Ford had been making pickup trucks and SUVs at its factories, so the company dusted off its World War II playbook and shifted gears. But this time around, instead of tanks and warplanes, the Blue Oval and its workers made medical equipment.</p><p>About five months and 50,000 ventilators later, the effort has been chronicled in a short film, <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?time_continue=4&v=lYHgV2u1T2Y&feature=emb_logoemb_logo\">\"On the Line\"</a><em>,</em> directed by Hollywood veteran Peter Berg, known for films such as \"Friday Night Lights\" and \"Hancock<em>.\" </em>The eight-and-a-half-minute documentary debuted at Aspen Ideas Now (an extension of the Aspen Ideas Festival) on Friday.</p><h2>The new UAW president steps up to the challenge</h2><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5e738a2dc485406e2f50fd52?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Rory Gamble\" height=\"1307\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>UAW President Rory Gamble has to deal with a pandemic and a leadership crisis at the union.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Reuters</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>Ford CEO Jim Hackett and GE Healthcare executives oversaw what the companies called \"Project Apollo,\" a name inspired by the movie \"Apollo 13<em>,\" </em>which celebrated American engineering ingenuity under the extreme stress of a failed 1970 Moon mission when NASA fought to return three astronauts to Earth after an accident damaged their spacecraft.</p><p>An unsung hero of the story was Rory Gamble, the new president of United Auto Workers, who had been on the job less than six months when the pandemic struck, and was dealing with his members' concerns about workplace safety while simultaneously managing the fallout of a leadership crisis at the union. (His predecessor, Gary Jones, had stepped down amid a scandal and later pled guilty to embezzlement charges.)</p><p>The UAW and the Detroit Big Three — Ford, General Motors, and Fiat Chrysler Automobiles — are often thought to be adversaries. And the differences between labor and management had exploded in late 2019, when the almost 50,000 UAW members walked out on GM, striking for more than a month.</p><p>But the Ford effort (as well as a similar undertaking at GM) showed that Detroit's leaders, on both sides, could put aside their differences to \"take care of each other,\" as Gamble said in an interview with Business Insider.</p><p>\"He flawlessly rose to the occasion,\" Hackett said of Gamble's determination. \"He saved a bunch of people's lives and deserves a ton of credit.\"</p><p>Gamble had been instrumental in pushing for factory shutdowns in mid-March, advocating for his membership. In the span of a week, the Detroit automakers and the UAW went from talking about how they would deal with the coronavirus crisis to idling plants in the US.</p><p>Hackett acknowledged that the pressure was a good thing. He estimated that Ford could have lost nearly 3,000 workers to the disease if the company hadn't swiftly pulled the plug.</p><p>\"We got them out of the exposure path,\" Hackett said, calling the undertaking a phenomenal effort by Ford and the UAW. His praise for Gamble was unflinching. \"I'd love to sit across the table from him,\" Hackett said.</p><p>\"We set a common goal and left our differences behind,\" Gamble said, adding that the UAW and Ford approached the pandemic from a \"humanitarian perspective.\"</p><p>\"The entire world is fighting this virus,\" he noted. \"It's a threat to all life, so all life should be fighting it collectively.\"</p><h2>Enter the Hollywood storyteller</h2><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5e94a02a0b3c9b68e05a6084?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Ford Coronavirus tech\" height=\"2194\" width=\"2925\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Ford rapidly shifted from making pickups to producing medical equipment.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Ford</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>The story captured the attention of Berg, who had already been working on a project with Ford and Hackett about how the 117-year-old company was reinventing itself for the 21st century. So he set about following Ford workers and executives as they repurposed numerous automotive components to make millions of masks and face shields and tens of thousands of ventilators, at a pace Hackett called \"mind-boggling.\" (UAW members volunteered to work at facilities that had to be revamped to make the medical technology.)</p><p>\"There wasn't a lot of shaping that had to be done,\" Berg said of the narrative, which features longtime Ford employees talking about their commitment to the company and its history, but also to the virus-beleaguered public and to front-line medical personnel and emergency workers.&#160;</p><p>\"It's an example of the very best within us, as a country, as workers, and for Ford as a company.\"</p><p>Berg agreed that he had filmed a distinctly American story.&#160;</p><p>\"We're desperate for these stories today.&#160;Cynicism is at levels I haven't seen in my lifetime. But this is an undeniable example of American ingenuity. I had an authentic, no-BS opportunity to document that.\"</p><iframe width=\"800\" height=\"400\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/lYHgV2u1T2Y\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen></iframe><p>&#160;</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/peter-berg-made-documentary-ford-uaw-fighting-covid-19-2020-9'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=1VzsPML4vUs:jgq-HHifgXo:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=1VzsPML4vUs:jgq-HHifgXo:F7zBnMyn0Lo\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=1VzsPML4vUs:jgq-HHifgXo:F7zBnMyn0Lo\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=1VzsPML4vUs:jgq-HHifgXo:V_sGLiPBpWU\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=1VzsPML4vUs:jgq-HHifgXo:V_sGLiPBpWU\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=1VzsPML4vUs:jgq-HHifgXo:qj6IDK7rITs\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=1VzsPML4vUs:jgq-HHifgXo:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=1VzsPML4vUs:jgq-HHifgXo:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\"></img></a>\n</div><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/1VzsPML4vUs\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sat, 05 Sep 2020 12:53:00 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5f52a4ec7ed0ee001e25da97?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"7f22e3282b194a79fa39337b431ab865","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn32@2020_6/2020/09/06/02-59-44-511_d8bd228e263b0633.webp","destWidth":1778,"destHeight":1333,"sourceBytes":159800,"destBytes":159800,"author":"insider@insider.com (Matthew DeBord)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f52a4e4e6ff30001d4e73f4?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn90@2020_1/2020/09/06/02-59-56-614_6cd6d232bdc0c4d7.webp","https://i.insider.com/5e738a2dc485406e2f50fd52?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn28@2020_5/2020/09/06/02-59-52-111_97c7398a266b3c95.webp","https://i.insider.com/5e94a02a0b3c9b68e05a6084?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn33@2020_2/2020/09/06/02-59-55-854_4dca473fc95729fa.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn78@2020_1/2020/09/06/02-59-58-308_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=1VzsPML4vUs:jgq-HHifgXo:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn44@2020_2/2020/09/06/02-59-50-243_ee346542181af711.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=1VzsPML4vUs:jgq-HHifgXo:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn12@2020_1/2020/09/06/02-59-53-896_9d27c415ff5001b1.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn60@2020_6/2020/09/06/02-59-52-353_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=1VzsPML4vUs:jgq-HHifgXo:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn80@2020_1/2020/09/06/02-59-49-690_fb94dbbc81094794.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/1VzsPML4vUs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn47@2020_3/2020/09/06/02-59-53-258_c217a57df7bcb646.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1599361164628},{"createdTime":"2020-09-06 10:59:24","updatedTime":"2020-09-06 10:59:24","title":"'I've known Donald Trump. It sounds like him': Trump's 'loser' remarks about military veterans are getting harder to deny as more evidence corroborates bombshell report","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-military-loser-sucker-veterans-atlantic-2020-9","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f539fd77ed0ee001e25db74?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Donald Trump\" height=\"3000\" width=\"6000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>President Donald Trump participates in a meeting with senior military officials in the Cabinet Room of the White House in Washington D.C., May 9, 2020.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Anna Moneymaker-Pool/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>A former senior White House official said the controversial remarks President Donald Trump was reported to have made, according to The Atlantic, resembled his speech pattern and was \"so consistent with who he is.\"</li>\n<li>\"He uses the word 'loser' as often as he can,\" the former official told Insider, adding that Trump's interest in the military was \"totally disingenuous.\"</li>\n<li>Trump was said to have called notable US military veterans, including Sen. John McCain and President George H.W. Bush a \"loser,\" according to The Atlantic's previous reporting.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>A former senior White House official acknowledged that the controversial remarks President Donald Trump was reported to have said about the military resembled his speech pattern and was \"so consistent with who he is.\"</p><p>\"I'm not surprised hearing about the comments,\" a former senior White House official told Insider. \"I've known Donald Trump. It sounds like him. They're consistent with things that he's said.\"</p><p>\"He uses the word 'loser' as often as he can,\" they added.</p><p>The comment comes as Trump was widely panned by critics following a report from <a href=\"https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2020/09/trump-americans-who-died-at-war-are-losers-and-suckers/615997/\">The Atlantic</a> that was published Thursday evening. According to several unnamed sources in the report, Trump had made multiple disparaging remarks about military veterans and appeared callous to the sacrifices made by service members.</p><p>During a trip to Paris in 2018, Trump reportedly resisted the idea of visiting a military cemetery to commemorate the 100th anniversary of World War I, saying that the revered site was \"filled with losers\" and \"suckers\" who died.</p><p>The Atlantic report, which was written by the publication's editor in chief Jeffrey Goldberg, also noted that Trump made critical remarks about former Republican leaders who served in the military. Three sources told Goldberg that Trump was furious at Sen. John McCain of Arizona, even after his death from an aggressive form of brain cancer in 2018. McCain and Trump have long been at odds with each other, despite being in the same political party.</p><p>\"We're not going to support that loser's funeral,\" Trump said after McCain's death, according to The Atlantic. The US senator's funeral included a widely-attended proceeding at the Capitol Rotunda from both Democratic and Republican icons, including Presidents George W. Bush and Barack Obama. Trump was not invited to the proceedings.</p><p>\"What the f--- are we doing that for? Guy was a f---ing loser,\" Trump reportedly said after US flags were lowered to half-staff out of respect for McCain.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5ee4f71a5af6cc155355cca2?format=jpeg\" alt=\"President Donald Trump delivers commencement address at the 2020 United States Military Academy Graduation Ceremony at West Point, New York\" height=\"2623\" width=\"5246\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>President Donald Trump delivers a commencement address at the 2020 United States Military Academy Graduation Ceremony at West Point, New York.\n<p class=\"copyright\">REUTERS/Mike Segar</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>Trump also described President George H.W. Bush as a \"loser,\" because the former president's aircraft crashed during World War II, the Atlantic reported. Both McCain and Bush served in the US Navy as pilots and were shot down by enemy forces.</p><p>Following the publication of The Atlantic's story, other news organizations have confirmed the alleged remarks with their own reporting. <a href=\"https://www.foxnews.com/politics/trump-didnt-cancel-visit-to-american-military-cemetery-in-france-over-disdain-for-slain-veterans-sources-say\">Fox News</a> also confirmed in its report portions of The Atlantic's original story, including a claim that Trump referred to Vietnam War draftees as \"suckers.\" Trump received five deferments — four for attending college and one for a bone spur diagnosis — and was not required to serve in the war.</p><p>Long before The Atlantic published its report, Trump's former personal attorney, Michael Cohen, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/michael-cohen-on-trump-vietnam-war-military-service-bone-sppurs-2019-2\">testified</a> that Trump made similar comments about successfully avoiding the Vietnam War: \"You think I'm stupid, I'm not going to Vietnam,\" Cohen recalled Trump as saying, during a congressional testimony in 2019.</p><p>A book written by Philip Rucker and Carol Leonnig, two Pulitzer Prize-winning reporters from the Washington Post, also references Trump berating his senior military leaders and describing them as \"dopes and babies\" — in addition to \"losers.\"</p><p>\"You're all losers,\" Trump said at a meeting with his national security team in 2017, according to the book \"A Very Stable Genius.\" \"You don't know how to win anymore.\"</p><p>Trump, in addition to his advisers, publicly denied the claims made in The Atlantic's report. White House press secretary Kayleigh McEnany on Friday characterized The Atlantic as \"liberal activists,\" and provided emails of weather reports that threw cold water on claims that Trump did not want to visit the Paris cemetery because of fears that his hair \"would become disheveled\" from the inclement weather.</p><p>In a late-night tweet on Thursday, Trump also acknowledged he \"was never a big fan\" of McCain and that he \"disagreed with him on many things.\" Still, he claimed, he \"never called John a loser.\"</p><p>But the description of McCain as a \"loser\" echoes much of what Trump has said <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-falsely-claimed-didnt-call-john-mccain-loser-2020-9\">in the past</a>: \"I like people who weren't captured,\" Trump said of McCain's time as a prisoner of war, during his presidential campaign in 2015. Trump added at the time, \"I don't like losers.\"</p><p>Following the event, Trump also tweeted a link to a political blog that quoted his remarks. The president's tweet is still viewable on his personal Twitter account.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f53a1aee6ff30001d4e74c8?format=jpeg\" alt=\"donald trump flag\" height=\"1534\" width=\"3069\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>President Donald Trump kisses the US flag at the annual Conservative Political Action Conference (CPAC) at Gaylord National Resort &#38; Convention Center February 29, 2020 in National Harbor, Maryland.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Tasos Katopodis/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>The callous tone of Trump's comments about America's veterans is on par with the president, the former senior White House official told Insider. The official recalled that immediately after Trump called the family members of US Army Sgt. LaDavid Johnson, a soldier who was killed during a militant ambush in Niger in 2017, the president's behavior was as though \"it was another day at the office for him.\"</p><p>That same phone call was criticized by Johnson's widow, who said at the time that it had \"made me cry even worse.\"</p><p>\"The president said that 'he knew what he signed up for but it hurts anyways,'\" Myeshia Johnson said during an interview with ABC. \"It made me cry because I was very angry at the tone of his voice and how he said it. He couldn't remember my husband's name.\"</p><p>One current Trump administration official told <a href=\"https://www.thedailybeast.com/trumps-defenders-he-doesnt-hate-the-troops-he-just-sounds-like-an-asshole\">The Daily Beast</a> that Trump's seemingly indifference towards the military was not intentional.</p><p>\"The president means no disrespect to our troops; it's just that the way he speaks, he can sound like an asshole sometimes,\" the official said to The Daily Beast, adding, \"it's his style.\"</p><p>The former White House official disputed that assertion to Insider; however, and called it \"totally disingenuous.\"</p><p>\"When I saw Donald Trump hugging the flag, it reminded me of Donald Trump the performer; the showman pandering,\" the former senior official told Insider, referring to the multiple occasions in which Trump physically embraced the US flag. \"Not Donald Trump, the commander-in-chief; the person who actually is responsible for what happens with our military.\"</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a Choi)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f539fd77ed0ee001e25db74?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn79@2020_6/2020/09/06/02-59-52-610_f9fed7a0d04d1d8a.webp","https://i.insider.com/5ee4f71a5af6cc155355cca2?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn96@2020_6/2020/09/06/02-59-46-861_49540efcd826d8e5.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f53a1aee6ff30001d4e74c8?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn74@2020_1/2020/09/06/02-59-57-536_33a05b2439a4a745.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn78@2020_1/2020/09/06/02-59-58-308_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=tA5YNvQyxZ4:zCXyzgCpWMU:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn8@2020_6/2020/09/06/02-59-51-967_745c623bae978a84.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=tA5YNvQyxZ4:zCXyzgCpWMU:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn14@2020_2/2020/09/06/02-59-59-912_e846de77e0059c7d.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn60@2020_6/2020/09/06/02-59-52-353_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=tA5YNvQyxZ4:zCXyzgCpWMU:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn90@2020_3/2020/09/06/02-59-55-532_db6faf8a0b0f2ceb.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/tA5YNvQyxZ4":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn89@2020_1/2020/09/06/03-00-01-080_ff4d2b5d6b148442.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1599361164622},{"createdTime":"2020-09-06 10:59:24","updatedTime":"2020-09-06 10:59:24","title":"The 10 US states with the lowest salaries for public school teachers","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/states-with-lowest-teacher-salaries-public-school-teachers-2020-9","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5b15aab07708e9283f31de76?format=jpeg\" alt=\"teacher\" height=\"1580\" width=\"2107\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Grant Halverson/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Salaries for New York and California teachers in public elementary and secondary schools are two of the highest salaries for this occupation in the US, according to 2018-2019 data from the <a href=\"https://nces.ed.gov/programs/digest/d19/tables/dt19_211.60.asp?current=yes\">National Center for Education Statistics</a>.</li>\n<li>But there are quite a few states that make low pay relative to other states and DC.&#160;</li>\n<li>In the 2018-2019 school year, teachers in Mississippi made an average of $45,574, the lowest average annual salary for public school teachers nationwide.</li>\n<li><strong><a href=\"http://newsletter.businessinsider.com/join/4np/insider-parenting\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-saferedirecturl=\"https://www.google.com/url?q=http://newsletter.businessinsider.com/join/4np/insider-parenting&source=gmail&ust=1598988574381000&usg=AFQjCNGbZHA1DLcL-ifRbokPTteEwu0n8gkPTteEwu0n8g\" data-analytics-module=\"summary_bullets\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"0\" data-uri=\"8e5d67ce0292b94da6a30f997f070ebc\">Sign up for our new parenting newsletter Insider Parenting here.</a></strong></li>\n</ul><p>&#160;</p><p>The average annual salaries of public school teachers differs from state to state, ranging from a little over $45,500 in Mississippi to nearly $86,000 in New York.&#160;</p><p>After recently <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/teacher-salary-in-every-state-2018-4\">ranking</a> the teacher salaries in every state and DC and with the school year beginning around the country, Business Insider decided to look at what are the 10 states where public school teachers make the lowest. To do this, we used 2018-2019 average salaries of teachers in public elementary and secondary schools from the <a href=\"https://nces.ed.gov/programs/digest/d19/tables/dt19_211.60.asp?current=yes\">National Center for Education Statistics</a>. This is the most recent academic year with available data.&#160;</p><p>The US average salary for 2018-2019 was $61,730, same as the previous year. At the state level, 36 states have an annual average less than this US figure. Mississippi had an average salary of $45,574 in 2018-2019, the lowest among the states and DC. When adjusting for inflation, this state's salary decreased by 4.4% from the average salary of $47,659 in 1990-200 and decreased by 14.6% from the average salary of $53,338 in 2009-2010.</p><p>Florida was another state where teachers do not make as much compared to the salaries of other states and DC. The current average annual salary in this state is low compared to figures from the past two decades. The average annual salary in Florida declined by 11.9% from the inflation-adjusted salary of 1999-2000 and 11.3% from the inflation-adjusted salary of 2009-2010 to $48,395 average salary in 2018-2019.&#160;</p><p>Some schools in Florida have already reopened for in-person schooling. The <a href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/education/2020/09/02/photo-shows-students-jammed-together-florida-high-school/\">Washington Post</a> recently shared a tweeted photo of crowded students in a Florida high school.</p><p>Utah is another state with a low average teacher salary relative to other states and DC. School plans vary throughout the state with some using a hybrid model of in-person and virtual learning. The <a href=\"https://www.sltrib.com/news/education/2020/08/09/heres-breakdown-how-some/\">Salt Lake Tribune</a> compiled a list of the varying plans from some of the state's largest districts.</p><p>The following are the 10 states where public school teachers earned the lowest average salaries during the 2018-2019 academic year. We also included total amount spent per pupil during the 2018 fiscal year in each state using public school data from the <a href=\"https://www.census.gov/programs-surveys/school-finances/data/tables.html\">US Census Bureau</a>.&#160;</p>\n<div id=\"slideshow\">\n\t10. South Carolina\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f53e1bb7ed0ee001e25dbb1?format=jpeg\" alt=\"south carolina teacher\" height=\"1196\" width=\"1595\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Mary Ann Chastain/AP</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p><strong>2018-2019 average teacher salary:</strong> $50,395</p><p><strong>Change in adjusted salary since 1999-2000:</strong> -6.6%</p><p><strong>State spending per student:</strong> $10,856</p>\n\t9. Utah\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f53e0f37ed0ee001e25dbb0?format=jpeg\" alt=\"utah teacher\" height=\"1279\" width=\"1705\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Rick Bowmer/AP</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p><strong>2018-2019 average teacher salary:</strong> $50,342</p><p><strong>Change in inflation-adjusted salary since 1999-2000:</strong> -3.7%</p><p><strong>State spending per student:</strong> $7,628</p>\n\t8. Missouri\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f53e0877ed0ee001e25dbae?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Missouri teacher\" height=\"1293\" width=\"1723\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Tammy Ljungblad/Kansas City Star/Tribune News Service/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p><strong>2018-2019 average teacher salary:</strong> $50,064</p><p><strong>Change in inflation-adjusted salary since 1999-2000:</strong> -6.1%</p><p><strong>State spending per student:</strong> $10,810</p>\n\t7. Arizona\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f53e026e6ff30001d4e7501?format=jpeg\" alt=\"arizona teacher\" height=\"1333\" width=\"1778\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Mike Moore / Stringer/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p><strong>2018-2019 average teacher salary:</strong> $49,892</p><p><strong>Change in inflation-adjusted salary since 1999-2000:</strong> -9.6%</p><p><strong>State spending per student:</strong> $8,239</p>\n\t6. Kansas\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5ac6612d7708e91fd64423c8?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Kansas teacher reading\" height=\"904\" width=\"1205\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Charlie Riedel/AP</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p><strong>2018-2019 average teacher salary:</strong> $49,800</p><p><strong>Change in inflation-adjusted salary since 1999-2000:</strong> -4.8%</p><p><strong>State spending per student:</strong> $11,653</p>\n\t5. South Dakota\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5ac6612b7708e91fd64423bf?format=jpeg\" alt=\"South Dakota teacher pay\" height=\"1133\" width=\"1511\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Dirk Lammers/AP</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p><strong>2018-2019 average teacher salary:</strong> $48,786</p><p><strong>Change in inflation-adjusted salary since 1999-2000:</strong> 12.2%</p><p><strong>State spending per student:</strong> $10,073</p>\n\t4. Florida\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f53de34e6ff30001d4e7500?format=jpeg\" alt=\"return to florida school orlando florida\" height=\"1285\" width=\"1713\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Paul Hennessy/NurPhoto/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p><strong>2018-2019&#160;average teacher salary:</strong>&#160;$48,395</p><p><strong>Change in inflation-adjusted salary since 1999-2000:</strong> -11.9%</p><p><strong>State spending per student:</strong> $9,346</p>\n\t3. New Mexico\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f53dd917ed0ee001e25dbaa?format=jpeg\" alt=\"new mexico school budget rally\" height=\"1153\" width=\"1538\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Morgan Lee/AP</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p><strong>2018-2019 average teacher salary:</strong>&#160;$47,826</p><p><strong>Change in inflation-adjusted salary since 1999-2000:</strong> -1.8%</p><p><strong>State spending per student:</strong> $9,582</p>\n\t2. West Virginia\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5d8b605b21214c0f0d140eaa?format=jpeg\" alt=\"west virginia teacher\" height=\"2000\" width=\"2667\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Spencer Platt/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p><strong>2018-2019 average teacher salary:</strong> $47,681</p><p><strong>Change in inflation-adjusted salary since 1999-2000:</strong> -9.0%</p><p><strong>State spending per student:</strong> $11,334</p>\n\t1. Mississippi\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5ac6612b7708e91fd64423c0?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Mississippi teacher pre k\" height=\"1067\" width=\"1422\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Rogelio V. Solis/AP</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p><strong>2018-2019 average teacher salary:&#160;</strong>$45,574</p><p><strong>Change in inflation-adjusted salary since 1999-2000:</strong> -4.4%</p><p><strong>State spending per student:</strong> $8,935</p>\n</div><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/states-with-lowest-teacher-salaries-public-school-teachers-2020-9'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a 2020 21:13:40 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5b15aab07708e9283f31de76?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"602e94bd1b49af8cb068b4aa9873c209","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn13@2020_6/2020/09/06/02-59-24-937_c6433d8edd8bbc4c.webp","destWidth":2107,"destHeight":1580,"sourceBytes":160484,"destBytes":160484,"author":"insider@insider.com (Madison Hoff)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5b15aab07708e9283f31de76?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn13@2020_6/2020/09/06/02-59-24-937_c6433d8edd8bbc4c.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f53e1bb7ed0ee001e25dbb1?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn52@2020_6/2020/09/06/02-59-46-421_2767f44567af800a.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f53e0f37ed0ee001e25dbb0?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn39@2020_2/2020/09/06/02-59-49-363_b9da5f9bd4d9148c.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f53e0877ed0ee001e25dbae?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn52@2020_6/2020/09/06/02-59-49-363_11ca1a84cc31eb38.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f53e026e6ff30001d4e7501?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn83@2020_6/2020/09/06/02-59-51-788_7881befb4d3511e7.webp","https://i.insider.com/5ac6612d7708e91fd64423c8?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn91@2020_6/2020/09/06/02-59-48-082_0727a9e7e2dfeb8e.webp","https://i.insider.com/5ac6612b7708e91fd64423bf?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn74@2020_3/2020/09/06/02-59-44-353_f1d6d6a9ed899b20.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f53de34e6ff30001d4e7500?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn27@2020_4/2020/09/06/02-59-48-467_92d92b7730e96f2d.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f53dd917ed0ee001e25dbaa?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn40@2020_5/2020/09/06/02-59-52-294_5725e31c52d1a957.webp","https://i.insider.com/5d8b605b21214c0f0d140eaa?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn49@2020_2/2020/09/06/02-59-59-041_85d1a8312c619383.webp","https://i.insider.com/5ac6612b7708e91fd64423c0?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn52@2020_5/2020/09/06/02-59-47-670_33a3b53de80eea4e.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn78@2020_1/2020/09/06/02-59-58-308_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=-qUpdImBUuM:X6iPUJxC6Nw:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn71@2020_5/2020/09/06/02-59-47-750_da3533a315f2a13d.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=-qUpdImBUuM:X6iPUJxC6Nw:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn98@2020_5/2020/09/06/02-59-44-254_cbfcd50c8465493e.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn60@2020_6/2020/09/06/02-59-52-353_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=-qUpdImBUuM:X6iPUJxC6Nw:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn5@2020_4/2020/09/06/02-59-58-742_58d4f98cfb09c4ae.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/-qUpdImBUuM":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn86@2020_2/2020/09/06/02-59-54-470_347050276688d7ad.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1599361164623},{"createdTime":"2020-09-06 10:59:24","updatedTime":"2020-09-06 10:59:24","title":"How Ben & Jerry's makes nearly 1 million pints of ice cream a day","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/ben-and-jerrys-makes-1-million-pints-ice-cream-day-2020-9","description":"<div style=\"position:relative; overflow:hidden; padding-bottom:56.25%\">\n<iframe src=\"https://cdn.jwplayer.com/players/p5G70v1c-jZbcmOYf.html\"\nwidth=\"100%\" height=\"100%\" frameborder=\"0\" scrolling=\"auto\" title=\"How Ben & Jerry's makes nearly 1 million pints of ice cream a day\"\nstyle=\"position:absolute;\" allowfullscreen></iframe>\n</div><ul class=\"summary-list\"><li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/meet-ben-cohen-jerry-greenfield-founders-of-ben-and-jerrys-2020-6\">Ben &#38; Jerry's</a> is the best-selling single ice cream brand in the world.</li><li>It's gained a cult following thanks to classic flavors like Half Baked and Cherry Garcia and a mission to use ice cream to <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/ben-and-jerrys-celebrated-for-campaign-against-white-supremacy-2020-6\">fight for equality</a>.</li><li>Business Insider visits the plant in St. Albans, Vermont, to see how Ben &#38; Jerry's pumps out nearly 1 million pints a day.</li><li>It takes hundreds of workers, special machinery, and a 24/7 operation to package up these pints.</li><li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li></ul><p>&#160;</p><p>Following is a transcription of the video:&#160;</p><p>Narrator: Scooped up across 38 countries and up to 75 flavors, Ben &#38; Jerry's is no pint-sized operation. Its two Vermont factories run 24/7, operated by hundreds of flavor makers. Together, they pump out nearly a million pints a day, from classic flavors like Cherry Garcia and Half Baked to flavors on a mission for criminal-justice reform and refugee rights. And all those flavors have to be delicious.</p><p>Sarah Fidler: Our minimum run size, once we get a flavor to the factory, is 80,000 pints. So not only do we have to love it, but 80,000 fans have to love it too.</p><p>Narrator: We visited the St. Albans plant in northern Vermont to see how these famous pints flip their way to our freezers. Ben Cohen and Jerry Greenfield started Ben &#38; Jerry's Homemade Ice Cream in 1978. From a renovated gas station in Burlington, Vermont, they launched a brand based on sustainable ice cream making and advocating for causes they believed in, and it worked. Today, Ben &#38; Jerry's is the best-selling single brand ice cream label in the US. To pump out its iconic flavors, first it starts with ingredients.</p><p>Ben &#38; Jerry's partners with 250 farms globally to source everything from vanilla bean to milk. Milk comes from the St. Albans Cooperative Creamery, just a mile and a half from the factory. Once the milk's at the plant, it heads to one of these massive, 6,000-gallon silos.</p><p>But before it can be made into ice cream, everyone involved has to suit up, including us. Gowns, hairnets, caps, and boots.</p><p>To make the ice cream base, the milk heads to the blend tank. Cream, milk, and lots of sugar are churned together. The factory goes through 6,700 gallons of cream every single day. Every ice cream flavor starts with either a sweet cream base or a chocolate base.</p><p>Next, the Mix Master will pour in eggs, stabilizers, and cocoa powder if it's a chocolate base. Then it's piped into the pasteurizer. You can't see it happening, but hot steel plates are heating up the mix to kill any harmful bacteria. The newly pasteurized milk is stored in a tank for four to eight hours, so the ingredients can really get to know each other.</p><p>After making the two bases, they'll head to one of the 20 flavor vats to get a flavor boost.</p><p>Fidler: We're always coming up with new flavors, hundreds of flavors a year, and we usually narrow it down to about three or four. We really love to bring our social mission values into our naming process. For example, Empower Mint to talk about voting rights.</p><p>Narrator: Before Ben &#38; Jerry's famous chunks can be added, the mix has to get to below-freezing temperatures. It's pumped through this giant freezing barrel, and when it gets to the front, it's finally ice cream. Along the way, it's quality tested, meaning lucky factory floor workers get to taste the ice creams.</p><p>Then it goes into the first of two freezer visits. When it comes out, it's 22 degrees and somewhere between the consistency of a milkshake and soft serve.</p><p>Now for the best part, the chunks. Founder Ben actually didn't have a great sense of smell, which meant he couldn't taste much either. So his big thing was texture. That's why Ben &#38; Jerry's has some of the biggest chunks in the ice cream industry. These chunks end up in flavors like Half Baked, Chubby Hubby, or the one we're making, Chocolate Therapy.</p><p>Workers dump in add-ins through the Chunk Feeder, from brownie bites and cookie dough globs to chocolate chunks, fruits, and nuts. They let us give it a try, but it's not as easy as it looks. Then it's finally time to pack those pints. Workers stack the empty containers into the automatic filler. The machine drops the pints into position and perfectly pumps in ice cream. It can fill up 270 pints a minute. The pints are pushed towards the lidder and sealed tight.</p><p>At this point, six pints every hour are pulled off the line for quality testing. Quality assurance personnel first cut pints open. They're making sure the ingredients are symmetrical and there aren't any big air bubbles.</p><p>Worker: There is a small gap, but that's what we call a functional void. If we saw large voids, it would be concerning. It's actually quite the workout, as you can tell.</p><p>Narrator: They also measure the weight and volume of pints to ensure that the right amount of ice cream makes it into each container.</p><p>Worker: So, we know the weight of the ice cream, and anything below 460 is not passable.</p><p>Narrator: Now back to the factory line. It's now time for the pints to take a second spin in the freezer. The ice cream has to get even colder, down to minus 10 degrees. The pints travel along the Spiral Hardener, a corkscrew-shaped conveyor belt inside a freezer. With the wind chill, it can get up to minus 60 degrees in there.</p><p>After three hours, the pints are finally frozen and ready to be packaged. They're flipped over and shrink wrapped into groups of eight. Together, they make a gallon. But you'll never actually see a gallon tub of Ben &#38; Jerry's ice cream, because the company never wants its ice cream going bad sitting in the back of your fridge. Once the pints are packaged, they're ready to be shipped across the globe.</p><p>Abby Narishkin: Hey, guys, my name's Abby, and I'm one of the producers on this video. My favorite flavor is definitely Ben &#38; Jerry's Milk &#38; Cookies, but let me know your favorites in the comments below and if you have any ideas for the next episode of \"Big Business.\" Don't forget to hit the subscribe button so you don't miss out.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/ben-and-jerrys-makes-1-million-pints-ice-cream-day-2020-9'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=UaUVHD6u58A:nzhnA9Ls9xc:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=UaUVHD6u58A:nzhnA9Ls9xc:F7zBnMyn0Lo\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=UaUVHD6u58A:nzhnA9Ls9xc:F7zBnMyn0Lo\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=UaUVHD6u58A:nzhnA9Ls9xc:V_sGLiPBpWU\"><img border=\"0\"></img></a>\n</div><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/UaUVHD6u58A\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sat, 05 Sep 2020 14:31:00 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5f4fc3a8e6ff30001d4e6a34?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"82b3483442f7ed4ad12d2a305c3440b9","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn54@2020_1/2020/09/06/02-59-44-278_015ae265c3fbae68.webp","destWidth":1321,"destHeight":990,"sourceBytes":86762,"destBytes":86762,"author":"insider@insider.com (Abby Narishkin,Steve Cameron,Irene Anna Kim,Ally Giannini)","articleImgCdnMap":{"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn78@2020_1/2020/09/06/02-59-58-308_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=UaUVHD6u58A:nzhnA9Ls9xc:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn34@2020_5/2020/09/06/02-59-59-992_d05c8d1fd7d842b5.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=UaUVHD6u58A:nzhnA9Ls9xc:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn92@2020_5/2020/09/06/02-59-46-002_81cef1e24658d796.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn60@2020_6/2020/09/06/02-59-52-353_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=UaUVHD6u58A:nzhnA9Ls9xc:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn44@2020_5/2020/09/06/02-59-46-589_222281f0a27fb96d.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/UaUVHD6u58A":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn14@2020_5/2020/09/06/03-00-01-296_a2faf02fc7fdfba9.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1599361164630},{"createdTime":"2020-09-06 10:59:24","updatedTime":"2020-09-06 10:59:24","title":"A top strategist says the S&P 500 has predicted the election winner 87% of the time in nearly 100 years, but 'transformational' events pose a challenge for 2020 vote","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/sp-500-predicted-us-election-winner-nearly-100-years-2020-9","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f43eb0d89aff80028ab782b?format=jpeg\" alt=\"biden trump\" height=\"386\" width=\"773\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Joe Biden, Donald Trump\n<p class=\"copyright\">Doug Mills-Pool/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul><li><strong>The S&#38;P 500 has correctly predicted the election winner 87% of the time for nearly a century, although four major events this year pose a greater challenge to the 2020 vote, a top strategist said in a BNY Mellon webcast on Thursday.&#160;</strong></li><li><strong>The incumbent party generally secures victory when stocks are higher in the 3-month period before an election than they were at the start of the year. If not, the opposition tends to win.</strong></li><li><strong>Dan Clifton, a strategist with Strategas Research, predicted the next two months would be the \"wildest\" ever in politics, and provided a 3-point framework to understand potential outcomes.</strong></li><li><strong>He said Democrats could end up hurting themselves if they choose to vote through mail-in ballots, as that dramatically increases chances of error and delays the process.</strong></li><li><strong><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</strong></li></ul><hr><p>The S&#38;P 500 index has correctly predicted the winner of the US presidential election 87% of the time over the last almost-100 years, strategist Dan Clifton of Strategas Research Partners said at a BNY Mellon webcast on Thursday.&#160;</p><p>If stocks are higher in the 3-month period before the election than they were at the beginning of the year, the incumbent party generally tends to win. If they are lower, it's the opposition that tends to take the White House.</p><p>Right now, it's tight. The S&#38;P 500 hit record highs on Wednesday, but has since dropped by nearly 7%, leaving it with a year-to-date gain of just 3.7%. The most recent data has reflected an economy that is recovering, but at an ever-slower pace.</p><p>However, four \"transformational\" events in 2020 — the COVID-19 pandemic, an ensuing recession, mass protests against racial injustice, and a US presidential election — pose a great challenge to potential outcomes this year, he said.</p><p>Going back a hundred years, \"I can only find three of these instances ever happening in one year, and that happened just three times,\" Clifton said, adding that 2020 is a rare situation, with an increased range of outcomes.&#160;</p><p><strong data-stringify-type=\"bold\"><em data-stringify-type=\"italic\">Read more:</em></strong><em data-stringify-type=\"italic\"> <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/stock-market-crash-expert-says-hypervalued-market-set-to-plunge-2020-9\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">'Never been so extreme': A renowned stock bear says today's 'hypervalued' market implies the worst market returns in history — and expects a 66% crash from today's levels</a></em></p><p>Clifton said anybody claiming they know what will happen is \"not being honest\" and it is important for investors to&#160; plan around different scenarios.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f5245547ed0ee001e25d7b1?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Screenshot 2020 09 04 at 14.46.38\" height=\"872\" width=\"1262\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Strategas Research Partners</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>In case of a contested election, confirming the results could drag on as late as mid-December — a timeframe to note ahead of the critical tax deadline of December 31.&#160;</p><p>Clifton said the next two months would be the \"wildest\" ever in politics, and provided a 3-point framework to understand potential outcomes:&#160;</p><ul><li>Understand what's happening in the economy and with COVID-19</li><li>Establish the mood in key swing states</li><li>When the COVID-19 caseload was rising, there was a referendum on Donald Trump. But since cases peaked, it has become more of a choice between Trump and Joe Biden.</li></ul><p>A traditional presidential election could take place if COVID-19 is restrained, but if it comes flaring back in September and October when children go back to school, a likely referendum on Trump would not be good for his reelection process, Clifton said.</p><p><em><strong>Read more:</strong> <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/us-investing-championship-strategy-matthew-caruso-contender-secret-to-return-2020-8\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">US Investing Championship hopeful Matthew Caruso landed a 382% return in the first half of 2020. He shares the unique twist he's putting on a classic trading strategy — and 3 stocks he's holding right now.</a></em></p><p>He referenced the <a href=\"https://news.gallup.com/poll/203198/presidential-approval-ratings-donald-trump.aspx\">Gallup Approval Rating</a> to monitor multi-day polls as it is linear-related to the percentage of votes a president receives in an election.&#160;</p><p>\"The race is tightening because the economy is getting better,\" Clifton said.</p><p>The Atlanta Fed's GDP model predicts a third-quarter GDP growth rate of 29.6%, up from a prior estimate of 28.5%.&#160;</p><p>Clifton highlighted that the fastest growth rate ever seen before an election in the US was 6.2%, which means that current predictions are about five times the average rate.&#160;</p><p>Strategas forecasts Biden's win probability at about 55%, which means Trump is at about 45% — closer race than what polls suggest.</p><p><strong data-stringify-type=\"bold\"><em data-stringify-type=\"italic\">Read more:</em></strong><em data-stringify-type=\"italic\"> <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/stock-picks-to-buy-hedge-mutual-funds-market-favorites-goldman-2020-8\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">GOLDMAN SACHS: Buy these 9 stocks that are poised to continue crushing the market as the 'shared favorites' of Wall Street's biggest investors</a></em><strong data-stringify-type=\"bold\"><em data-stringify-type=\"italic\"><br></em></strong></p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/sp-500-predicted-us-election-winner-nearly-100-years-2020-9'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=HVMVz0W9zcc:zS5L2M61aA8:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=HVMVz0W9zcc:zS5L2M61aA8:F7zBnMyn0Lo\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=HVMVz0W9zcc:zS5L2M61aA8:F7zBnMyn0Lo\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=HVMVz0W9zcc:zS5L2M61aA8:V_sGLiPBpWU\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=HVMVz0W9zcc:zS5L2M61aA8:V_sGLiPBpWU\" src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=HVMVz0W9zcc:zS5L2M61aA8:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\"></img></a>\n</div><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/HVMVz0W9zcc\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sat, 05 Sep 2020 12:30:00 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5ee427eb5af6cc52c3520256?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"4738207b718f7ff03c92004ce2a4374a","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn8@2020_6/2020/09/06/02-59-58-375_91cb78a5d8d4a4ce.webp","destWidth":571,"destHeight":428,"sourceBytes":17412,"destBytes":17412,"author":"snagarajan@businessinsider.com (Shalini Nagarajan)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f43eb0d89aff80028ab782b?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn15@2020_2/2020/09/06/02-59-47-110_f5e10b79e3902c43.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f5245547ed0ee001e25d7b1?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn9@2020_2/2020/09/06/03-00-00-306_8f305c89dcb623f4.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn78@2020_1/2020/09/06/02-59-58-308_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=HVMVz0W9zcc:zS5L2M61aA8:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn45@2020_5/2020/09/06/02-59-59-166_b402431e26cab839.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=HVMVz0W9zcc:zS5L2M61aA8:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn54@2020_5/2020/09/06/02-59-57-144_796c43bc2a0505fe.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn60@2020_6/2020/09/06/02-59-52-353_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=HVMVz0W9zcc:zS5L2M61aA8:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn35@2020_1/2020/09/06/02-59-47-450_69d57c6707bbd76b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/HVMVz0W9zcc":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn55@2020_3/2020/09/06/02-59-50-349_a45456e0e17f1116.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1599361164630},{"createdTime":"2020-09-06 10:59:24","updatedTime":"2020-09-06 10:59:24","title":"A Maine wedding is linked to 147 coronavirus cases and 3 deaths. Infections spilled over into a jail and two nursing homes.","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/maine-wedding-coronavirus-outbreak-church-reception-jail-nursing-homes-2020-9","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f3c40dc42f43f001ddfda08?format=jpeg\" alt=\"big weddings coronavirus pandemic 2x1\" height=\"1200\" width=\"2400\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases; Samantha Lee/Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>An <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/a-wedding-reception-spread-coronavirus-to-53-people-killing-one-2020-8\">indoor church wedding and reception</a> has been linked to 147 coronavirus cases across Maine.</li>\n<li>Three of those people have died. None of them were wedding attendees.</li>\n<li>Contact-tracing efforts found that guests at the wedding either directly or indirectly spread the virus to two nursing homes and inmates at a local jail.</li>\n<li>The pastor who officiated the wedding said people should have the freedom to not wear a face mask at a sermon on August 30.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>At the start of August, Maine had emerged from the coronavirus pandemic relatively unscathed. The state had one of the lowest case tallies in the US — and its average number of new daily cases was declining.</p><p>That was before <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/a-wedding-reception-spread-coronavirus-to-53-people-killing-one-2020-8\">an indoor church wedding and reception</a> on August 7 ignited a chain of infections across the state.&#160;</p><p>As of Saturday, 147 coronavirus cases were linked to the wedding — including three deaths. One of the deceased victims, an 83-year-old woman, died on August 31. Her husband, a 97-year-old World War II veteran, was hospitalized with the virus but is scheduled to be discharged soon.</p><p>None of the three people who died were wedding attendees.</p><p>The infections spread from Millinocket, a town in north-central Maine, to two nursing homes and a jail about 230 miles south. Maine's <a href=\"https://www.maine.gov/dhhs/mecdc/infectious-disease/epi/airborne/coronavirus/data.shtml\">weekly average of coronavirus cases</a> has now risen to 27 new daily cases, compared to 15 new daily cases on the day of the wedding.</p><p>\"One of the things we've learned over the past six months of working with outbreaks and COVID-19 is that no outbreak is an island,\" Maine CDC Director Dr. Nirav Shah said during a Thursday press briefing. \"What this really hammers home is that outbreaks are not isolated events. One outbreak can quickly lead to several more outbreaks, especially in a close geographic area.\"</p><p>Maine's contract tracers linked 72 wedding-related cases to the York County Jail, including 46 infections among inmates. One of the jail employees who tested positive was a guest at the wedding. The local sheriff, William King, said guards and inmates at the jail <a href=\"https://www.pressherald.com/2020/08/28/outbreak-spreads-dramatically-in-york-county-jail/\">weren't required to wear masks</a> prior to the outbreak.</p><p>Local officials also linked the wedding to an outbreak at Maplecrest&#160;Rehabilitation &#38;&#160;Living Center in Madison,&#160;Maine. One of the wedding guests had contact with a staff member at the nursing facility, who spread the infection to eight residents and seven staffers.</p><p>Contract tracers also recorded 10 cases at the Calvary Baptist Church in Sanford, Maine. The pastor at that church, Todd Bell, officiated the Millinocket wedding.</p><p>At a sermon on August 30, Bell <a href=\"https://www.bostonglobe.com/2020/08/31/metro/i-want-people-god-enjoy-liberty-pastor-maine-super-spreader-wedding-gives-defiant-indoor-sermon/\">said people should have the liberty</a> to choose whether to wear a face mask.</p><p>\"I'll tell you what the world wants all the churches to do,\" Bell said. \"They want us to shut down, go home, and let people get used to that just long enough until we can finally stop the advancing of the Gospel.\"</p><h2>The Maine wedding defied local laws&#160;</h2><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5e718a17c4854049785876b2?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Vietnamese tourists wearing wedding clothes put on face masks in Paris on March 15, 2020 amid the COVID-19 outbreak, caused by the novel coronavirus. - France on March 14, 2020 drastically stepped up its measures against the spread of the coronavirus, announcing the closure of all non-essential public places including restaurants and cafes.\" height=\"1311\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The wedding industry has been hit particularly hard by the coronavirus pandemic.\n<p class=\"copyright\">FRANCK FIFE/AFP via Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>The Millinocket wedding is a classic example of a superspreading event, in which one person infects a disproportionately large number of people. Researchers in Hong Kong have suggested that <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/super-spreader-events-account-for-most-coronavirus-transmission-2020-6\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"80\" data-uri=\"85d5cfa86db91f9c26e59bf9eedd58bf\">superspreader events involving indoor social gatherings</a>&#160;may be responsible for the majority of coronavirus transmission.</p><p><a href=\"https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/large-events/considerations-for-events-gatherings.html\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"60\" data-uri=\"1441404a61a36ee7e436217e6ab1bd4c\">Weddings are particularly high-risk</a>, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, because attendees often travel from outside the local area, which brings a risk of either introducing the coronavirus to local guests or spreading the virus to other parts of the state or country.</p><p>A&#160;<a href=\"https://www.medrxiv.org/content/10.1101/2020.02.28.20029272v2\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"80\" data-uri=\"0c5e7955a9f2514090ad643d1b094dfc\">study from Japanese scientists</a> estimated that the odds of a person spreading the coronavirus in a closed environment is almost 19 times higher than in an open-air environment, though that research is still awaiting peer review.</p><p>Maine's current limit on indoor gatherings is 50 people. At least 65 people attended the wedding ceremony at the Tri-Town Baptist Church in Millinocket. The reception at the Big Moose Inn also exceeded the state's indoor limit.</p><p>Disobeying local ordinances for public gatherings has had detrimental consequences in other parts of the US as well.</p><p>In July, a San Francisco church attempted to hold an indoor wedding, despite the fact that the city requires religious services to be held outdoors. At least 10 attendees, including the newlywed couple, later tested positive for the coronavirus.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/maine-wedding-coronavirus-outbreak-church-reception-jail-nursing-homes-2020-9'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=7WYPyLNoEHI:3pc0akseDzo:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=7WYPyLNoEHI:3pc0akseDzo:F7zBnMyn0Lo\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=7WYPyLNoEHI:3pc0akseDzo:F7zBnMyn0Lo\" href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=7WYPyLNoEHI:3pc0akseDzo:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=7WYPyLNoEHI:3pc0akseDzo:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\"></img></a>\n</div><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/7WYPyLNoEHI\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sat, 05 Sep 2020 19:31:46 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5f53d76ae6ff30001d4e74f9?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"dddca68a54faf1e351382085c6a16a88","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn28@2020_3/2020/09/06/02-59-51-043_ed93aa0d85eed619.webp","destWidth":1747,"destHeight":1310,"sourceBytes":110334,"destBytes":110334,"author":"insider@insider.com (Aria Bendix)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f3c40dc42f43f001ddfda08?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn86@2020_4/2020/09/06/03-00-01-226_829787fb773460db.webp","https://i.insider.com/5e718a17c4854049785876b2?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn90@2020_6/2020/09/06/03-00-00-132_d53d168a8c8121a6.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn78@2020_1/2020/09/06/02-59-58-308_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=7WYPyLNoEHI:3pc0akseDzo:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn19@2020_1/2020/09/06/02-59-52-228_6f98497ce5072e1e.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=7WYPyLNoEHI:3pc0akseDzo:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn6@2020_4/2020/09/06/02-59-56-565_12aa90fee47c2fe9.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn60@2020_6/2020/09/06/02-59-52-353_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=7WYPyLNoEHI:3pc0akseDzo:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn98@2020_1/2020/09/06/02-59-56-584_402202c9ae61a673.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/7WYPyLNoEHI":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn34@2020_6/2020/09/06/03-00-00-538_0b6966078c0951ae.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1599361164605},{"createdTime":"2020-09-06 10:59:24","updatedTime":"2020-09-06 10:59:24","title":"Leading US drugmakers will sign a pact to produce a safe coronavirus vaccine amid concerns about shots being rushed to market before the presidential election","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/us-drugmakers-moderna-pfizer-joint-pledge-coronavirus-vaccine-safety-2020-9","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5eac7571204ad32644504c9c?format=jpeg\" alt=\"covid 19 coronavirus vaccine working development britain.JPG\" height=\"1667\" width=\"2500\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Scientists work on a potential COVID-19 vaccine.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Carl Recine/Reuters</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Two drug companies at the forefront of the <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/coronavirus-vaccine-timeline-what-to-watch-leading-research-2020-3\">US race to develop a coronavirus vaccine</a>, Moderna and Pfizer, are expected to join a pledge that promises to put safety before speed.</li>\n<li>In an <a href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/covid-19-vaccine-developers-prepare-joint-pledge-on-safety-standards-11599257729\">early draft obtained by the Wall Street Journal</a>, the companies promise to only seek emergency FDA approval after final human trials show \"substantial evidence of safety and efficacy.\"</li>\n<li>Many public-health experts worry that the Trump administration will rush the timeline for vaccine development before researchers know about adverse side effects.</li>\n<li>On Friday, President Trump said a coronavirus vaccine would <a href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/nation/2020/09/04/coronavirus-covid-live-updates-us/\">probably be available for distribution</a> next month &#8212; despite experts' claims that it could take until 2021.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>The race to develop a coronavirus vaccine has already shattered records.</p><p>In March, the biotechnology company Moderna entered its vaccine candidate in a clinical trial less than 70 days after the virus was sequenced, shaving a year off the development process. Since then, two US drug companies, Moderna and Pfizer, have <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/coronavirus-vaccine-timeline-what-to-watch-leading-research-2020-3\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"ce6be15cc44baee5e33fdd7aa39c6f48\">published early data</a> showing that their vaccines generated immune responses without causing serious side effects.</p><p>That could put the companies on track to finish their human trials in October, under the most optimistic scenario. But scientists and public-health experts worry about the push to bring a vaccine to market before data clearly shows it's safe and effective.&#160;</p><p>To assuage these concerns, Moderna and Pfizer — along with US pharmaceutical company Johnson &#38; Johnson and French pharmaceutical company Sanofi — are preparing to release a joint statement that promises to put safety before speed.</p><p>The statement <a href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/covid-19-vaccine-developers-prepare-joint-pledge-on-safety-standards-11599257729\">could be released as early as next week</a>, according to the Wall Street Journal, which obtained an early copy. In the draft, the companies pledge to only seek emergency FDA approval for their vaccine candidates after final human trials show \"substantial evidence of safety and efficacy.\"</p><p>A sentence from the draft reads: \"We believe this pledge will help ensure public confidence in the COVID-19 vaccines that may ultimately be approved and adherence to the rigorous scientific and regulatory process by which they are evaluated.\"</p><p>Most experts agree there's little hope of a coronavirus vaccine being ready before 2021. But President Donald Trump has suggested otherwise: On Friday, Trump said a coronavirus vaccine would <a href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/nation/2020/09/04/coronavirus-covid-live-updates-us/\">probably be available for distribution</a> next month, according to The Washington Post. Trump has previously said <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-claims-coronavirus-vaccine-will-be-ready-right-around-election-2020-8\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"20\" data-uri=\"e43bd95d142c574a8ad2ea975d2171da\">a vaccine may become available</a> \"right around\" the presidential election on November 3.</p><p>\"I'm rushing it. I am. I'm pushing everybody,\" Trump&#160;<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-claims-coronavirus-vaccine-will-be-ready-right-around-election-2020-8\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"20\" data-uri=\"e43bd95d142c574a8ad2ea975d2171da\">told radio host Geraldo Rivera</a>&#160;in an August 6 interview.</p><p>The US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention is prepared for that scenario: The agency has asked public health officials in all 50 states to get ready for vaccine distribution by late October. CDC Director Robert Redfield said the goal was to be ahead of the game. The agency expects there to be one or more vaccines ready by November or December.</p><p>Still, public-health experts fear that the Trump administration could rush the timeline before researchers know whether a vaccine produces adverse side effects. Some White House officials believe Trump's reelection prospects <a href=\"https://apnews.com/7cc45cdcb3e53515b8ff4304a4ae5c06\">hinge on whether a vaccine comes to market</a>, the Associated Press reported in July.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f2c32ee7924a13ad872185a?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Trump NIH NIAID coronavirus vaccine\" height=\"1666\" width=\"2500\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Dr. Barney Graham, Deputy Director at the Vaccine Research Center at the National Institutes of Health, speaks with President Donald Trump during a lab tour on March 3, 2020, in Bethesda, Maryland.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Evan Vucci/Associated Press</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>\"This timeline of the initial deployment at the end of October is deeply worrisome for the politicization of public health and the potential safety ramifications,\" Saskia Popescu, an epidemiologist at the University of Arizona, <a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/09/02/health/covid-19-vaccine-cdc-plans.html\">told The New York Times</a> on Wednesday. \"It's hard not to see this as a push for a pre-election vaccine.\"</p><p>Under normal circumstances, vaccines take 10 years or more to develop and approve. The Trump administration's effort to accelerate and fund vaccine research, Operation Warp Speed, hopes to deliver 300 million doses of a safe, effective coronavirus vaccine by at least January 2021. The program is manufacturing six vaccine candidates in large quantities while clinical trials are still ongoing.&#160;</p><p>\"My concern is even with the name Operation Warp Speed, because it suggests that speed is the determining factor as opposed to science,\" Dr. Leana Wen, a public-health professor at George Washington University who previously served as Baltimore's Health Commissioner, previously told Business Insider.</p><p>At <a href=\"https://www.al.com/news/2020/09/uab-expert-says-rushed-covid-vaccine-is-pushing-scientists-into-data-free-zone.html\">an online press conference</a> on Thursday, Dr. Jeanne Marrazzo, director of the University of Alabama at Birmingham's Division of Infectious Diseases, said it would take until at least early 2021 to know whether a vaccine was safe and effective.</p><p id=\"IZBGHI76LNFYRJJDOKJYOR7VA4\">\"People have been incredibly concerned about vaccine safety for decades and we've spent countless hours, countless press conferences, countless meetings, trying to assure them that we have done our absolute best to make sure that every vaccine we give is safe,\" Marrazzo said. \"This is not that. This is exactly the opposite of that so it makes me very concerned.\"</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/us-drugmakers-moderna-pfizer-joint-pledge-coronavirus-vaccine-safety-2020-9'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a
