border=\"0\" /></a> \n </div>\n <img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/WfZwVCmZPVk\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\" />\n</hr>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sat, 05 Sep 2020 14:27:00 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5f4fece4e6ff30001d4e6b3f?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"14436b0ec0d9b2d1d051790954aa8ad9","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn31@2020_1/2020/09/06/02-59-44-464_39a3ab97913068aa.webp","destWidth":1666,"destHeight":1249,"sourceBytes":63208,"destBytes":63208,"author":"tbufete@businessinsider.com (Tercius Bufete)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f4fecb7e6ff30001d4e6b3d?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn26@2020_2/2020/09/06/02-59-57-768_47382ec3d592374d.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn78@2020_1/2020/09/06/02-59-58-308_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=WfZwVCmZPVk:o8F7HtIOwng:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn88@2020_6/2020/09/06/02-59-47-730_8e91d9aeee0c97b1.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=WfZwVCmZPVk:o8F7HtIOwng:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn13@2020_5/2020/09/06/02-59-45-452_de215df840553d15.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn60@2020_6/2020/09/06/02-59-52-353_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=WfZwVCmZPVk:o8F7HtIOwng:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn22@2020_6/2020/09/06/03-00-00-528_89c814d3888a8e6c.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/WfZwVCmZPVk":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn56@2020_6/2020/09/06/02-59-48-687_9e8835101d9cc954.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1599361164660},{"createdTime":"2020-09-06 10:59:24","updatedTime":"2020-09-06 10:59:24","title":"What gaslighting is, and 5 signs someone may be gaslighting you, according to a psychotherapist","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/what-gaslighting-is-and-5-signs-someone-is-gaslighting-you-2020-9","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f494d4b7ffa48002894ceb2?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Depression\" height=\"1414\" width=\"1885\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The term gaslighting may be used casually, but it&#39;s a serious term in therapy.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Josef Lindau/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/author/amy-morin\" data-analytics-module=\"summary_bullets\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"0\" data-uri=\"fa86f4bd4d935d709a1e8684bd64a05c\">Amy Morin</a>&#160;is a psychotherapist, licensed clinical social worker, mental strength coach, and international bestselling author.</li>\n<li>Despite its casual references in pop culture, Morin explains that gaslighting is a serious term in therapy, and a problem that many victims struggle to recognize due to the nature of the abuse.</li>\n<li>Morin says that someone who is gaslighting you will deny things that you know to be true, make you question your own memories, and weaponize your displays of emotions against you.</li>\n<li><strong data-stringify-type=\"bold\">If you're struggling, call the SAMHSA National Helpline, 1-800-662-HELP (4357), or reach out to the Crisis Text Line by texting HOME to 741741.</strong></li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\" data-analytics-module=\"summary_bullets\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"0\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>In psychology, the term \"gaslighting\" occurs when someone tries to convince an individual into thinking they're losing touch with reality. Over time, the victim often grows convinced that they can't trust their own judgment.</p><p>The term gaslight stems from a <a href=\"https://www.concordtheatricals.com/p/2380/angel-street-gaslight\">play in the 1930s</a> where the husband manipulated small aspects of the environment — such as dimming the gaslights — to convince his wife that she was delusional.&#160;&#160;</p><p>Now, gaslighting is frequently referenced in pop culture — perhaps you've heard the song \"Gaslighter\" by The Chicks (formerly the Dixie Chicks).</p><p>While it's often referenced in a fun manner in the media, in the therapy office, it's a serious problem. Quite often, by the time a victim seeks professional help, they've often endured a painful existence for quite some time. Most of them have spent years thinking they were \"going crazy.\" And for some of them, seeking treatment only reinforces the idea that there is something seriously wrong with them.</p><p>If someone can identify that they're being gaslighted early on, it could prevent years — maybe even decades — of manipulation. Psychoanalyst Robin Stern has written a book called <a href=\"https://www.amazon.com/Gaslight-Effect-Survive-Manipulation-Control/dp/0767924452/ref=tmm_hrd_swatch_0?_encoding=UTF8&qid=1599099855&sr=1-3p;sr=1-3\">\"The Gaslight Effect</a>,\" which outlines signs that you're being gaslighted.</p><p>Her research is in line with what I've seen firsthand as a therapist. Here are the top signs that someone is gaslighting you:</p><h2><strong style=\"color: #000000;\">1. They deny things you know to be true</strong></h2><p>You might think someone who is gaslighting you would only lie about big things that they could cover up or hide. But that's not the case.</p><p>They often lie about all things big and small just to throw you off. They might deny something that just happened — and then insist your memory is \"off.\" They may lie about what you did yesterday and then insist you are \"crazy\" if you don't remember doing it.</p><h2><strong style=\"color: #000000;\">2. They pretend to be concerned for your psychological well-being</strong></h2><p>A gaslighter will often say things like, \"That's disturbing you can't remember where you put your purse.\"</p><p>In reality, they probably hid it from you. They'll constantly act like you're fragile or that you're not in your \"right mind\" so that you'll question yourself.</p><h2><strong style=\"color: #000000;\">3. They isolate you from other people</strong></h2><p>They will tell you that your loved ones are talking about you behind your back. And they will do all they can to separate you from your friends and family.</p><p>They may even reach out to people without your knowledge to tell them that you're having some problems lately. This may lead to people asking if you're OK — which could reinforce your fear that there's something wrong with you.</p><h2><strong style=\"color: #000000;\">4. They minimize your feelings and use them against you</strong></h2><p>Whether you express sadness, anger, or fear, they'll use it against you. They'll tell you that crying is \"proof that you're crazy\" or getting upset is evidence that you are \"an emotional wreck.\"</p><p>They will insist that all of your emotions are unreasonable and irrational. You might find yourself constantly apologizing for your feelings.</p><h2><strong style=\"color: #000000;\">5. They insist getting help is proof you aren't stable</strong></h2><p>If you talk to your therapist or get hospitalized due to the emotional distress of the situation, they'll insist they were right when they said you were mentally unstable.</p><p>They'll likely say you're beyond help anyway or that mental health professionals can't \"fix you.\" They may even reach out to professionals to tell them that you seem confused lately, in an effort to make sure you don't get effective treatment for what's really going on — you're being manipulated.</p><h2><strong>How to get help</strong></h2><p>It's impossible to feel psychologically well when someone is constantly trying to convince you that you are mentally ill, or that you can't trust your own judgment or memory.</p><p>So the key to feeling better usually involves getting away from the perpetrator. Being away from the person, even for a short period of time, often helps victims see that they are OK.</p><p>If you suspect you might be the victim of gaslighting, reach out for help. Talk to a therapist, either online or in-person, about your distress.&#160;</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/what-gaslighting-is-and-5-signs-someone-is-gaslighting-you-2020-9'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=5xJfQfNN-j0:p-txnuoYa4k:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=5xJfQfNN-j0:p-txnuoYa4k:F7zBnMyn0Lo\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=5xJfQfNN-j0:p-txnuoYa4k:F7zBnMyn0Lo\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=5xJfQfNN-j0:p-txnuoYa4k:V_sGLiPBpWU\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=5xJfQfNN-j0:p-txnuoYa4k:V_sGLiPBpWU\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=5xJfQfNN-j0:p-txnuoYa4k:qj6IDK7rITs\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=5xJfQfNN-j0:p-txnuoYa4k:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=5xJfQfNN-j0:p-txnuoYa4k:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\"></img></a>\n</div><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/5xJfQfNN-j0\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sat, 05 Sep 2020 14:00:00 target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"><strong>Winc</strong></a>: 45% off your first order using code <strong>LD2020</strong></p>\n\tLabor Day 2020 FAQs\n\t\n\t<h3>When do Labor Day sales start in 2020?</h3><p>Labor Day sales typically start the week before Labor Day, which falls on Monday, September 7 this year. Most sales run through the weekend, but some continue to run for a couple of days afterward, giving shoppers a full week or more in some cases to take advantage of deals.</p><h3>What types of deals will I find over Labor Day weekend?</h3><p>Most online retailers offer discounts for Labor Day. Shoppers can expect big discounts on tech, clothes, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/best-mattress\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">mattresses</a>, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/labor-day-furniture-sales\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">furniture</a> and home goods, outdoor gear, and more during the week leading up to and following Labor Day weekend.</p><p>Labor Day weekend is one of the best times in the year to shop online for furniture, appliances, and outdoor gear.&#160;</p><p>If you're shopping for fall-friendly attire, it's also a solid time to refresh your wardrobe. Check out our buying guides to the best <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/best-cashmere-sweater\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">women's cashmere sweaters</a>, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/best-mens-cashmere-sweaters\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">men's cashmere sweaters</a>, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/best-winter-coat-women\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">women's winter coats</a>, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/best-winter-coat-men\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">men's winter coats</a>, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/best-slippers-women\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">women's slippers</a>, and <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/best-slippers-men\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">men's slippers</a> for inspiration.</p>\n\tAll of our additional coverage related to the Labor Day sales\n\t\n\t<h3><strong><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/best-labor-day-sales\">A full rundown of all the Labor Day sales happening in 2020</a></strong></h3><p>We highlighted 16 of the best Labor Day sales to shop this weekend, but there are plenty more. border=\"0\"></img></a>\n</div><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/O7PdSmbFVfs\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sat, 05 Sep 2020 14:32:00 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5d601db423f19c67823b5b1b?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"f5c6cb874de093ee3bff3f05f4dd27c6","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn10@2020_6/2020/09/06/02-59-29-728_1d53b9795b9620a0.webp","destWidth":1200,"destHeight":900,"sourceBytes":98414,"destBytes":98414,"author":"rrosmarin@businessinsider.com (Remi Rosmarin,Tercius Bufete)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5d601db423f19c67823b5b1b?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn10@2020_6/2020/09/06/02-59-29-728_1d53b9795b9620a0.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f490264db1ed0002971472b?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn61@2020_3/2020/09/06/02-59-54-294_5d3125f387a44aca.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f4902f4db1ed0002971472f?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn52@2020_1/2020/09/06/02-59-53-223_df36fd9ea740fca2.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f51326b7ed0ee001e25d51a?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn12@2020_3/2020/09/06/02-59-49-050_54ae5042d5177b3f.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f4d58ed7ffa48002894d3b6?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn92@2020_3/2020/09/06/02-59-46-802_a3640c5b82b82659.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f490503db1ed0002971473b?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn96@2020_5/2020/09/06/02-59-46-034_c6451960425205b6.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f49056cdb1ed00029714740?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn54@2020_3/2020/09/06/02-59-54-485_0165fdf30fab4921.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f490601cd2fec00296a4bcb?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn63@2020_6/2020/09/06/02-59-51-355_59b360ac287a21cf.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f4d582960bf1f00280798e3?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn38@2020_2/2020/09/06/02-59-55-871_24523e6c042bb07f.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f4906e2cd2fec00296a4bd4?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn59@2020_5/2020/09/06/02-59-49-711_6d2762253cf2fc77.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f5133927ed0ee001e25d522?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn84@2020_1/2020/09/06/02-59-47-796_776c0be9704cc758.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn78@2020_1/2020/09/06/02-59-58-308_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=O7PdSmbFVfs:NRQqXDBC3yE:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn24@2020_2/2020/09/06/02-59-45-328_4f4e806f97c7229c.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=O7PdSmbFVfs:NRQqXDBC3yE:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn82@2020_2/2020/09/06/02-59-58-431_9ed3c59428a6a08a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn60@2020_6/2020/09/06/02-59-52-353_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=O7PdSmbFVfs:NRQqXDBC3yE:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn64@2020_6/2020/09/06/02-59-45-492_c6067ab8ab67f4cf.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/O7PdSmbFVfs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn75@2020_1/2020/09/06/02-59-45-673_29f2178202a95b05.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1599361164631},{"createdTime":"2020-09-06 10:59:24","updatedTime":"2020-09-06 10:59:24","title":"I put a $2,300 electric all-terrain bike to the test, and it was the most fun I've had since the pandemic began","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/charge-xc-electric-off-road-bike-ebike-review-2020-9","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f5297a4e6ff30001d4e73c0?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Charge XC electric review bike\" height=\"2016\" width=\"4032\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Graham Rapier / Business Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Charge, a British startup now owned by Cannondale, wants to simplify the bike-buying process.&#160;</li>\n<li>I tested out their high-end model, a $2,300 behemoth designed to handle off-road trails.&#160;</li>\n<li>It's the most fun I've had on two wheels since childhood, but just not a feasible purchase for my current living situation.&#160;</li>\n<li>If you have the space &#8212; and funds &#8212; it might be the best socially distant recreation option possible, and it's actually in stock (<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/united-states-is-running-out-of-bikes-during-coronavirus-pandemic-2020-5\">unlike many other bikes)</a>.&#160;</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>There's no real reason to own an electric bike as tough as a tank, that glides over asphalt as easily as gravel or mud and bounds up hills with no struggle.</p><p>But, if you can afford it, there's also no reason <em>not</em> to.</p><p>At $2,300, the Charge XC — the heaviest duty member of the British company's three-bike lineup meant to have a choice for everyone — is a seemingly perfect fit for the weekend warrior or a cycle-curious explorer. It's also great for a slightly out-of-shape journalist like me, who just wants to tear up some dirt trails to blow off steam.</p><p>I took out a fully loaded version of the bike for spins around New York City to see how well it weathered rough asphalt, bumpy bike lanes, gravel paths, muddy trails, and any other obstacles I could find.</p><h2><strong>Unlike some new bikes, the Charge XC was a breeze to put together — even in a tiny apartment</strong></h2><p>The box is heavy but has punched-out handles like any good box should. It also has handy pull cords that rip along perforated edges, easily exposing the bike and its parts.</p><p>A cardboard stand — no plastic here! — helped keep the bike upright while installing the front wheel and other parts. Still, it's an easier job with two people.</p><p>\"A gigantic challenge in design, really more than the bike, was to get rid of all the plastic, the zip ties, all the foam,\" Charge founder Nick Larsen told me in an interview. \"That might seem like something that would be normal to most people — but if you saw the equivalent of what a bike would normally come like, it was a huge undertaking.\"</p><p>From the packaging to the integrated battery, the sleek design made it clear how much thought went into the bike's creation. Larsen told me many of his design peers from school ended up at Dyson, the legendary British design shop, and the inspiration for Charge bikes was closely linked.&#160;</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f529678e6ff30001d4e73b7?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Charge XC electric review bike\" height=\"3024\" width=\"4032\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Graham Rapier / Business Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>\"Bikes are a little bit like computers used to be,\" he said. \"They're complicated to understand and a bit of an intimidating purchase. That's what computers were before Apple and others made the user experience more simple.\"</p><p>Within 30 minutes, it was ready to ride (but still needed to charge). Within a few hours I was ready go go explore — and had some hills in mind to put it through the gauntlet.</p><h2><strong>First impression: the smoothest ride I've been on in a while</strong></h2><p>This thing is like riding a motorcycle no matter how high the seat is set thanks to a 60 mm handlebar rise. The handlebars are also incredibly wide, which is nice for off-road control, but I was hesitant to squeeze through the gaps in traffic road bikes can go without a problem, but was never uncomfortably hunched over.</p><p>And when the motor kicks in, it's smooth sailing. It has three settings, from \"eco\" mode's slight boost up to the near-whiplash-inducing \"sport\" mode.&#160;</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f529676e6ff30001d4e73b6?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Charge XC electric review bike\" height=\"3024\" width=\"4032\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Graham Rapier / Business Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>I set off with two targets in mind: the oldest bike path in the United States, and the only forest in Brooklyn.</p><p>First up was Ocean Parkway. This bustling road was designed by the architectural duo behind Central Park and other famous US green spaces, and has two grassy malls flanking its lanes from Prospect Park all the way down to Coney Island. It was one of the first true \"highways\" in the United States, and a few years after its construction it also became home to the first true bike path in the country — it's only seen a spattering of maintenance since.</p><p>Jokes aside, the bike lane is notorious for bumps after years of water, ice, tree roots and other forces have buckled the asphalt. Charge XC's massive Goodyear tires and fork suspension handled the rough riding with ease.</p><p>Its plastic fenders also helped keep disgusting gutter water from splashing up at intersections. However, for all their utility, the fenders shake like crazy over the smallest bumps, rattling loudly nearly constantly — and I'm not the first person to notice it. These seemed easily removable, and are a small part of otherwise perfect bike.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f5296717ed0ee001e25da4a?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Charge XC electric review bike\" height=\"3024\" width=\"4032\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>A better look at the bike&#39;s tough tires, disc brakes, and finicky fenders.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Graham Rapier / Business Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><h2><strong>Up hills and through mud where the bike truly shined</strong></h2><p>The Charge XC isn't a mountain bike, despite having a frame that easily could. Its numerous warnings against attempting jumps seemed funny at first, until I realized just how tempting it would be to shoot for a dangerous amount of air.</p><p>The bike didn't skip a beat over loose gravel or puddles of mud that would be impossible to find traction on with many other bikes. Even on steep up-hill climbs, I lost balance before its motor ever spun the back wheel. With so much power underfoot, it's easy to forget to change gears sometimes too.</p><p>Down the other side of a hill is where things got interesting. I'd never used disc brakes before this very moment. I'm here to testify that the hydraulic disc brakes on the Charge work instantaneously, and well. In hindsight the near incident was hilarious, and goes to show no matter how much energy the 55-pound bike and its rider can muster, things can stop quickly.</p><p>After an hour or so of taking the bike on every different earthen path I could find in the park's winding ravine, I felt the bike had been adequately put through the paces.</p><p>It was when I got home that I realized an important qualifier for potential customers: the weight. It took all of my effort to get the bike up a flight of stairs, and might be more suited to someone on the ground floor or with a garage. (Though to be fair, most electric bikes are expensive and a lighter frame wouldn't be as tough.)</p><p>\"Compared to an analog bike it's heavy,\" Larsen told me, \"but what you benefit from is range and performance.\"</p><p>He wasn't wrong: my 90-minute, eight-mile adventure had only used up about 10% of the bikes battery, according to the convenient heads-up display.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f5296727ed0ee001e25da4b?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Charge XC electric review bike\" height=\"3024\" width=\"4032\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The control screen (with battery info) up display is big enough to see without being distracted\n<p class=\"copyright\">Graham Rapier / Business Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>And even despite the struggle to take it up my building's stairs, the folding pedals and swiveling handlebars made for easy storage in an otherwise tiny apartment.</p><p>The bikes are in stock, too — or at least they were when I spoke to Larsen in late August —&#160; a major selling point these days as manufacturers rush to build bikes as fast as they can to keep up with an absolute explosion in demand.</p><p>\"We've got stock. We've got products,\" he said. \"How long that will last I can't tell you.\"<br><br></p><p><em><a href=\"https://www.chargebikes.com/\">Browse the Charge bike lineup here.</a></em></p><div +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5f5296ae7ed0ee001e25da4c?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"94c2fe9b412d7ade92f5b56b588c0722","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn50@2020_6/2020/09/06/02-59-44-362_266326d0f8511728.webp","destWidth":2947,"destHeight":2210,"sourceBytes":1404232,"destBytes":1404232,"author":"grapier@businessinsider.com (Graham Rapier)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f5297a4e6ff30001d4e73c0?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn94@2020_1/2020/09/06/03-00-00-303_112fb1b4f5f7c92d.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f529678e6ff30001d4e73b7?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn56@2020_6/2020/09/06/02-59-51-732_b65a1dd53c699cbf.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f529676e6ff30001d4e73b6?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn76@2020_5/2020/09/06/02-59-53-565_59a673a744d93a72.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f5296717ed0ee001e25da4a?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn23@2020_5/2020/09/06/02-59-46-692_74d3234219525dce.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f5296727ed0ee001e25da4b?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn44@2020_6/2020/09/06/02-59-53-437_8ae25c63551bf9cf.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn78@2020_1/2020/09/06/02-59-58-308_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=iRZTro4h3fE:ieqn3P5ejAM:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn87@2020_5/2020/09/06/02-59-45-805_db4d32fa59ed82b3.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=iRZTro4h3fE:ieqn3P5ejAM:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn83@2020_5/2020/09/06/02-59-48-757_8138c3fea13bb20b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn60@2020_6/2020/09/06/02-59-52-353_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=iRZTro4h3fE:ieqn3P5ejAM:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn67@2020_5/2020/09/06/02-59-45-531_b07500b13e457afd.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/iRZTro4h3fE":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn69@2020_6/2020/09/06/02-59-54-423_30053eb020181644.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1599361164649},{"createdTime":"2020-09-06 10:59:24","updatedTime":"2020-09-06 10:59:24","title":"Tens of thousands of schools have dangerously poor ventilation, raising the risk that the coronavirus could spread through the air","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/poor-indoor-air-quality-could-make-schools-coronavirus-hotspots-2020-9","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f32a4975fa9a419464b3b22?format=jpeg\" alt=\"texas school reopening\" height=\"1987\" width=\"3146\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Elementary school students walk to classes to begin their school day in Godley, Texas, Wednesday, Aug. 5, 2020.\n<p class=\"copyright\">LM Otero/AP Imagse</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>As schools reopen, teachers and parents worry that weak ventilation will put students at greater risk of catching the coronavirus.</li>\n<li>Poor air quality can impact test scores and learning; it's been a problem in US schools for decades.&#160;</li>\n<li>A June report estimated that 41% of school districts &#8212; 36,000 schools &#8212; need major upgrades to their ventilation systems.&#160;</li>\n<li>Experts suggest schools with poor air quality install portable ventilation systems.&#160;</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>&#160;</p><p>Three years ago, teacher Kerri Landry found a hole in the wall of her middle-school classroom in Coventry, Rhode Island. It looked strange, so Landry took a flash photo of the inside of the hole — and captured a troubling image.</p><p>\"The entire inside of that wall was all black mold, the entire thing,\" she told Business Insider.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f4fbaaf7ed0ee001e25d001?format=jpeg\" alt=\"blackmold_hole\" height=\"4048\" width=\"6072\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Left: A hole in the wall of Kerri Landry&#39;s classroom at the Alan Shawn Feinstein Middle School in Coventry, Rhode Island. Right: Black mold inside the wall behind the hole.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Kerri Landry</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>Landry&#160;showed her husband Tom the picture. A specialist in heating, ventilation and air conditioning (HVAC) at a local company called Environmental Systems, Tom knew the mold was an indicator of the building's poor air quality.&#160;</p><p>School custodians patched up the hole and treated the mold, but Landry said she's seen mold in other classrooms, too. She thinks it may be a sign that her school — the Alan Shawn Feinstein Middle School — shouldn't bring students back at all.</p><p>\"This has been an ongoing issue for years,\" Landry said, adding that she's recently been <a href=\"https://turnto10.com/news/coronavirus/reopening-schools/upgrading-air-filtration-systems-at-school-buildings-is-a-pricey-challenge-for-districts\">telling anyone who will listen</a> that the school district must fix its ventilation systems before students return. She feels strongly about that for her own safety as well as that of her students and two youngest sons, who attend a high school in the district.&#160;</p><p>However, Landry's school district decided on Monday to do a phased reopening, with all grades slated to be back by October 13.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f4fb941e6ff30001d4e69ee?format=jpeg\" alt=\"kerri landry\" height=\"3024\" width=\"4032\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Kerri Landry, a teacher in the Coventry School District in Rhode Island, with her youngest sons.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Courtesy of Kerri Landry</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>Landry's school isn't exceptional: Research shows that air quality is a major issue in tens of thousands of schools across the US. A June report from the <a href=\"https://www.gao.gov/assets/710/707374.pdf\">Government Accountability Office estimated</a> that 41% of districts nationwide, or 36,000 schools, need major upgrades to their HVAC systems.</p><p>Before the pandemic, poor air quality in schools was problematic because it impeded kids' learning and lowered their test scores. But now, faulty HVAC systems are even more concerning since they could facilitate the spread of the coronavirus.&#160;</p><h2><strong>The link between coronavirus transmission and HVAC systems</strong></h2><p>The coronavirus most commonly spreads via respiratory droplets emitted when an infected person coughs, sneezes, speaks, or breathes heavily. But research suggests it can also be airborne, meaning the virus gets transmitted via aerosols: tiny particles or droplets that can hang in the air, potentially <a href=\"https://www.health.harvard.edu/diseases-and-conditions/coronavirus-resource-center\">for hours at a time</a>.&#160;&#160;</p><p>Either way, most instances of documented coronavirus transmission have occurred in <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/coronavirus-risk-higher-tight-indoor-spaces-with-little-air-flow-2020-5\">tight, poorly ventilated indoor spaces</a>; one <a href=\"https://www.medrxiv.org/content/10.1101/2020.02.28.20029272v2\">study</a> (though not yet peer-reviewed) suggested that a person might be nearly 20 times more likely to spread the coronavirus inside than outside.&#160;</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5ebc1d66578532025d11d9a5?format=jpeg\" alt=\"FILE PHOTO: Students wearing face masks are seen inside a classroom during a government-organised media tour at a high school as more students returned to campus following the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) outbreak, in Shanghai, China May 7, 2020.  REUTERS/Aly Song\" height=\"3943\" width=\"5915\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Students are seen inside a classroom at a high school in Shanghai\n<p class=\"copyright\">Aly Song/Reuters</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>Studies have also shown that poor HVAC systems can spread the coronavirus around, sparking outbreaks. In one <a href=\"https://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/26/7/20-0764_article\">case study</a>, a single person infected nine others at a restaurant in Guangzhou, China. Epidemiologists found that the strong airflow in the restaurant's air conditioning — and lack of effective filtration and ventilation — likely carried droplets from one table to several others.&#160;</p><p>\"The biggest risk comes from poorly ventilated, crowded environments where people spend a lot of time. Unfortunately, that kind of perfectly describes a lot of schools,\" <a href=\"https://civmin.utoronto.ca/home/about-us/directory/professors/jeffrey-siegel/\">Jeffrey Siegel</a>, a professor of civil engineering at the University of Toronto, told Business Insider.</p><p>To ensure an HVAC system removes coronavirus particles from the air — at a school or elsewhere — it needs have adequate ventilation and filtration, not just circulation. One crucial factor, then, is airflow: the amount of new air that flows through a building. Most buildings should have at least 15 cubic feet per person per minute.&#160;</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f4fc2247ed0ee001e25d031?format=jpeg\" alt=\"MERV installation\" height=\"5464\" width=\"8192\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Mike Saladino cleans an air duct before installing an HVAC filter at Gold&#39;s Gym in Islip, New York, August 24, 2020.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Al Bello/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>Filtration is also key: On commercial HVAC units, filters are rated according to their minimum efficiency reporting value (MERV). Both HEPA and MERV-13 or -14 filters can block most coronavirus particles.</p><h2><strong>Most schools don't have safe indoor air</strong></h2><p>Most US schools don't meet the standards necessary to prevent coronavirus transmission indoors, according to Corey Metzger, who leads the school-reopening task force for The American Society of Heating, Refrigerating and Air-Conditioning Engineers, or ASHRAE. The group offers a list of <a href=\"https://www.ashrae.org/file%20library/technical%20resources/covid-19/ashrae-reopening-schools-and-universities-c19-guidance.pdf\">HVAC guidelines</a> for schools.&#160;</p><p>\"A large percentage of facilities, if not the majority, don't meet our recommended minimums for ventilation or other operating capabilities,\" Metzger said.</p><p>These standards include proper filter installation, ensuring circulation of outdoor air, and balanced humidity levels.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5ebb322b48d92c2a17674f43?format=jpeg\" alt=\"school class children coronavirus reopen reopening\" height=\"1492\" width=\"2300\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>A teacher wears a mask at a private school in Saint-Sebastien-sur-Loire, France, May 12, 2020.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://www.reutersconnect.com/all?id=tag%3Areuters.com%2C2020%3Anewsml_RC2YMG941C1C&#38;share=true\" target=\"_blank\">Stephane Mahe/Reuters</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>Landry's husband, Tom, said these problems certainly persist in the schools where his wife teaches and sons study: Most don't have systems that can support MERV-13 and 14 filters.&#160;</p><p>\"Our schools are very old and [have] antiquated HVAC systems,\" he said. \"The majority of schools in our town don't have any fresh air coming into them at all.\"</p><p>Craig Levis, the Coventry district's superintendent, told Business Insider that the middle school where Landry teaches is his \"primary focus\" in terms of addressing air quality. He said he's hired HVAC specialists to inspect the district's other buildings and help with quick fixes, like placing fans near windows to increase ventilation.</p><p>\"If there are simple things I can do to mitigate the virus, I put a stake in the ground, and that's what we're doing,\" he said.</p><p>Siegel said he's concerned that fall and winter could make air-quality problems in schools even worse, since cold weather will likely lead teachers to close windows, and holding classes outside will be difficult. Plus, Siegel said, indoor heating could dry out the air, enabling viral particles to travel farther and drying out people's mucous membranes, which can weaken immune systems.&#160;</p><h2><strong>What parents can look out for, and what teachers can do</strong></h2><p>Even before the coronavirus hit, poor ventilation in schools created problems for students, primarily due to the buildup of carbon dioxide. Previous studies have shown that high levels of CO2 in classrooms can contribute to poor focus and <a href=\"https://www.sciencenewsforstudents.org/article/stuffy-classrooms-may-lower-test-scores\">lower test scores.</a></p><p>But upgrading a school's HVAC system can cost millions of dollars and take months to years.</p><p>Siegel said a few other measures can mitigate the risks of low-quality ventilation systems in the meantime, though. For instance, portable ventilation systems can help filter air in individual classrooms. The filters are loud, but they work.</p><p>\"I don't want anyone to think that I'm saying this is a simple problem, but it is a solvable problem,\" Siegel said.&#160;</p><p>Additionally, although there's no simple, easy, or cheap way to measure coronavirus particles in the air, carbon dioxide can be a \"canary in the coal mine,\" according to Roger Silveira, an air-quality specialist and the facilities director at San Jose's East Side Union High School District. Carbon-dioxide monitors sell for <a href=\"https://www.amazon.com/CO2Meter-AZ-0004-Temperature-Relative-Humidity/dp/B001PDGFR8?tag=bisafetynet2-20\">about $100</a>.&#160;</p><p>In a building with good ventilation, CO2 levels should generally stay under 1,100 parts per million, Silveira said.&#160;</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f4fc2c0e6ff30001d4e6a2e?format=jpeg\" alt=\"CO2 monitor\" height=\"1024\" width=\"821\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>A wall-mounted carbon-dioxide meter reads 818 ppm in Walnut Creek, California, September 2, 2019.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Smith Collection/Gado/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>Opening windows is another obvious way to mitigate the problem, as is holding classes in larger spaces, like gymnasiums and auditoriums, according to Dr. Tina Tan, an infectious-disease specialist at Northwestern University's Feinberg School of Medicine.</p><p>\"I think right now we have to think outside the box,\" Tan said.&#160;</p><p>She also recommends that teachers limit activities involving shouting or singing, since those create <a href=\"https://www.theatlantic.com/ideas/archive/2020/08/wear-your-mask-and-stop-talking/615796/\">more potentially virus-laden droplets</a> than ordinary talking.</p><p>Of course, remote learning is likely the safest option for many districts, though it comes with plenty of its own challenges.</p><p>Some districts that are reopening still offer a remote option for that reason; Landry's is one of them. At the moment, she's not sure what to do. Her sons want to go back to school, but both have preexisting respiratory issues. She doesn't want them to have a subpar, remote education, but she's also afraid for their lives.&#160;</p><p>\"It's so difficult as a parent to make this decision — no parent should have to make it,\" Landry said, adding, \"it's like playing Russian roulette.\"</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a (Susie Neilson)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f32a4975fa9a419464b3b22?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn92@2020_4/2020/09/06/02-59-49-700_4583496974be77ec.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f4fbaaf7ed0ee001e25d001?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn37@2020_5/2020/09/06/02-59-58-122_8c158572d3b41037.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f4fb941e6ff30001d4e69ee?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn62@2020_5/2020/09/06/02-59-57-191_387835dfa4b98520.webp","https://i.insider.com/5ebc1d66578532025d11d9a5?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn13@2020_5/2020/09/06/02-59-57-639_df739d071e3a5da2.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f4fc2247ed0ee001e25d031?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn80@2020_5/2020/09/06/02-59-53-501_df256e41e98b5f9b.webp","https://i.insider.com/5ebb322b48d92c2a17674f43?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn61@2020_5/2020/09/06/02-59-55-546_55d6c4b62c0518ef.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f4fc2c0e6ff30001d4e6a2e?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn87@2020_2/2020/09/06/02-59-51-795_e289296617d260c8.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn78@2020_1/2020/09/06/02-59-58-308_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=qYM8AQrx8ic:stYvvDWmAlM:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn81@2020_4/2020/09/06/02-59-55-555_12d5b184ff8e2003.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=qYM8AQrx8ic:stYvvDWmAlM:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn54@2020_1/2020/09/06/03-00-01-787_ce041ba8da934ecc.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn60@2020_6/2020/09/06/02-59-52-353_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=qYM8AQrx8ic:stYvvDWmAlM:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn15@2020_6/2020/09/06/02-59-52-196_eceb681368cb52ec.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/qYM8AQrx8ic":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn52@2020_3/2020/09/06/02-59-52-218_e3d4d2b6bfe270f9.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1599361164661},{"createdTime":"2020-09-06 10:59:24","updatedTime":"2020-09-06 10:59:24","title":"Meet the 'K-shaped' recession, where professional workers are largely fine and everyone else is doing awful","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/what-is-a-k-shaped-recovery-coronavirus-pandemic","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f52b35c7ed0ee001e25daf0?format=jpeg\" alt=\"New york closed restaurant\" height=\"3840\" width=\"5119\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>A closed sign in a restaurant during the coronavirus pandemic in New York on April 16, 2020.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Michael Nagle/Xinhua/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Joe Biden said in a speech Friday that he blames Trump's failed leadership for allowing for a \"K-shaped\" economic recovery, where high earners are faring better than low-wage workers during the recession.&#160;</li>\n<li>Industries like technology, retail, and software services have largely recovered and begun rehiring, while travel, entertainment, hospitality, and food services have continued to decline past March levels.</li>\n<li>The result is that low-wage jobs like restaurant staff, transportation workers, and cleaners are <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/most-jobs-destroyed-by-the-pandemic-have-been-low-wage-2020-8\">least likely to come back</a>.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>Since it became obvious the coronavirus pandemic would create a recession, economists have debated the \"shape\" of it, with big implications for the future of the economy. Would it be a \"V\" shape, with a rapid recovery, a \"U\" shape, with a softer recovery, or the dreaded \"L\" shape, with no recovery at all?</p><p>Joe Biden weighed in on the matter in a speech on Friday, blaming President Trump for creating an unusual \"K shape.\" He said many Americans thought the country would bounce back economically within months of March's record job losses, but Trump's leadership botched that recovery.&#160;</p><p>\"As a result, economists are starting to call this recession a K-shaped recession, which is a fancy phrase for everything that's wrong with Trump's presidency,\" Biden said. \"What 'K' means is those at the top are seeing things go up, and those are the middle and below are seeing things go down and get worse.\"</p><p>The economists and pundits Biden referred to have surmised the economic recovery is taking the shape of a \"K\" — allowing for those at the top to prosper while sending working class Americans into further debt.&#160;</p><p>Here's what the \"K-shaped\" recovery means, and how that impacts jobs and economic inequality.&#160;</p><h2>What is a 'K' shaped recovery?</h2><p>The US entered a <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/us-recession-economy-february-coronavirus-nber-official-data-2020-6\">recession in February</a>, per the National Bureau of Economic Research, ending a record 128-month economic expansion.&#160;</p><p>Economists and analysts use letters like \"V\", \"L\", and \"I\" to describe their projections for the length of the recession and potential recovery, <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/recession-recovery-coronavirus-alphabet-letter-shape-project-economic-when-analysts-2020-3-1029042463#\">Business Insider's Ben Winck reported</a>.</p><p>A \"V-shaped\" recovery, for instance, is the most optimistic, as it suggests economic spending and employment will rapidly decline, but quickly pick back up like a \"V.\" A \"U\" shape is similar but suggest the period of unemployment and low economic activity will remain longer than a \"V\" recovery.&#160;</p><p><a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/recession-recovery-coronavirus-alphabet-letter-shape-project-economic-when-analysts-2020-3-1029042463#\">\"L\" and \"I\"</a>-shaped recovery outlooks are much more dire, suggesting the high unemployment and low spending will have other ramifications, like cause debt defaults and overwhelm health systems.</p><p>A \"K-shaped\" recovery is somewhere between a \"V\" and \"L\" — depending on who you are. Industries like technology, retail, and software services have recovered from the industry and begun re-hiring, while the travel, entertainment, hospitality, and food services industries have continued to decline past March levels.</p><p>\"The pandemic's uneven economic impact on industries and workers has been stark,\" US Chamber of Commerce president Suzanne Clark wrote in a blog post on Thursday, called \"Enter the K-Shaped Recovery.\"</p><h2>What does a 'K' shaped recovery mean for jobs?</h2><p>In March, following the rapid spread of the coronavirus that prompted officials to shut down businesses and schools, the US <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/labor-market-charts-show-bad-march-jobs-report-coronavirus-outlook-2020-4#based-on-the-monthly-survey-of-employers-the-number-of-jobs-in-the-us-fell-by-701000-between-february-and-march-ending-a-113-month-streak-of-net-job-creation-5\">lost 701,000 non-farm jobs</a> and <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/us-weekly-jobless-claims-unemployment-filings-record-labor-market-coronavirus-2020-4\">nearly 10 million people</a> filed for jobless claims.&#160;</p><p>While the record job loss hit the travel and hospitality industries, some economists assumed the <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/economic-outlook-coronavirus-labor-market-unemployment-rapid-recovery-recession-experts-2020-4\">US would bounce back</a> once businesses reopened. The result would have resulted in a \"V-shaped\" recovery, where unemployment and spending drop sharply but pick back up in a short period of time.&#160;</p><p>But the US has yet to control the virus to the point of safe reopening. The country has the most cumulative infections at more than 6 million, and a resurgence of infections have been tied to <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/states-and-cities-slowing-pausing-coronavirus-reopening-plans-2020-6\">hasty restaurant and business reopening</a>.</p><p>The stagnated recovery has meant the restaurant and travel industries have continued to decline, as more and more chains and restaurants have gone <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/restaurant-chains-at-risk-of-bankruptcy-amid-pandemic-2020-8\">bankrupt</a>. While job growth has <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/job-openings-are-down-20-percent-high-wage-growth-lags-2020-9\">picked back up slowly</a>, the unemployment rate is still <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/august-jobs-report-nonfarm-payrolls-unemployment-rate-us-economy-recovery-2020-9\">8.4% nationally</a>.&#160;</p><p>Clark said the financial services sector has already recovered 94% of its pre-pandemic employment, while the leisure and entertainment industries have only brought back 74% of their former workers. The result is that low-wage jobs like restaurant staff, transportation workers, and cleaners are <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/most-jobs-destroyed-by-the-pandemic-have-been-low-wage-2020-8\">least likely to recover</a>.</p><p>\"It's no surprise at root of this is the fact that Trump has mismanaged the COVID crisis, and that's why it's a K-shaped pandemic,\" Joe Biden said Friday.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/what-is-a-k-shaped-recovery-coronavirus-pandemic'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a pictured on the left on September 4, 2020. UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson is pictured on the right on August 13, 2020.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Getty/Getty</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><br >\n<ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Sir Kim Darroch, the former British ambassador to the US, interviewed in The Times magazine this weekend, detailed the events surrounding his resignation in 2018.&#160;</li>\n<li>Darroch resigned after the leak of classified diplomatic cables in which he described President Trump as \"inept.\"&#160;</li>\n<li>In the interview, Darroch said that Johnson seemed \"fascinated\" by Trump, and \"intrigued\" by the president's use of language.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>Boris Johnson is \"fascinated\" by Donald Trump and \"intrigued\" by his use of language, according to the former British ambassador to the US.&#160;</p><p>Sir Kim Darroch resigned from his ambassadorship in 2018, after the embarrassing leak of diplomatic cables in which he described the American president as \"inept\" and \"deeply dysfunctional.\"&#160;</p><p>In an interview with <a href=\"https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/kim-darroch-donald-trump-boris-johnson-book-8fnzdhr28\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">The Times</a> on Saturday, Darroch detailed the events that led to his resignation and described how he had seen Trump and Johnson get on during the latter's trips to Washington, DC. <figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f539cf4e6ff30001d4e74c5?format=jpeg\" alt=\"GettyImages 931631410\" height=\"2178\" width=\"3299\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Sir Kim Darroch, the former British ambassador to the US, is pictured in March 2018.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://www.gettyimages.com/detail/news-photo/kim-darroch-the-united-kingdoms-ambassador-to-the-united-news-photo/931631410?adppopup=true\" target=\"_blank\">Niall Carson/PA Images via Getty Images</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>Trump viewed Johnson as a \"kindred spirit,\" while Johnson was \"fascinated\" by Trump's political techniques, Darroch said.&#160;</p><p>Johnson was \"intrigued by Trump's limited vocabulary, the simplicity of the messaging, the disdain for political correctness, the sometimes incendiary imagery, and the at best intermittent relationship with facts and the truth,\" Darroch said.&#160;</p><p>Trump and Johnson have often been compared to each other, and Darroch said say he saw similarities in the two leaders, using the words \"charm,\" \"charisma,\" and \"stardust\" to describe them.&#160;</p><p>When asked if Johnson had modeled himself in some way after his American counterpart, Darroch said: \"If you go back through the current prime minister's history, he's often said quite striking things. And he never apologizes. So, Boris might have done this anyway, but certainly, having watched Trump in action, he wouldn't have been put off.\"</p><p>Darroch also blamed Johnson in part for his resignation after the leak, saying that Johnson's refusal to defend him at a debate while he was vying for prime minister led to Darroch's decision to step down.</p><ul class=\"read-more-links\"><li>Read more:</li><li><a readerx5oss/cdn16@2020_5/2020/09/06/02-59-49-051_51a95cebf173a6fa.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f4e89f6e6ff30001d4e6669?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn72@2020_5/2020/09/06/02-59-45-609_ee9e9349a2081251.webp","https://i.insider.com/5ef630e1f0f41929aa604313?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn74@2020_2/2020/09/06/02-59-59-220_50532d03bf5af0b5.webp","https://i.insider.com/5ef62d801918242adc3f2c10?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn64@2020_4/2020/09/06/02-59-52-331_904cb77ee1ef3655.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn78@2020_1/2020/09/06/02-59-58-308_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=8p31Yf-CzxM:lbF_XgJXdtE:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn17@2020_5/2020/09/06/02-59-55-119_aadb5233d7720363.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=8p31Yf-CzxM:lbF_XgJXdtE:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn91@2020_6/2020/09/06/02-59-48-757_90e5072ec4b6c9f6.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn60@2020_6/2020/09/06/02-59-52-353_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=8p31Yf-CzxM:lbF_XgJXdtE:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn53@2020_1/2020/09/06/02-59-58-113_3fe388992dadd67b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/8p31Yf-CzxM":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn40@2020_2/2020/09/06/02-59-48-463_6a7395234d25ed40.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1599361164606},{"createdTime":"2020-09-06 10:59:24","updatedTime":"2020-09-06 10:59:24","title":"The rise of private members' clubs, reimagined by a virus","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/private-members-clubs-reimagined-by-virus-soho-house-zero-bond-2020-9","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f512cc77ed0ee001e25d501?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Copyright Soho Works Water Street Loft 202002 JI LR 001\" height=\"1591\" width=\"2121\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>SoHo Works members have access to work amenities like printers, phone booths, meeting rooms, and podcast equipment that they might not have at home.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Soho Works Water Street Loft</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>As people seek out safe, hygienic, and private places to work and socialize amid office closures and citywide shutdowns, private members&#8217; clubs stand to be a rare winner on the current hospitality scene.</li>\n<li>Chateau Marmont, the Andr&#233; Balazs-owned LA hotspot, is being transformed into a members-only hotel.</li>\n<li>Zero Bond, founded by hospitality magnate Scott Sartiano, is the latest private members&#8217; club on the New York scene, attracting celebrities and athletes.</li>\n<li>At members&#8217; clubs, staff know your name, you can leave belongings with peace of mind, and you&#8217;re always guaranteed a place to sit, unlike a restaurant or bar.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>&#160;</p><p>For centuries, private clubs have been attracting powerful businessmen and dignitaries — often exclusively males — for business and social purposes. Private clubs were extremely popular in London, which, in the late 19th century, had more than 400 clubs. In 20th century America, golf and country clubs, which often required a strict dress code, also gained popularity among upper-class individuals.</p><p>Today, many private members' clubs have chosen to abandon this old-fashioned model in favor of attracting young creatives and entrepreneurs. Gone are the hallmarks of old members' clubs, like strict dress codes and no workspaces. Those have given way to new members' clubs, which offer a stylish, contemporary space to work and network.</p><p>Nick Jones, founder of Soho House, was one of the first to do this with the opening of the club in London in 1995. As of 2020, Soho House operates more than 27 clubs worldwide, with locations slated to open in Tel Aviv, Rome, Paris, Nashville, Austin, Canouan, and another in London, in 2021 and 2022.&#160;</p><p>Henry Wallmeyer, President and CEO of the National Club Association, whose members include 400 clubs like the prestigious Yale Club of New York City, New York Athletic Club and New York Yacht Club, said within the last five years clubs have become a \"third place.\"&#160;</p><p>\"Everybody's first place is their home, second is work and the third place is their personal refuge,\" he told Business Insider.</p><h2><strong>A hospitality magnate makes a pivot into private members' clubs</strong></h2><p>Scott Sartiano is a hospitality magnate and the founder of some of the world's hottest nightclubs, including New York City's 1Oak, favored by celebrities like Drake and Paris Hilton, and Up &#38; Down. This month, he's slated to open his first-ever private members' club, Zero Bond.</p><p>Located at 0 Bond Street in Manhattan's NoHo neighborhood, Zero Bond is a work and social club for individuals in the art, entertainment, media, fashion, and literary industries.</p><p>\"I wanted to create an elevated environment,\" Sartiano told Business Insider of the decision to open the members' club. \"I thought the 28- to 50 year-old bracket was kind of underrepresented in New York when it came to social options. People want to know who they're associating with, but also want their own space and more control over their experiences.\"</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f512c12e6ff30001d4e6e8f?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Zero Bond\" height=\"607\" width=\"1387\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>A rendering of Zero Bond&#39;s communal space.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Zero Bond</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>Membership fees are $3,000 annually, with a $500 initiation fee. And while it's not the most expensive members' club in the city, it's also not easy to get in: Those who apply are required to have a reference by a current member. It has a roster of high-profile celebrities, athletes, and designers on board as founding members, including Kim and Kourtney Kardashian, Liev Schreiber, Tom Brady, Zac Posen, and Caroline Wozniacki.</p><p>\"There's no one type of person that Zero Bond is looking for,\" Sartiono said. \"I want a mixture and diversity. That's New York City. When you go out in New York and meet someone you wouldn't have ordinarily met, that's the makings of a great night.\"</p><p>\"My goal is to create the safest place in New York to work and socialize,\" Sartiano said of Zero Bond. He's implemented technology to automatically take the temperature of anyone who walks through the door. Staff's temperature will be taken hourly and upon entry. There will also be dividers and separators to ensure social distancing.&#160;</p><p>The 20,000-square-foot, high-ceilinged space spans two floors with several lounge areas, two restaurants, five private rooms, and a bar. Design aficionados will love Zero Bond's contemporary aesthetic, designed by William Sofield and Studio Sofield, which designed store interiors for Gucci and Tom Ford. The building, built in 1874, retains much of its original structure, including red-brick archways and large windows.&#160;</p><p>The building was formerly the second-ever Brooks Brothers store and factory; in a nod to the building's past, the staff will wear custom-designed Brooks Brothers uniforms. Zero Bond will also hang artwork by Andy Warhol, Roy Lichtenstein, Robert Mapplethorpe, and Keith Haring, whose former studio was next door.</p><p>\"I'm trying to tie things back into the neighborhood,\" Sartiano said.</p><h2><strong>The office landscape is shifting, and private clubs serve as remote workspaces</strong></h2><p>As the pandemic swept the US, companies across the country shut their offices and instructed employees to work from home. But even during the pandemic, it's not uncommon to see a sea of laptops at a given Soho House during the day. In an effort to give members a more dedicated workspace, the company launched its first shared workspace for creatives, Soho Works, in London in 2015.</p><p>Its first New York City outpost opened earlier this year, and a Los Angeles location is slated to open later this year. Existing Soho House members and non-member creatives alike can apply for a membership. Members have access to work amenities like printers, phone booths, meeting rooms, and podcast equipment that they might not have at home.</p><p>Zero Bond will also be a place to work, complete with quiet areas and phone booths to take calls without disturbing members.</p><p>\"I want to create a place where people can come to work, have a meeting, have an after-work cocktail or come on a date,\" Sartiano said, adding that many members' clubs in New York often feel overcrowded. \"There's always going to be space for people, and they're always going to know your name and who you are,\" he said.</p><h2><strong>Private clubs are also finding new ways to engage with members</strong></h2><p>With the pandemic limiting in-person meetings, some private clubs are turning to digital programming to keep guests entertained and connected.<strong>&#160;</strong></p><p>Soho House, which is known — in pre-pandemic times — for programming that includes off-site trips and mixology classes, is finding new ways to engage with members. Since April, Soho House has hosted digital events, including speakers, musical performances, meditations, and virtual screenings via its app.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f512d8a7ed0ee001e25d508?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Copyright Soho Works Water Street Lounge 202002 JI LR 001\" height=\"1666\" width=\"2222\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>One of the lounges at Soho Works Water Street.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Soho Works Water Street Lounge</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>CORE: Club in New York City is another club implementing digital events for members to access remotely. The club opened its doors in New York City in 2005. It has 1,600 members and doesn't come cheap: Initial members' fees cost $50,000 and annual dues are $17,000.</p><p>CORE: Club Founder Jennie Enterprise told Business Insider that membership is \"highly curated,\" and they search for those seeking \"intellectual challenges.\" While privacy is of the utmost importance, members include leaders, entrepreneurs, and CEOs. What differentiates CORE: from other clubs is the wide range of industries from which they select members, including science and academia, hospitality and culinary, and sports and technology, among others.</p><p>COVID-19 inspired Enterprise to launch CORE: Connects, a digital platform featuring cultural programming. Sessions are recorded, uploaded to the website, and made available for members only. One speaker series, called Minds &#38; Mavericks, includes sessions by former Google CEO Eric Schmidt and Abigail Disney, documentary filmmaker, philanthropist and social activist. CORE: is slated to open its second location in Milan in 2021.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f513a69e6ff30001d4e6ee0?format=jpeg\" alt=\"CORE: Club Terrace\" height=\"922\" width=\"1229\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>A terrace on CORE: Club.\n<p class=\"copyright\">CORE: Club</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><h2><strong>A public hotel turned private members'-owned hotel</strong></h2><p>Hotels, too, are pivoting to a private membership model. Chateau Marmont, the historic Los Angeles hotel,&#160; first opened in 1927 and was bought by André Balazs Properties in 1990. It's known for glamorous parties that attract actors, writers, musicians, and artists. This summer, Balazs <a href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/hotelier-to-the-stars-plans-to-make-some-properties-private-clubs-11595928601\">announced</a> his plans to rebrand it as a members'-owned hotel, meaning members will own a piece of real estate at the hotel.</p><p>This decision stemmed from the fact that 70% of guests were repeat customers and the top 100 guests generated the majority of the room revenue. In addition to the investment, owners will be able to leave personal belongings, stay for extended periods of time, and have access to private dining areas.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f513bb6e6ff30001d4e6ef3?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Chateau Marmont\" height=\"1666\" width=\"2222\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Chateau Marmont is known for glamorous parties that attract actors, writers, musicians, and artists.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Chateau Marmont</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>Only one restaurant and a few common areas will be available for public access. When owners aren't staying there, the hotel will only accept guests personally recommended by owners.</p><p>\"What's been amazingly surprising, but good, is how quickly clubs turn[ed] on a dime once COVID-19 hit,\" Wallmeyer of the National Club Association said. \"Historically, clubs have been notoriously slow in changing. A lot of it is because some are 100 years old.\"</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a Reynolds)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f512cc77ed0ee001e25d501?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn76@2020_2/2020/09/06/02-59-48-749_1998a020259bc7e4.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f512c12e6ff30001d4e6e8f?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn87@2020_3/2020/09/06/02-59-48-756_091d55f576d2c7ad.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f512d8a7ed0ee001e25d508?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn74@2020_4/2020/09/06/03-00-00-056_b31684cc1ffc063f.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f513a69e6ff30001d4e6ee0?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn97@2020_1/2020/09/06/02-59-58-578_81dffe46953b86f5.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f513bb6e6ff30001d4e6ef3?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn86@2020_4/2020/09/06/02-59-55-618_b4fd75749a6925d3.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn78@2020_1/2020/09/06/02-59-58-308_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=gbaPAH2-FQ4:w2TsSwk6mTg:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn57@2020_1/2020/09/06/02-59-58-158_f2dc64269060b53b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=gbaPAH2-FQ4:w2TsSwk6mTg:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn28@2020_5/2020/09/06/02-59-53-887_3b036ef27a7582b5.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn60@2020_6/2020/09/06/02-59-52-353_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=gbaPAH2-FQ4:w2TsSwk6mTg:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn30@2020_1/2020/09/06/02-59-57-823_02c8f5f7ebb12d7f.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/gbaPAH2-FQ4":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn60@2020_6/2020/09/06/02-59-53-305_6bd6d4696c3136ed.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1599361164629},{"createdTime":"2020-09-06 10:59:24","updatedTime":"2020-09-06 10:59:24","title":"Only 3% of all US financial regulators over the past 90 years have been Black Americans, study finds","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/black-americans-under-represented-us-financial-regulatory-agencies-brookings-institution-2020-9","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5eaae5ca5f726e65b6375784?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Federal Reserve\" height=\"1333\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>A person walks by the Federal Reserve on Saturday, April 25, 2020.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Caroline Brehman/CQ-Roll Call/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Just 10 out of 327 people who've been appointed to financial regulatory agencies in the US have been Black Americans, a study from the Brookings Institution found.</li>\n<li>There has yet to be a single Black comissioner at the Securities and Exchange Comission or the Commodities Futures Trading Commission, for example.</li>\n<li>The study concludes that Black Americans only entail 11% of new directors serving on the boards of S&#38;P 500 corporations.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>&#160;</p><p>As Black Americans push for change and more diversity in corporate America, it turns out that they're underrepresented among the leadership ranks of financial regulatory agencies in a big way.</p><p>Just 10 out of 327 people who've been appointed to US financial regulatory agencies, or 3% of all financial regulators, have been Black Americans over the past 90 years, a research paper <a href=\"https://www.brookings.edu/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/ES-09.02.20-Brummer.pdf\">released on Wednesday</a> by the Brookings Institution said.&#160;</p><p>This includes federal financial regulatory agencies such as the Federal Reserve, the Securities and Exchange Commission as well as the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation.</p><p>Though Black Americans make up 13.4% of the population, there have only been 141 Black members of Congress dating back to 1900, with 98 of them being voted into office over the past two decades. In comparison, according to the study, 140 Black American judges serve across all levels of U.S. federal courts.</p><p>The paper showed that there has yet to be a single Black commissioner at the SEC or the Commodities Futures Trading Commission, for example. The paper's author also pointed out that there has never been a Black chairman at the FDIC, SEC or the CFTC.</p><p>\"This in effect means that African Americans have been, for the most part, shut out in any given year from representation on any given financial regulatory body,\" <a href=\"https://www.brookings.edu/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/ES-09.02.20-Brummer.pdf\">said</a> Chris Brummer, the paper's author and faculty director at Georgetown University's Institute of International Economic Law. \"The consequence is that African Americans have had little, and usually no direct say in the very shape and operation of finance, the lifeblood of capitalism and the U.S. economy.\"</p><p>One policy that Brummer refers to as an example of Black Americans largely missing out on having an equal voice in corporate America is the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act enacted in July 2010. As the study concludes, Black Americans only entail 11% of new directors serving on the boards of S&#38;P 500 corporations.</p><p>Brummer added that the lack of diversity in financial regulation isn't necessarily a partisan problem, indicating that both Democrats and Republicans haven't done the best job at attracting diverse talent given the fact that neither party in the US Senate \"has sponsored an African American appointment in the absence of Executive political action since the first term of the Reagan administration.\"</p><p>The paper's publication comes after Jacob Blake, a 29 year-old Black man, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/video-shows-police-wisconsin-shoot-black-man-back-2020-8\">was shot 7 seven times</a> by police in Wisconsin, leaving him with <a href=\"https://www.insider.com/picture-details-jacob-blake-black-man-shot-by-police-kenosha-2020-8\">serious injuries,</a> sparking further <a href=\"https://www.cnn.com/2020/09/02/us/kenosha-curfew-lawsuit-protests-jacob-blake/index.html\">civil unrest</a> and protests across the US.&#160;</p><p>Gbenga Ajilore, a senior economist at Center for American Progress in Washington, D.C., <a href=\"https://twitter.com/gbenga_ajilore/status/1301862619796701184\">tweeted</a> on Friday that the Black-White unemployment ratio increased in August to a record-high since the coronavirus pandemic began.&#160;</p><p>Also on Friday, the <a href=\"https://www.bls.gov/news.release/empsit.nr0.htm\">Bureau of Labor Statistics</a> reported that the US economy <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/august-jobs-report-nonfarm-payrolls-unemployment-rate-us-economy-recovery-2020-9\">added</a> 1.37 million jobs in August, the fourth consecutive month of gains. Additionally, the US unemployment rate <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/august-jobs-report-nonfarm-payrolls-unemployment-rate-us-economy-recovery-2020-9\">declined</a> to 8.4% in August after reaching an historic high 14.7% back in April.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/black-americans-under-represented-us-financial-regulatory-agencies-brookings-institution-2020-9'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a
