border=\"0\"></img></a>\n</div><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/j6IHI0_YSNw\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sat, 05 Sep 2020 12:33:00 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5f5292367ed0ee001e25da36?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"993552f826d610e30094c18a3281c659","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn12@2020_3/2020/09/06/02-59-58-438_1660d2f2c30e4320.webp","destWidth":1778,"destHeight":1333,"sourceBytes":245546,"destBytes":245546,"author":"esully@businessinsider.com (Evan Sully)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5eaae5ca5f726e65b6375784?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn26@2020_3/2020/09/06/03-00-00-570_3b3c76219da2a94b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn78@2020_1/2020/09/06/02-59-58-308_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=j6IHI0_YSNw:dndyTGfEmto:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn24@2020_3/2020/09/06/02-59-48-435_6fb07262ab9df20d.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=j6IHI0_YSNw:dndyTGfEmto:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn40@2020_6/2020/09/06/02-59-45-391_aed84c59d12fc743.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn60@2020_6/2020/09/06/02-59-52-353_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=j6IHI0_YSNw:dndyTGfEmto:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn73@2020_2/2020/09/06/03-00-01-073_c13efeee4bf2bf43.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/j6IHI0_YSNw":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn46@2020_5/2020/09/06/02-59-55-067_98be9053f6a053f7.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1599361164654},{"createdTime":"2020-09-06 10:59:24","updatedTime":"2020-09-06 10:59:24","title":"A Wall Street strategist that nailed last week's sell-off says the only path to a 'sharply higher' stock market is a dot-com-like bubble","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/stock-market-outlook-analysis-bubble-send-sharply-higher-selloff-dotcom-2020-9","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f528110e6ff30001d4e732a?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Trader Peter Tuchman works on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange Monday, March 16, 2020. (AP Photo/Craig Ruttle)\" height=\"1800\" width=\"3600\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Associated Press</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul><li><strong>The ongoing technology-driven stock market rally is on the verge of rivaling market bubbles not seen since the dot-com era and the Great Depression, according to Stifel's Barry Bannister.</strong></li><li><strong>The only way stocks can move \"sharply higher\" from current levels is if a bubble is formed, fueled by near-zero interest rates and a falling equity risk premium, Stifel said.</strong></li><li><strong>Bannister nailed last week's market sell-off, <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/stock-market-outlook-fed-bubble-stocks-overvalued-stifel-tech-growth-2020-8-1029497134#\">having called the market 5% to 10% overvalued just last month.</a></strong></li><li><strong><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingestgest\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</strong></li></ul><hr><p>Investors still have a lot to learn from the Nifty Fifty stock market bubble of 1972 and the dot-com-era bubble of 2000, according to Stifel's Barry Bannister.</p><p>In a recent note to clients, the head of institutional equity strategy said the current technology-driven stock market is showing similarities to previous market bubbles, and is even rivaling past melt-ups based on the cyclically adjusted price-earnings ratio, or CAPE.</p><p>\"The current market level is pivotal,\" Bannister said, explaining that, \"the CAPE of the S&#38;P 500 is knocking at the doorstep of the same point at which CAPE broke out in the last two years of the most powerful bull markets of the past century, the late 1920s and late 1990s.\"</p><p>If the widely followed CAPE ratio does break above the 30.0x level and decisively move higher, \"the building and bursting of a bubble\" could occur, according to the note.</p><p><strong data-stringify-type=\"bold\"><em data-stringify-type=\"italic\">Read more:</em></strong><em data-stringify-type=\"italic\"> <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/stock-market-crash-expert-says-hypervalued-market-set-to-plunge-2020-9\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">'Never been so extreme': A renowned stock bear says today's 'hypervalued' market implies the worst market returns in history — and expects a 66% crash from today's levels</a></em></p><p>\"The only path we see to a sharply higher market is a bubble like the end-stage of the 1920s and the 1990s bull markets,\" the note said.</p><p>Fueling a continued rally in stocks would be near-zero interest rates and a falling equity risk premium. In other words, the monetary policies from the Fed will likely be the determining factor of how long the stock market rally can last.</p><p>According to Bannister, the S&#38;P 500 could soar if Powell is able to avoid the Bernanke taper tantrum of 2013 and suppress the real 10-year Treasury yield. In this scenario, the S&#38;P 500 could jump 10% from current levels to 3,700, Stifel said.</p><p><em><strong>Read more:</strong> <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/stock-market-trading-rules-blueprint-from-market-legend-marty-schwartz-2020-9\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">'I had run $5,000 up to $140,000 in just 2 years': Here are the 7 trading rules stock-market wizard Marty Schwartz leverages to help ensure success</a></em></p><p>Additionally, there is a \"mega-bull case\" for stocks, depending on how low the real 10-year Treasury yield can fall, Bannister said. The real 10-year Treasury yield is the current interest rate of the 10-year Treasury less the current rate of inflation.</p><p>Still, market valuations are \"precariously high\" and investors should note that the decade following the dot-com&#160; bubble led to underperforming tech stocks relative to the S&#38;P 500 despite faster earnings growth, the note said.</p><p>Investors should take note of Bannister's call. The Wall Street strategist wasn't surprised by this week's tech-driven market sell-off given his note last month <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/stock-market-outlook-fed-bubble-stocks-overvalued-stifel-tech-growth-2020-8-1029497134#\">called for a 5% to 10% market correction</a>.</p><p><em><strong>Read more:</strong> <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/us-investing-championship-strategy-matthew-caruso-contender-secret-to-return-2020-8\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">US Investing Championship hopeful Matthew Caruso landed a 382% return in the first half of 2020. He shares the unique twist he's putting on a classic trading strategy — and 3 stocks he's holding right now.</a></em></p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f5290077ed0ee001e25da27?format=jpeg\" alt=\"stifel note 12.JPG\" height=\"678\" width=\"1139\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Stifel Research</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a Fox)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f528110e6ff30001d4e732a?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn63@2020_5/2020/09/06/02-59-46-742_f0e1bada08e48e55.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f5290077ed0ee001e25da27?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn76@2020_6/2020/09/06/02-59-49-655_cb86ede95d563815.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn78@2020_1/2020/09/06/02-59-58-308_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=uWODBUcKDwo:Z4qp98wko1Q:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn5@2020_5/2020/09/06/02-59-59-581_b6a8a1dc22fb76a9.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=uWODBUcKDwo:Z4qp98wko1Q:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn34@2020_1/2020/09/06/02-59-54-247_18e90568d9a0e5c5.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn60@2020_6/2020/09/06/02-59-52-353_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=uWODBUcKDwo:Z4qp98wko1Q:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn22@2020_5/2020/09/06/02-59-57-932_c55a78e64233f0d1.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/uWODBUcKDwo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn65@2020_3/2020/09/06/02-59-59-815_6e5e005c76945cda.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1599361164630},{"createdTime":"2020-09-06 10:59:24","updatedTime":"2020-09-06 10:59:24","title":"Kanye West claims he's worth $5 billion in new interview after striking 10-year Gap deal","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/kanye-west-claims-net-worth-5-billion-gap-yeezy-deal-2020-9","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f2ffdbdde1e965c1e7b8246?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Kanye West\" height=\"1014\" width=\"1200\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Jared Siskin/Patrick McMullan via Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Kanye West now says his net worth is $5 billion, up from $3.3 billion, after inking a decade-long Yeezy deal with Gap.</li>\n<li>Forbes last estimated his net worth to be $1.3 billion, though the publication noted West had shown them financial documents claiming it was over $3 billion, but it has yet to revise its estimate following the Yeezy-Gap deal.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>Kanye West says his deal with Gap nearly doubled his net worth.</p><p>West made the claim on a September 1 episode of '<a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KzgsxJt_KSI\">Cannon's Class</a>,' telling podcast host Nick Cannon that his net worth is now $5 billion.</p><p>\"So look, this year it was simple,\" said West. \"I was on the Bloomberg list... [and] they finally recognized that my net worth at that time was $3.3 billion. And then my net worth almost doubled after I did <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/kanye-west-teases-new-yeezy-collection-with-gap-on-twitter-2020-7\">the Gap deal</a> to $5 billion.\"</p><p>West was <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/is-kanye-west-finally-a-billionaire-forbes-says-yes-2020-4\">absent from the Forbes Billionaires 2020</a> list earlier this year, but the publication has since estimated his net worth <a href=\"https://www.forbes.com/sites/zackomalleygreenburg/2020/04/24/kanye-west-is-now-officially-a-billionaireand-he-really-wants-the-world-to-know/#cc0bfac7b9ec\">to be $1.3 billion</a>, though the publication noted West showed them financial documents claiming he was worth $3 billion.</p><p>Early in the conversation, West said he had been \"intentionally snuffed\" from the Forbes Billionaires list in the past because he didn't become a billionaire in a traditional way. West has also claimed that Forbes will not include him on the list due to his skin color, a claim he has <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/is-kanye-west-finally-a-billionaire-forbes-says-yes-2020-4\">made in the past.</a> A Forbes spokesperson was not immediately available to comment on West's statements.</p><p>Neither Forbes nor Bloomberg appear to have updated their net worth estimates of West yet to reflect the impact of the <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/kanye-west-worked-at-gap-store-as-a-teen-2020-6\">10-year Gap deal</a> on his net worth.</p><p>Business Insider has reached out to West's representatives for further clarification and details regarding the $5 billion claim.</p><p>Although West is best known for his music, most of his wealth comes from his Yeezy brand, which he has sole ownership of.&#160;</p><p>The Gap deal marks a new beginning for the retailer, which has struggled in recent years. When the deal was announced, Gap's stock <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/gap-stock-surges-10-year-apparel-deal-kanye-west-yeezy-2020-6-1029346081#\">rose by 42%</a>, adding more than $1 billion to its market cap. Since the announcement of the partnership, West has dropped some hints on his Twitter account about the new fashion line.</p><blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet blockquote\" data-lang=\"en\" data-cards=\"\" data-conversation=\"\">&#8212;ye  (@kanyewest) <a href=\"https://twitter.com/mims/statuses/1294485221711126533?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">August 15, 2020</a></blockquote><script async src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"></script><p>&#160;</p><p>West and Cannon covered other topics in the 45-minute interview, including West's 'Sunday Service' series, mental health, and architecture.</p><p>This is the first high-profile interview for the podcast series since Cannon made some controversial statements last month.&#160;</p><p>In a July episode of the podcast, Cannon said that Black people are \"the true Hebrews\" during an interview with rapper and spoken word artist Richard Griffin. The statements led to Cannon being accused of being anti-Semitic, and he was dropped from his longtime deal with ViacomCBS.</p><p>You can watch the full interview between West and Cannon below.</p><iframe width=\"560\" height=\"315\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/KzgsxJt_KSI\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen></iframe><p>&#160;</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original 2020 11:55:00 10:59:24","updatedTime":"2020-09-06 10:59:24","title":"Sarah Huckabee Sanders called one of her former White House colleagues a 'liberal, aggressive, foulmouthed Jew from New York City'","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/sarah-sanders-describes-former-wh-colleague-as-a-foulmouthed-jew-2020-9","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f5374537ed0ee001e25db53?format=jpeg\" alt=\"sarah huckabee sanders\" height=\"938\" width=\"1876\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>White House Press Secretary Sarah Huckabee Sanders speaks during a press briefing at the White House in Washington, DC, March 11, 2019.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://www.gettyimages.com/detail/news-photo/white-house-press-secretary-sarah-huckabee-sanders-speaks-news-photo/1129888440?adppopup=true\" target=\"_blank\">SAUL LOEB/AFP via Getty</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Sarah Huckabee Sanders, the former White House press secretary, describes one of her former colleagues as a \"foulmouthed Jew\" in her new memoir.&#160;</li>\n<li>Josh Raffel was brought on to the White House communications team by Jared Kushner and Ivanka Trump, and Sanders describes him as \"liberal.\"&#160;</li>\n<li>Sanders said she and Raffel eventually became close friends during their time working together. Raffel left the White House in 2018.&#160;</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>Former White House Press Secretary Sarah Huckabee Sanders describes one of her former colleagues as a \"foulmouthed Jew\" in her new memoir.&#160;</p><p>In \"Speaking for Myself: Faith Freedom, and the Fight of Our Lives Inside the Trump White House,\" Sanders describes former White House communications team colleague Josh Raffel as \"a liberal, aggressive, foulmouthed Jew from New York City,\" according to <a href=\"https://jewishinsider.com/2020/09/former-white-house-spokesperson-huckabee-sanders-calls-former-colleague-a-foulmouthed-jew-in-upcoming-memoir/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Jewish Insider</a>, which obtained a preview copy of the book.&#160;</p><p>Despite being \"pretty much his total opposite,\" Sanders, born in Hope, Arkansas, says she grew to love Raffel during their time working together.</p><p>\"He is one of the funniest people I know, intensely loyal, and probably the most talented communications strategist I've ever worked with,\" Sanders writes. \"Nobody in the White House could work a story better than Josh, and he was always one of the first colleagues I turned to for help on the toughest assignments.\"&#160;</p><p>During his time working at the White House, Raffel was the spokesperson for Jared Kushner and Ivanka Trump. He left the White House in 2018, returning to his work as a senior vice president of Hiltzik Strategies and head of marketing and communications at Blumhouse Productions.&#160;</p><p>Jewish Insider reached out to Raffel about Sanders' book, and he described her as a \"close friend.\"&#160;</p><p>In another chapter of the book, President Trump told Sanders to go to North Korea and take \"one for the team\" after Kim Jong Un appeared to wink at her, she said in a new memoir, <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2020/sep/01/donald-trump-sarah-sanders-take-one-for-the-team-kim-jong-un-wink-book\" data-analytics-module=\"summary_bullets\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"0\" data-uri=\"ab8ec637001af2ce2ad11eb53cb75dd4\">according to The Guardian</a>.</p><p>Sanders said that during a summit between Trump and Kim in Singapore in 2018, \"Kim nodded and appeared to wink at me.\"</p><p>\"Well, Sarah, that settles it. You're going to North Korea and taking one for the team!\" Trump told her, Sanders said. \"Your husband and kids will miss you, but you'll be a hero to your country!\"</p><p>Sanders served as White House Press Secretary under President Trump from 2017 to 2019.&#160;</p><p>&#160;</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a border=\"0\"></img></a>\n</div><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/-3Za5ruUDak\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sat, 05 Sep 2020 13:21:08 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5f53745d7ed0ee001e25db54?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"676c753b767040bd7b8cb93f1e8dc838","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn24@2020_6/2020/09/06/02-59-45-305_3634403ceff8cd80.webp","destWidth":1415,"destHeight":1061,"sourceBytes":36588,"destBytes":36588,"author":"acollman@businessinsider.com (Ashley Collman)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f5374537ed0ee001e25db53?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn68@2020_4/2020/09/06/02-59-44-327_cff3010439711188.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn78@2020_1/2020/09/06/02-59-58-308_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=-3Za5ruUDak:6myxOCHu88w:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn76@2020_1/2020/09/06/02-59-46-661_cb4a375e58891b1a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=-3Za5ruUDak:6myxOCHu88w:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn92@2020_4/2020/09/06/02-59-51-801_625d6e3059d1ca41.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn60@2020_6/2020/09/06/02-59-52-353_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=-3Za5ruUDak:6myxOCHu88w:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn25@2020_5/2020/09/06/03-00-01-539_a67f267650846e33.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/-3Za5ruUDak":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn29@2020_4/2020/09/06/03-00-01-348_618d278a42fb5408.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1599361164662},{"createdTime":"2020-09-06 10:59:24","updatedTime":"2020-09-06 10:59:24","title":"Inside the story of Ben Hill: the fictional executive and hotline used by Home Depot's founders to listen to customer backlash","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/home-depot-ben-hill-arthur-blank-good-company-customer-service-2020-9","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5cb63cb7f7d2900beb19cdcd?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Arthur Blank Home Depot GrandOpening\" height=\"986\" width=\"1308\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>&#34;Our job is to make every single customer happy,&#34; Home Depot cofounder Arthur Blank told Business Insider.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Courtesy of The Home Depot</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Early Home Depot shoppers called Ben Hill, a fictional executive, in order to voice their grievances about negative store experiences.</li>\n<li>Cofounder Arthur Blank wrote in his book \"Good Company\" that merchandising expert Pat Farrah came up with the name after seeing it on a sign off I-285 in Georgia.</li>\n<li>Home Depot's cofounders would take the \"Ben Hill calls\" themselves, almost always taking the customer's side.</li>\n<li>\"We established Ben Hill because, at the end of the day, we wanted to make sure that the store manager really thought of the store as their store,\" Blank said.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>&#160;</p><p>When it comes to the founding of Home Depot, Arthur Blank and Bernie Marcus are credited with dreaming up the world's largest home-improvement business in existence today. Pat Farrah also offered valuable merchandising expertise while financier Ken Langone helped to bankroll the operation.</p><p>But there's another name from the early days of the company that Blank credits with some of Home Depot's success: Ben Hill. Hill Isn't a real person, but rather an invention of Farrah's designed to solicit customer feedback.</p><p>Blank recently <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/arthur-blank-home-depot-atlanta-falcons-good-company-book-2020-8\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"28012f888b8bf2b699738be60e859932\">spoke</a> with Business Insider about his new book \"Good Company,\" the creation of Ben Hill, and his stint handling negative customer calls for Home Depot. He spoke about how the fictitious figure played a roll in helping the founders foster customer-focused values within the company.&#160;</p><p>The Home Depot founders had always sought out consumer critiques, with Blank and Marcus donning orange aprons and <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/home-depot-cofounder-customer-service-2019-4\">chasing down</a> customers leaving their stores empty-handed. But at a certain point, Home Depot had opened so many stores that the method became untenable. So the founders took a new approach.</p><p>In \"Good Company,\" Blank wrote: \"In every store, we hung a sign that read, 'Are you satisfied? If not, call Ben Hill,' followed by a phone number.\"</p><p>Farrah had thought up the fictitious executive after seeing the name on an exit sign off I-285 in Georgia. The California native \"thought it sounded friendly.\" Ben Hill is both the name of a county in Georgia, as well as a neighborhood in Home Depot's hometown of Atlanta. Ben Hill was also the name of a Georgia politician during the 1800s elected to the Confederate States Congress, the US House of Representatives, and the US Senate.</p><p>According to Blank, Home Depot's switchboard operators were told to patch calls for Ben Hill through to the founders.</p><p>\"So for the first number of years, myself, or Bernie, or, Pat Farrah would end up taking all of those calls,\" he told Business Insider. \"You'd tell the customer, \"This is Arthur Blank, I cofounded the company. Can I help you?\"</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f4e9543e6ff30001d4e669b?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Home Depot opening\" height=\"902\" width=\"1203\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Courtesy of The Home Depot</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>The founders ended up getting an earful from irritated shoppers. But despite the often-tense nature of the calls, the lessons gleaned from those conversations could be valuable.</p><p>\"Bernie, Pat, and I genuinely wanted to hear from those disgruntled customers ourselves, because we knew that their complaints were worth more than the advice of any retail expert we could hire,\" he wrote.</p><p>Still, Blank told Business Insider that the issues themselves usually didn't make much a difference to the founders.&#160;</p><p>\"We never viewed ourselves as a judge trying to decide which side of the scale is right or wrong,\" he said. \"The customer's always going to be right.\"</p><p>While \"Ben Hill calls\" could sometimes pinpoint merchandising or installation issues, callers frustrations typically went back to customer service. Blank said that after getting off the phone with the disgruntled customers, he, Marcus, or Farrah would follow-up with store managers.&#160;</p><p>This resulted in talks that were often \"not the most pleasant in the world,\" according to Blank. He said that store managers came to fear \"Ben Hill calls.\" In the wake of such a call, managers would gather the entire store workforce to talk about the importance of customer service.</p><p>\"We established Ben Hill because, at the end of the day, we wanted to make sure that the store manager really thought of the store as their store,\" he said. \"Our job is to make every single customer happy. And that means if they're not happy after step one, you go to step two and you make them happy.\"</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/home-depot-ben-hill-arthur-blank-good-company-customer-service-2020-9'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a Though still quite pricey, this is the cheapest we've seen this model so far. src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f2c77b65fa9a43e646868d4?format=jpeg\" alt=\"FILE PHOTO: A model walks on an in-house catwalk at the ASOS headquarters in London April 1, 2014. REUTERS/Suzanne Plunkett/File Photo\" height=\"1491\" width=\"2982\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>FILE PHOTO: A model walks on an in-house catwalk at the ASOS headquarters in London\n<p class=\"copyright\">Reuters</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>The fashion industry has long been under fire for human rights abuses.</li>\n<li>But the COVID-19 crisis is shining a new light on those abuses.</li>\n<li>Without a system that allows consumers to hold companies accountable, the abuses will persist.</li>\n<li>Nicky is a writer and speaker who primarily covers arts and culture.</li>\n<li>This is an opinion column. The thoughts expressed are those of the author.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>The fashion industry has long been a focus of human rights campaigners. <a href=\"https://labs.theguardian.com/unicef-child-labour/\">Child labor</a>, p<a href=\"https://www.vox.com/2018/2/27/17016704/living-wage-clothing-factories\">overty wages</a>, and <a href=\"https://www.businessoffashion.com/articles/news-analysis/why-fashion-doesnt-pay-fair\">a lack of transparency</a> means that garment workers — especially in the global South — are consistently exploited.</p><p>The same goes with environmental concerns: <a href=\"https://www.weforum.org/agenda/2020/01/fashion-industry-carbon-unsustainable-environment-pollution/#:~:text=Fashion%20production%20makes%20up%2010,of%20plastic%20into%20the%20ocean\">the fashion industry is responsible for 10% of humanity's carbon emissions, 35% of all microplastics in the ocean, and 85% of all textiles produced annually end up in landfill</a>. With stats like those, it's clear that the fashion industry's reckoning has been a long time coming.</p><p>COVID-19 is that reckoning.</p><h2>Fashionably late</h2><p>In April, <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2020/apr/02/fashion-brands-cancellations-of-24bn-orders-catastrophic-for-bangladesh\">The Guardian</a> reported that major high street fashion brands, including Primark and Matalan, had cancelled or suspended orders for £2.4 billion worth of garments from factories in Bangladesh. Over 97% of suppliers surveyed by the WRC and Penn State University said that brands had offered \"no financial assistance\" to cover furlough or severance costs; the executive director of the WRC described the situation as a \"wholesale abandoning of workers and suppliers\" by brands.</p><p>Factory owners, who operate on low profit margins and lack access to cash reserves or credit, are <a href=\"https://labourbehindthelabel.org/covid-19-support-workers/\">unable to pay their workers</a> — who themselves aren't paid enough to accumulate the savings they would need to weather this pandemic. While brands scramble to minimize losses, factory owners and workers in Bangladesh are facing destitution.</p><p>Closer to home, the brands <a href=\"https://www.gmb.org.uk/news/asos-warehouse-suffers-suspected-coronavirus-outbreak\">ASOS</a> and <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/business/2020/jul/06/boohoo-leicester-factory-conditions-covid-19\">Boohoo</a> both made headlines for the unsanitary working conditions in their UK factories, leading directly to COVID-19 outbreaks in both locations. Boohoo in particular has been criticised for allegedly paying workers <a href=\"https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/boohoos-sweatshop-suppliers-they-only-exploit-us-they-make-huge-profits-and-pay-us-peanuts-lwj7d8fg2?wgu=270525_54264_15992424200592_a439613e96&wgexpiry=1607018420&utm_source=planit&utm_medium=affiliate&utm_content=22278tm_content=22278\">as little as £3.50 per hour</a> in a Leicester factory — less than half the UK legal minimum wage of £8.72 per hour. Although Boohoo has said the factory was run by a subcontractor and the bran dis investigating its supply chain, up until this point sales were booming and bosses were in line to make £150 million in bonuses.</p><p>ASOS, meanwhile, <a href=\"https://inews.co.uk/news/asos-boycott-online-drivers-redundant-coronavirus-outbreak-417087\">fired 70 workers</a> at the beginning of the outbreak when they switched delivery suppliers (from Menzies to DPD). The administrators and drivers were originally told that their contracts would be transferred, only for DPD to U-turn on its commitment and announce that they would be dismissed on May 1.</p><h2>A new light on abuse</h2><p>Whether in the UK or farther afield, the effects of COVID-19 on the fashion industry are unmistakable. As the crisis has developed, it has thrown into sharp relief many of the systemic issues in the industry — obscure supply chains, worker exploitation, and extreme waste, to name a few — but we're yet to find sustainable solutions to these problems.</p><p>Initiatives like Mallzee's Lost Stock have sprung up to plug the gap left by brands abandoning their suppliers. Consumers can purchase a bag of clothes from Lost Stock, tailored to their size and preferences, at £35 — a 50% discount from the estimated £70 retail price. <a href=\"https://loststock.com/\">Lost Stock's website</a> claims that each bag supports a Bangladeshi worker and their family for one week.</p><p>Although an innovative solution to the dual problem of supporting workers and reducing waste, initiatives like this speak to our neoliberal, late-capitalist era by putting the onus on the consumer to fix the deep-seated problems in the fashion industry. While brands continue to profit from the exploitation of their workers, the burden of \"doing the right thing\" and bailing out these workers falls on individuals — many of whom are themselves suffering from COVID-related redundancies and reduced hours.</p><p>In asking individuals to contribute to ending systemic issues, initiatives like this also require the public to make difficult personal choices about what matters to them, as they are asked to split what disposable income they have between different causes — BLM, local food banks, queer fundraisers, etc. The focus is on individual consumers to make ethical choices for the greater good, rather than holding brands to account.</p><p>Mallzee's program appeals to consumers' self-interest: it's undeniably positive that the garments won't go to waste, but the 50% discount incentive speaks to a world in which we are consumers first and foremost; where everything is transactional, and doing a good deed comes with a material reward. It's also worth noting that focusing on poverty and exploitation in other countries leads to western consumers buying into the lie that it \"doesn't happen here\", and doing a disservice to the vulnerable, precarious, and exploited workers in our home countries.</p><h2>Accountability</h2><p>In a time when we should be reflecting on our relationship to fast fashion and our place in a deeply consumer-oriented society, the response to COVID-19 seems to be a focus on increased consumption. Rather than addressing the <a href=\"https://inews.co.uk/news/asos-boycott-online-drivers-redundant-coronavirus-outbreak-417087\">#BoycottAsos campaign</a> which sprang up in response to ASOS' treatment of its workers, ASOS doubled down: in the week leading up to pubs reopening in England, <a href=\"https://twitter.com/ASOS/status/1277899298924003329\">ASOS offered discounts to UK shoppers to get ready for \"Super Saturday.\"</a> In doing so they encouraged the public to see themselves as consumers, capitalizing on the reopening of pubs and bars as an opportunity to push sales — even while public health advice remained clear on staying at home and avoiding unnecessary travel.</p><p>In all of these instances, making ethical choices becomes individual consumers' responsibility, when what we need is corporate and governmental accountability. The COVID-19 crisis has precisely illuminated everything wrong with fast fashion: cramped unsanitary working conditions, precarious and exploitative employment, an opaque supply chain which enables brands to abandon their laborers.</p><p>It's evident that real systemic change is needed, and that calling on consumers to behave \"ethically\" will not be enough. Without organised collective action and a system which enables us to hold brands to account, these issues will continue, even right under our noses.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original 10:59:24","updatedTime":"2020-09-06 10:59:24","title":"Seven states should be on alert for rising coronavirus cases over Labor Day weekend, Fauci says","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/seven-states-risk-coronavirus-surge-labor-day-weekend-fauci-warns-2020-9","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5efb67443ad8611bc2071228?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Fauci mask coronavirus testimony\" height=\"1667\" width=\"2500\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Dr. Anthony Fauci at a Senate Health, Education, Labor and Pensions Committee hearing on June 30, 2020 in Washington, DC.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Al Drago/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>The nation's top infectious disease specialist warned that seven states might see a surge in the number of positive coronavirus cases after the Labor Day weekend.</li>\n<li>\"There are several states that are at risk for surging, namely North Dakota, South Dakota, Iowa, Arkansas, Missouri, Indiana, Illinois,\" said Dr. Anthony Fauci, director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases.</li>\n<li>In the past, several states have reported surges in the number of confirmed coronavirus cases after a holiday weekend like <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/coronavirus-contact-tracer-cases-are-rising-after-memorial-day-2020-6\">Memorial Day</a> or the <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/florida-texas-coronavirus-cases-record-high-fourth-of-july-2020-7\">Fourth of July</a>.</li>\n</ul>\n<ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>Dr. Anthony Fauci delivered a grim warning ahead of the Labor Day weekend, saying that seven states should be on high alert for a potential spike in coronavirus cases.&#160;</p><p>\"There are several states that are at risk for surging, namely North Dakota, South Dakota, Iowa, Arkansas, Missouri, Indiana, Illinois,\" Fauci, the director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases and the leading White House coronavirus expert, told <a href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-09-03/fauci-warns-seven-midwest-states-to-be-on-alert-over-labor-day\">Bloomberg News</a>.</p><p>\"Those states are starting to see an increase in the percent positive of their testing; that is generally predictive that there's going to be a problem.\"</p><p>The warning comes after at least one of those states engaged in large-scale events in recent weeks.&#160;</p><p>South Dakota held a <a href=\"https://www.insider.com/minnesota-man-died-of-covid-19-after-sturgis-motorcycle-rally-2020-9\">10-day motorcycle festival last month</a>, a spectacle that drew more than 400,000 people and led to hundreds of positive cases nationwide connected to the event. Most attendees had not worn a mask and did not adhere to social distancing guidelines.&#160;</p><p>Multiple states have reported surges in the number of confirmed coronavirus cases after a holiday weekend like <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/coronavirus-contact-tracer-cases-are-rising-after-memorial-day-2020-6\">Memorial Day</a> or the <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/florida-texas-coronavirus-cases-record-high-fourth-of-july-2020-7\">Fourth of July</a>.</p><p>As many states enter the seventh month of mask-wearing and quarantine, the coronavirus continues to spread nationwide.&#160;</p><p>The disease has infected more than 6.2 million people in the United States, according to the latest data compiled by Johns Hopkins University. Of that figure, more than 187,000 people have died.&#160;</p><p>Anticipating a surge over the holiday weekend, the White House doubled down on the message to practice social distancing and wear masks.&#160;</p><p>On a phone call earlier this week, Fauci and Vice President Mike Pence asked governors to continue to enforce mask-wearing and social distancing, Bloomberg reported.&#160;</p><p>Following Fauci's warnings, President Donald Trump on Friday <a href=\"https://fox2now.com/news/national/pres-trump-to-hold-white-house-news-conference/\">urged people to \"remain vigilant\"</a> and \"apply common sense.\"&#160;</p><p>\"As we begin Labor Day weekend, America's unprecedented economic recovery continues,\" Trump said, speaking at a White House briefing.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/seven-states-risk-coronavirus-surge-labor-day-weekend-fauci-warns-2020-9'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=auV_MDlquwU:xvxrv4qkXGI:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sat, 05 Sep 2020 13:26:55 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5f5388cee6ff30001d4e74b5?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"c8a5ed26d8ca6b354e4d41c37a6b0797","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn84@2020_5/2020/09/06/02-59-50-644_9353f0a66aeb4b28.webp","destWidth":2222,"destHeight":1666,"sourceBytes":337968,"destBytes":337968,"author":"ydzhanova@businessinsider.com (Yelena Dzhanova)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5efb67443ad8611bc2071228?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn84@2020_5/2020/09/06/02-59-46-872_b2ec81361a5f9d8c.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn78@2020_1/2020/09/06/02-59-58-308_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=auV_MDlquwU:xvxrv4qkXGI:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn93@2020_1/2020/09/06/03-00-02-238_220c734b957fa689.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=auV_MDlquwU:xvxrv4qkXGI:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn56@2020_6/2020/09/06/02-59-46-615_5fdf52f56498f0c5.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn60@2020_6/2020/09/06/02-59-52-353_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=auV_MDlquwU:xvxrv4qkXGI:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn42@2020_5/2020/09/06/02-59-55-968_a24b5bbfc5ad7344.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/auV_MDlquwU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn63@2020_3/2020/09/06/02-59-44-220_9e4a248111dae6ca.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1599361164628},{"createdTime":"2020-09-06 10:59:24","updatedTime":"2020-09-06 10:59:24","title":"Google is building its own town near its Silicon Valley headquarters, complete with parks, restaurants, and affordable housing","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/google-mountain-view-new-campus-renderings-middlefield-park-2020-9","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f528c3fe6ff30001d4e7376?format=jpeg\" alt=\"google headquarters\" height=\"2067\" width=\"2757\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Google&#39;s Mountain View, California, headquarters.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Justin Sullivan/Getty</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Google submitted its proposal this month for a new campus near its headquarters in Mountain View, California.&#160;</li>\n<li>The new campus, called Middlefield Park, would span a 40-acre site and include public amenities like parks and sports field, retail space, restaurants, and affordable housing.&#160;</li>\n<li>Google wants the town-like campus to be walkable and bikeable, with all the amenities and services within a 10-minute walk for residents.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>Google hopes to build a new, town-like campus near its Silicon Valley headquarters.&#160;</p><p>The company this month unveiled its proposal for Middlefield Park, a revamped 40-acre site in the city of Mountain View, California, where Google's main headquarters is currently based. The plan includes a parks network, retail space, office space, and even a public pool and sports field.&#160;</p><p>The tech giant also plans to add as many as 1,850 residential units, and the company says 20% of those units will be affordable housing. The housing commitment follows <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/google-announces-1-billion-additional-investment-in-housing-across-bay-area-2019-6\">a $1 billion pledge Google made last year</a> to housing in the Bay Area, which included repurposing some its land holdings to create 15,000 new homes at varying income levels, including homes intended for lower- and middle-income families.&#160;</p><p>Google's new campus plans come at a time when the future of offices is uncertain. None of the major tech companies has sent employees back to work in the US amid the ongoing coronavirus outbreak, and Google's itself isn't requiring companies to return to work <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/google-employees-working-from-home-summer-2021-report-2020-7\">until July 2021</a>.&#160;</p><p>But Google isn't alone in reaffirming its commitment to physical offices. Last month, Amazon announced that it plans to <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/amazon-adds-jobs-new-office-hub-locations-2020-8\">expand its physical office space in six \"tech hubs\"</a> across the US, investing $1.4 billion to build out the offices and adding 3,500 jobs.&#160;</p><p>And Facebook in August <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/facebook-signs-730000-square-foot-office-lease-at-farley-building-2020-8\">signed a deal for a massive new office</a> in the Farley Building in New York City. The office space spans 730,000 square feet and Facebook said at the time it will be used to expand the company's engineering operations in New York.&#160;</p><p>While Google's plans are still in the very early stages, we got our first look at how the company is imagining its new campus. Take a look:&#160;</p>\n<div id=\"slideshow\">\n\tGoogle said in its master plan for the development that it aims to \"create a complete community\" where all of the amenities and services are within a 10-minute walk for residents.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f528bd07ed0ee001e25da05?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Google Middlefield Park\" height=\"843\" width=\"1500\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Google</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p><em>Source: <a href=\"https://www.mountainview.gov/depts/comdev/planning/activeprojects/google_middlefield_park.asp\">City of Mountain View</a></em></p>\n\tGoogle's plan includes 1.3 million square feet of office space, 30,000 square feet of space for restaurants, retail, or services, and 20,000 square feet for community facilities.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f528c00e6ff30001d4e7373?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Google Middlefield Park\" height=\"843\" width=\"1500\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Google</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p><em>Source: <a href=\"https://www.mountainview.gov/depts/comdev/planning/activeprojects/google_middlefield_park.asp\">City of Mountain View</a></em></p>\n\tGoogle's plan will create 12 acres of public space, including a park network of six separate parks. The company says the parks will have space for playgrounds, outdoor fitness, bike paths, a community pool, a sports field, and a dog park.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f528bf2e6ff30001d4e7372?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Google Middlefield Park\" height=\"843\" width=\"1500\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Google</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p><em>Source: <a href=\"https://www.mountainview.gov/depts/comdev/planning/activeprojects/google_middlefield_park.asp\">City of Mountain View</a></em></p>\n\tAccording to the Mountain View Voice, the Middlefield Park area currently has a significant amount of street parking that will be replaced by parks — the addition of 12 new parking garages makes that possible.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f528be47ed0ee001e25da06?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Google Middlefield Park\" height=\"843\" width=\"1500\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Google</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p><em>Source: <a href=\"https://mv-voice.com/news/2020/09/01/google-unveils-massive-mixed-use-housing-and-office-village-in-east-whisman\">Mountain View Voice</a></em></p>\n\tThe proposal is still in its very early stages, and many of the buildings that will be constructed haven't been designed yet, according to the Mountain View Voice, but none of the buildings will be taller than 12 stories due to a nearby airfield.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f528c0e7ed0ee001e25da09?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Google Middlefield Park\" height=\"843\" width=\"1500\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Google</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p><em>Source: <a href=\"https://mv-voice.com/news/2020/09/01/google-unveils-massive-mixed-use-housing-and-office-village-in-east-whisman\">Mountain View Voice</a></em></p>\n</div><div class=\"read-original\">Read the 2020 13:23:00 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5f52927de6ff30001d4e73a2?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"74e7f61ff6c474429fada1ab2b2491d4","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn63@2020_4/2020/09/06/02-59-46-978_c1d233455d2ec6d3.webp","destWidth":1019,"destHeight":764,"sourceBytes":172724,"destBytes":172724,"author":"ahartmans@businessinsider.com (Avery Hartmans)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f528c3fe6ff30001d4e7376?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn83@2020_5/2020/09/06/02-59-52-932_c99cdfec59ecdfa6.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f528bd07ed0ee001e25da05?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn4@2020_4/2020/09/06/02-59-50-027_0e9a2460670ccded.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f528c00e6ff30001d4e7373?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn93@2020_2/2020/09/06/02-59-58-477_7935d8e936728d8d.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f528bf2e6ff30001d4e7372?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn77@2020_1/2020/09/06/03-00-01-055_6068f0d1435946cf.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f528be47ed0ee001e25da06?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn70@2020_5/2020/09/06/02-59-55-390_18e435a894de068f.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f528c0e7ed0ee001e25da09?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn51@2020_5/2020/09/06/02-59-45-456_a3e710d0900ad403.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn78@2020_1/2020/09/06/02-59-58-308_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=wsoWKKRhH7o:Yn1KWszMcbs:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn73@2020_6/2020/09/06/02-59-55-364_7b68ad5d3b23c3db.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=wsoWKKRhH7o:Yn1KWszMcbs:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn99@2020_3/2020/09/06/02-59-49-768_91fb76a1ccbb7561.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn60@2020_6/2020/09/06/02-59-52-353_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=wsoWKKRhH7o:Yn1KWszMcbs:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn46@2020_2/2020/09/06/02-59-59-865_7228e90cbe4597db.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/wsoWKKRhH7o":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn47@2020_2/2020/09/06/02-59-48-531_f6973ed1810aeed8.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1599361164657},{"createdTime":"2020-09-06 10:59:24","updatedTime":"2020-09-06 10:59:24","title":"Inside the richest zip code in America, a private island off of Miami Beach","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/inside-richest-zip-code-in-america-fisher-island-miami-florida-2020-8","description":"<div style=\"position:relative; overflow:hidden; padding-bottom:56.25%\">\n<iframe src=\"https://cdn.jwplayer.com/players/xRcnX7Mj-jZbcmOYf.html\"\nwidth=\"100%\" height=\"100%\" frameborder=\"0\" scrolling=\"auto\" title=\"Inside the richest zip code in America, a private island off of Miami Beach\"\nstyle=\"position:absolute;\" allowfullscreen></iframe>\n</div><ul class=\"summary-list\"><li>A seven-minute ferry ride from Miami Beach is the <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/the-richest-zip-code-in-america-with-an-average-income-of-25-million-2018-4\">richest zip code</a> in the US, with residents earning an average income of $2.2 million a year.</li><li>On <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/richest-zip-code-us-fisher-island-miami-photos-tour-2019-5\">Fisher Island</a>, millionaires drive around on golf carts, lounge on beaches with sand imported from the Bahamas, and vacation in condos worth over $40 million.</li><li>The island paid $30,000 for every resident and staff member to get a <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-richest-zip-code-fisher-island-got-coronavirus-tests-2020-4\">COVID-19 antibody test</a>, while the rest of Miami struggled to obtain tests.</li><li>Business Insider tours the exclusive, members-only island, where residents pay a $250,000 equity membership.</li><li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li></ul><p><em>Following is a transcription of the video.</em></p><p>- Abby Narishkin: So, we're about to check out one of the country's most expensive neighborhoods. This is Fisher Island. Mel Brooks, Julia Roberts, and Oprah have all owned homes here. With an average income of $2.2 million, it's the richest zip code in the United States. And we got a chance to tour it. You may have heard of Fisher from reports that all the residents and staff got COVID-19 antibody tests, just three miles from Miami, where testing was rare. Yep, that's where we're headed. You actually have to take a ferry there. It's one of the only ways to get on the island. The other way to get on the island? Private yacht. Only the island's 800 families and their guests are allowed on Fisher. So security is pretty tight at the ferry terminal, but we got special access back in November 2019 thanks to Dora Puig, one of the island's real-estate agents.</p><p>Dora Puig: Fisher Island is a private island enclave with 216 acres.</p><p>Abby: Dora invited us to tour Fisher's newest developments, Palazzo del Sol and Palazzo della Luna, opened in 2019, which is how we ended up on the island's newest ferry, taking the seven-minute journey from Miami Beach. So, right now I'm on the ferry over to Fisher Island, and, as you can see, I'm the only one here in the passenger lounge. Most everyone is in their cars. We've got a Bentley, a Lamborghini, a Porsche, Ferrari, I think. You won't see these zooming around the island, though. To enforce strict speed limits, most people drive around in golf carts.</p><p>Dora: When you go to the beach club, you'll have a mini Rolls-Royce golf cart or you'll have a Range Rover golf cart, or I've seen even vintage old American cars in baby blue.</p><p>Abby: The median waterfront home here costs $2.9 million, but residents are not only splurging on million-dollar apartments. They're also paying a hefty membership fee. That covers unlimited use of the community pools, the 17 tennis courts, and the private beaches with sand imported from the Bahamas. But it doesn't include the golf course or the two marinas.</p><p>Dora: The original idea of Fisher Island was for everyone to live in the community and use the community amenities.</p><p>Abby: But even on a private island, some residents want even more exclusive perks. The newest condos, Palazzo del Sol and della Luna, don't have beachfront locations, but they do have a private gym, salon, theater, and pool and water transport that only condo residents can use.</p><p>Dora: Come step in with me.</p><p>Abby: Dora first showed us a $14.5 million unit in Palazzo della Luna. She says many of the island's current residents have been looking to trade up for a home like this one so they don't have to share amenities with the whole community. This unit has four bedrooms and five baths.</p><p>Dora: You walk in, you're at ground level, just like in a single-family home. You have your private pool, you're on the bay, and look at the size of the outdoor entertaining terraces. It wraps around the whole corner of the residence. You could have a dinner for 200 to 300 people here.</p><p>Abby: The selling point: the disappearing master suite.</p><p>Dora: You walk into a dressing room that looks like an Hermès shop. Walk-in dressing room for the lady and white-lacquered Italian closets. The custom bathroom by Boffi for us, with the floating island in white lacquer. The tub is custom made for us, and it's called the Fisher Island. And then enter into the master suite, with your 12-foot ceilings.</p><p>Abby: Because we were curious, we went to check out a second apartment, a supposedly more affordable unit up a couple floors. At $9 million, it's got three bedrooms and three and a half bathrooms.</p><p>Dora: Here you're walking into the wooded parlor with our little mini-library, all in blond oak. You have the main living room, dining room, kitchen areas to the bay, and the master suite is also to the bay. And then you have the two guest suites on the golf-course side.</p><p>Abby: You can keep all the furniture for an extra $2 million.</p><p>Dora: Look at how beautiful it is.</p><p>Abby: These two new developments have only made Fisher more untouchable, pushing home values across the island up by 20%. Today, you'll find price tags of over $40 million for a condo. That's only $10 million short of the most expensive home ever sold in Miami. And that was an entire mansion. The Palazzos were the first developments on Fisher in nearly a decade and are targeting a new generation of buyers.</p><p>Dora: Traditionally, we had a little bit older demographic because the island is so beautiful and it's expensive. We've really seen it switch to a much younger crowd. So we've seen a nice migration towards younger families. Some come from generations of family wealth; others come from selling oil companies, selling financial instruments, technology, hedge funds.</p><p>Abby: Even still, half of the residents are over 60, making them particularly vulnerable for COVID-19. The island has always been a place for the 1% to get away, ever since it was formed in 1906, when a canal was dredged so boats could go from the Port of Miami straight to the ocean.</p><p>Dora: The interesting part about this is that Fisher Island today would have been south of Fifth Street in Miami Beach, because it was actually connected to the tip of Miami Beach peninsula.</p><p>Abby: Miami's first Black billionaire, real-estate mogul Dana Dorsey, was one of the first owners of the new island. He wanted to build a Black resort here, but he had trouble getting workers out to the island to build it. So he sold it to billionaire developer Carl Fisher, who named it after himself. Next up, the Vanderbilt family.</p><p>Dora: Carl Fisher and William Vanderbilt were known to party and have a lot of fun here. And one very late night, I'm sure there were drinks involved, they traded the island. Carl Fisher traded his island with his winter home, which is today the club, to William Vanderbilt for his over-200-foot yacht. So, they did the trade, and then the Alva later on sunk and William Vanderbilt kept the island. So I think he was the better businessman.</p><p>Abby: After Vanderbilt's death, the island passed hands between millionaires. And then it was left vacant for 15 years. In the 1980s, Fisher's current developers started work on the community you see today. And now Fisher is a full-blown town. The old Vanderbilt mansion is a hotel with suites running for almost $1,500 a night. Vanderbilt's old airplane hangar is now a spa, and you can even rent a property here on Airbnb for about $700 a night. But this doesn't happen in a vacuum. It takes about 600 workers to run this island. They live off-island and have three separate ferries. During the day, they staff a school, post office, fire station, a security force, and a medical center. It was from that private health clinic that residents and workers got those infamous antibody tests. We're back on the ferry. We just finished our tour of Fisher Island. It's really hard to wrap your brain around just the amount of wealth squished into one place. How that exists so close to reality across the bay. As visitors pre-COVID, we got the sense that even with all its normal town functions, Fisher Island is anything but normal. It's like a live-in resort community. Manicured, eerily perfect, and as secluded as ever.</p><p>Hey, guys, my name's Abby. I'm the producer on this video. Obviously, things have changed a lot for Fisher since we visited back in November 2019. But I honestly wasn't that surprised when I heard that they were able to get antibody tests for everyone on the island. Not only did they have one of the first cases of COVID-19 in Miami-Dade County, they also have the means, the wealth to get them. But I wanna know what else you wanna see from us. What other luxury apartments, private enclaves do you want us to explore? Let us know in the comments below, and make sure to subscribe.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/inside-richest-zip-code-in-america-fisher-island-miami-florida-2020-8'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=We9uienAiEg:Vau3giPvbZM:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=We9uienAiEg:Vau3giPvbZM:qj6IDK7rITs\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=We9uienAiEg:Vau3giPvbZM:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=We9uienAiEg:Vau3giPvbZM:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\"></img></a>\n</div><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/We9uienAiEg\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sat, 05 Sep 2020 14:29:00 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5f4e4d4e60bf1f0028079a2f?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"c1674920d26ae62048bff29ad67c0e50","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn41@2020_2/2020/09/06/02-59-53-703_ce25e0469fc829ff.webp","destWidth":1440,"destHeight":1080,"sourceBytes":258318,"destBytes":258318,"author":"insider@insider.com (Abby Narishkin,Clayton Dyer,Alexandra Appolonia)","articleImgCdnMap":{"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn78@2020_1/2020/09/06/02-59-58-308_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=We9uienAiEg:Vau3giPvbZM:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn48@2020_6/2020/09/06/02-59-47-629_c944f67585f751a4.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=We9uienAiEg:Vau3giPvbZM:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn37@2020_1/2020/09/06/03-00-00-903_9ac0bf98c8c7d9b8.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn60@2020_6/2020/09/06/02-59-52-353_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=We9uienAiEg:Vau3giPvbZM:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn99@2020_4/2020/09/06/02-59-52-705_a2512b108bb383ae.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/We9uienAiEg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn86@2020_5/2020/09/06/03-00-00-082_fb29c7376bdd18c2.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1599361164609},{"createdTime":"2020-09-06 10:59:24","updatedTime":"2020-09-06 10:59:24","title":"If you want to counter China's digital crackdown, regulate Big Tech at home and abroad","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/to-counter-china-digital-crackdown-regulate-big-tech-companies-2020-9","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5dae325fe94e8643e836398a?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Mark Zuckerberg\" height=\"1500\" width=\"3000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Mark Zuckerberg testifies before Congress.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Getty</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>American tech CEOs have fended off scrutiny of their business practices by portraying China as a bigger threat to US interests.</li>\n<li>The way to counter China's digital agenda is not through a lack of regulation but rather through sensible regulations on the tech sector that balance between free and open discourse online and protecting privacy and democratic institutions, writes Coby Goldberg of the Center for a New American Security.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>The heads of Amazon, Google, Apple and Facebook fended off tough questions from lawmakers last month at a hearing of the House Judiciary Committee's antitrust subcommittee.</p><p>To help allay concerns about monopolistic business practices, each CEO sought to portray his company as representing American values and serving American interests. They all did so in part by pointing to a threat supposedly bigger than their own companies: China.</p><p>\"If you look at where the top technology companies come from, a decade ago the vast majority were American. Today, almost half are Chinese,\" <a href=\"https://www.rev.com/blog/transcripts/mark-zuckerberg-opening-statement-transcript-antitrust-hearing-july-29\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Facebook's Mark Zuckerberg said in his opening remarks</a>. \"There's no guarantee our values will win out.\"</p><p>Limiting Facebook's power, he implied, would only play into Beijing's hands. Zuckerberg and the other Big Tech executives <a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/live/2020/07/29/technology/tech-ceos-hearing-testimony\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">returned to the specter of Chinese technological dominance more than 30 times</a> over the course of the afternoon, according to a New York Times tally.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5806aec5dd089523498b4884?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Mark Zuckerberg Jack Ma in China\" height=\"1702\" width=\"2628\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Zuckerberg and Alibaba founder Jack Ma at the China Development Forum in Beijing, March 19, 2016.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Reuters</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>This was not the first time that Zuckerberg has <a href=\"https://www.defenseone.com/ideas/2020/07/theres-bigger-threat-big-tech-its-big-china/167187/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">tried to use the China threat to Facebook's advantage</a>.</p><p>In congressional hearings about Facebook's digital currency project, Libra, Zuckerberg warned that regulating it would <a href=\"https://www.ft.com/content/28c600de-f5a1-11e9-9ef3-eca8fc8f2d65\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">leave the field open to rival digital currencies from China</a>. He was also an <a href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2020/07/25/tiktok-investors-want-in-bytedance-wise-to-hold-on.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">early advocate of banning TikTok</a> — the Chinese-owned short-form video platform that has become a <a href=\"https://supchina.com/2020/07/16/banning-tiktok-is-a-terrible-idea/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">major competitor of Facebook</a> — ostensibly due to concerns that its parent company's ties with the Chinese government could lead to content being censored.</p><p>Zuckerberg is right to warn of the threat posed by China's technological authoritarianism.</p><p>Beijing has harnessed cutting-edge machine learning tools to build surveillance systems that can track residents' travel and even identify people as predisposed to crime. It is actively exporting this Orwellian vision by providing loans to the Chinese technology giant Huawei for its \"<a href=\"https://www.aspi.org.au/report/mapping-chinas-tech-giants\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Safe City</a>\" projects across more than 90 countries and by <a href=\"https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-net/2018/rise-digital-authoritarianism\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">providing training on internet policymaking for foreign leaders</a> from more than 30 countries.</p><p>But the way to counter China's digital agenda is not through a lack of regulation, as Zuckerberg and his fellow tech titans argue. In recent years, mounting concerns over violations of digital privacy at the hands of companies like Facebook and the rampant spread of disinformation online have undermined the notion that an open and free internet means an unregulated internet.</p><p>A better way to fight back against China's global technological ambitions would be for Washington to work together with its allies and build a broad coalition in favor of sensible regulations on the technology sector that strike a balance between free and open discourse online, on the one hand, and protecting privacy and democratic institutions, on the other.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5beddd2e0591f2301157289c?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Trump looking the wrong way NATO\" height=\"1080\" width=\"1637\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>President Donald Trump with NATO Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg and other NATO leaders at the opening of the 2018 NATO Summit at NATO headquarters in Brussels, July 11, 2018.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://www.gettyimages.com/detail/news-photo/german-chancellor-angela-merkel-belgian-prime-minister-news-photo/996209950\" target=\"_blank\">Sean Gallup/Getty Images</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>The US needs to work together with allies to offer an appealing alternative to the Chinese system. But as it stands, the US and its allies are not on the same page.</p><p>Consider the issue of data rights: In 2018, the European Union implemented the <a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2018/05/06/technology/gdpr-european-privacy-law.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">General Data Protection Regulation</a>, the world's most comprehensive data protection scheme. Australia, Japan and South Korea have all followed suit. In the US, though, <a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2019/06/08/opinion/sunday/privacy-congress-facebook-google.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">proposed legislation on digital privacy tends to die</a> on the floor of Congress, without being brought up for a vote.</p><p>On competition, too, America's allies have gotten out ahead of it. The EU, for example, has <a href=\"https://www.cnn.com/2019/03/20/tech/google-eu-antitrust/index.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">slapped Google with more than $9 billion in fines</a> for antitrust violations. In rapidly growing countries like India, Indonesia and Thailand, which are <a href=\"https://www.newamerica.org/cybersecurity-initiative/reports/digital-deciders/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">wavering to varying degrees between the Chinese and American models</a> of technological governance, surveys have found that more than 80% of the population <a href=\"https://www.usnews.com/news/best-countries/articles/2020-01-15/the-world-wants-big-tech-companies-to-be-regulated\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">thinks the power of Big Tech companies should be limited</a>.</p><p>Yet in spite of clear global antipathy toward the laissez-faire US approach to tech regulation, American trade negotiators have persisted in trying to promote it abroad.</p><p>In trade agreements with Canada, Mexico and Japan, for example, the Trump administration forced the inclusion of <a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/05/28/business/section-230-internet-speech.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act</a>, a controversial law that shields internet companies from liability for third-party content posted on their platforms.</p><p>The White House called its deals with these countries the \"<a href=\"https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefings-statements/president-donald-j-trump-secured-tremendous-victory-american-farmers-businesses-new-japan-trade-agreements/#:~:text=The%20United%20States%2DJapan%20Digital,%2DCanada%20Agreement%20(USMCA).\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">gold standard on digital trade rules</a>.\" But both the Democratic and Republican leaders of the House Energy and Commerce Committee disagreed, <a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2019/10/07/business/tech-shield-trade-deals.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">saying it was</a> \"inappropriate for the United States to export language mirroring Section 230\" while the law is the subject of a heated policy debate in the US.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5890efcc713ba130008b5c24?format=jpeg\" alt=\"trump cybersecurity\" height=\"3225\" width=\"5048\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Trump and then-Homeland Security Secretary John Kelly meet with cybersecurity experts at the White House, January 31, 2017.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"http://pictures.reuters.com/C.aspx?VP3=SearchResult&#38;VBID=2C0BXZGXVQJR3&#38;SMLS=1&#38;RW=1795&#38;RH=876#/SearchResult&#38;VBID=2C0BXZGXVQJR3&#38;SMLS=1&#38;RW=1795&#38;RH=876&#38;POPUPPN=1&#38;POPUPIID=2C0BF1FEGXDCH\" target=\"_blank\">REUTERS/Kevin Lamarque</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>In many ways, Washington is already taking the initiative in setting the global digital regulatory agenda. Through programs like the Digital Connectivity and Cybersecurity Partnership, the Trump administration has tried to build other countries' regulatory capacity and counter China's efforts to export of its authoritarian model.</p><p>And the US Agency for International Development recently unveiled its <a href=\"https://www.usaid.gov/usaid-digital-strategy\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">first-ever Digital Strategy</a>, an effort to advance the American vision of \"open, inclusive, and secure digital ecosystems\" through partnerships with foreign governments and civil society groups.</p><p>But in order to promote those kinds of digital regulations abroad, the US needs to have an appealing vision of what they should look like. Many people across the globe dislike the Chinese model of state control over personal data, but they also do not want to give corporations unfettered ownership over their data.</p><p><a href=\"https://www.pewresearch.org/internet/2019/11/15/americans-and-privacy-concerned-confused-and-feeling-lack-of-control-over-their-personal-information/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">A survey conducted last fall by the Pew Research Center</a> found that around 80% of Americans are concerned about the way their personal data is collected by technology companies, and feel that the risks of this data collection outweigh the benefits.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5d60546dadbcf871f92fc6f4?format=jpeg\" alt=\"china hacking\" height=\"2359\" width=\"3500\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>A Chinese soldier in front of &#34;Unit 61398,&#34; a secretive Chinese military unit believed to be behind hacking attacks, in Shanghai, February 19, 2013.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Carlos Barrio / REUTERS</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>This points to a need for the US to build a domestic system that better protects its citizens' private information, perhaps even modelled after the EU's regulations.</p><p>Not only would that be in line with Americans' own stated preferences, it would also harmonize the US system with that of its allies in Europe and the Asia-Pacific, allowing these countries to more effectively work together to counter China's digital ambitions. After all, many countries are wary of China's heavily subsidized tech giants exerting dominance over global markets, but they also do not want to let America's tech giants form de facto monopolies.</p><p>Zuckerberg argued that strong regulations on tech companies would hamstring America's efforts to compete with China. That argument works only in his own interest.</p><p>Competing with China requires advancing a vision of a truly open and inclusive internet, and that will necessarily require meaningful regulations to claw back the power of Facebook and other American giants. If the US wants to slow the spread of China's Orwellian technologies across the globe, it must start by regulating Big Tech at home.</p><p><em>Coby Goldberg is the Joseph S. Nye, Jr. intern for the Asia-Pacific Security Program at the Center for a New American Security.</em></p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/to-counter-china-digital-crackdown-regulate-big-tech-companies-2020-9'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a
