border=\"0\"></img></a>\n</div><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/7oZnct4yO54\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sat, 05 Sep 2020 12:49:00 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5c51ec332bdd7f7da81590ec?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"c1b7589fec7aadaba35c9a248096a32c","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn59@2020_3/2020/09/06/02-59-44-270_c52e3526ad95b073.webp","destWidth":1393,"destHeight":1045,"sourceBytes":61794,"destBytes":61794,"author":"insider@insider.com (Coby Goldberg)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5dae325fe94e8643e836398a?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn78@2020_6/2020/09/06/02-59-54-625_29de8013205fa97e.webp","https://i.insider.com/5806aec5dd089523498b4884?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn40@2020_6/2020/09/06/02-59-53-219_034e124534568658.webp","https://i.insider.com/5beddd2e0591f2301157289c?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn4@2020_3/2020/09/06/02-59-51-914_12c5199444787b19.webp","https://i.insider.com/5890efcc713ba130008b5c24?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn7@2020_4/2020/09/06/02-59-53-923_94a79e84a1e938fb.webp","https://i.insider.com/5d60546dadbcf871f92fc6f4?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn10@2020_1/2020/09/06/02-59-58-664_c46c0c1f980e20a5.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn78@2020_1/2020/09/06/02-59-58-308_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=7oZnct4yO54:Ca-OEzd3vlo:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn66@2020_2/2020/09/06/02-59-58-254_b6086a91169d205a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=7oZnct4yO54:Ca-OEzd3vlo:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn44@2020_4/2020/09/06/02-59-47-504_473c73e2de02f129.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn60@2020_6/2020/09/06/02-59-52-353_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=7oZnct4yO54:Ca-OEzd3vlo:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn80@2020_5/2020/09/06/02-59-48-939_7189a567389755bb.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/7oZnct4yO54":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn82@2020_6/2020/09/06/03-00-01-143_89ad192455c01dab.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1599361164628},{"createdTime":"2020-09-06 10:59:24","updatedTime":"2020-09-06 10:59:24","title":"3 ways to get over your need to be right about everything all the time","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-to-get-over-need-to-be-right-about-everything-2020-9","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5e5feaa0fee23d451b3cd259?format=jpeg\" alt=\"meeting presentation\" height=\"5588\" width=\"7450\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Thinking you have all the answers won&#39;t get you ahead in business.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Morsa Images/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Raj Jana is an entrepreneur and the founder of <a href=\"https://www.javapresse.com/\">JavaPresse Coffee Company</a>, an ecommerce coffee company.\n<section></section>\n</li>\n<li>As a boss, Jana says he often mediates disputes between employees, usually over an argument about who is right or whose opinions are better.</li>\n<li>Being successful at work is about more than being right, Jana explains. It's about putting your ego aside, and working to understand the other person's perspective.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p dir=\"ltr\">\"He isn't doing his part, and he can't keep up with my work speed.\"&#160;</p><p dir=\"ltr\">I sat across from a&#160;<a href=\"https://www.inc.com/martin-zwilling/how-to-successfully-establish-a-board-of-advisors-directors.html?cid=search\">member of my board</a>&#160;while he expressed frustration around an employee on his team.&#160;This employee was doing quality work but&#160;wasn't the fastest or most efficient team member.</p><p>The words of the&#160;manager&#160;began to sink in, and I could sense his deep-seated need to be right and have his opinion validated.</p><p>Although he was correct about the employee's time management, that wasn't what was most important to me.&#160;What was most imperative&#160;was helping them build&#160;a&#160;healthy working relationship&#160;and work on efficiently completing their projects together.</p><p>It can be so tempting to believe you have all the answers and need to dish them out to people all day long. But that isn't necessarily getting you&#160;or your business&#160;to succeed.</p><p>As a leader, it isn't your job to be right;&#160;it's your job to do whatever you need to do&#160;in order to get the job done. At the end of the day, brushing aside the need to be right is possible.&#160;I was able to walk&#160;my board member through how to do this with three simple steps.</p><h2>1. Show up with excitement instead of frustration</h2><p>I started the conversation with my board member by asking, \"How is your frustration working out for you?\"&#160;He sat back&#160;and after a few moments he&#160;laughed at himself.&#160;He knew it wasn't working for him&#160;and&#160;if anything, it was detracting from his energy and effort to what mattered more.</p><p>Show up with excitement instead of frustration. Follow up with someone on a task or project need from a place of enthusiasm. This shifts the energy of the conversation and&#160;motivates the receiving party to become inspired to execute and get involved. When you are excited about something, other will follow suit.&#160;</p><h2>2. Speak the other person's language</h2><p>Most people are speaking their own language full of expressions and jargon expecting everyone else to understand them. True leadership is understanding what kind of language someone speaks and meeting them where they are. Show up with higher&#160;energy to inspire others to act and move in the direction you want.</p><p>Step into the other person's&#160;shoes to understand what motivates them and why they would be enticed to do what needs to be done.&#160;Once you have a grasp on this, you can then speak from their vantage point.</p><p>This also could mean shifting the vocabulary you use and the outcomes you speak to. Have you ever sat in a room where a highly technical expert gave a presentation so granular and detailed that the overall message was lost to those that didn't have the same background? Instead of bombarding a team member with metrics, try approaching it from the customer's emotional outcome or vice versa. Adjust how you speak to people in order to better grab their attention and their desire to get involved.</p><h2>3. Put your ego aside</h2><p>At the end of the day, as a leader, you need to do whatever it takes to get the job done. Sometimes this requires&#160;you to allow someone else to be right, to step into roles that aren't typically yours, and&#160;let your ego down to get your hands dirty right alongside your team.</p><p dir=\"ltr\"><a href=\"https://www.inc.com/matt-haber/simon-sinek-leadership-listening.html?cid=search\">Simon Sinek</a> wrote a book titled \"Leaders Eat Last,\" and that statement alone couldn't summarize the message better. A team expects the leader to mitigate threats, even at the expense of their personal well-being. The sooner you can understand this, the quicker you shift from being an authoritative boss to being a true leader.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/how-to-get-over-need-to-be-right-about-everything-2020-9'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a border=\"0\"></img></a>\n</div><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/YXpsr_SK_20\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sat, 05 Sep 2020 14:15:00 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5f5294bde6ff30001d4e73b1?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"a14f138991f56175a86f7395f7e124fe","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn4@2020_3/2020/09/06/02-59-44-770_d55f5aaace398736.webp","destWidth":7697,"destHeight":5773,"sourceBytes":970196,"destBytes":970196,"author":"insider@insider.com (Raj Jana)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5e5feaa0fee23d451b3cd259?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn69@2020_5/2020/09/06/02-59-56-485_1993fd03f922aa9a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn78@2020_1/2020/09/06/02-59-58-308_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=YXpsr_SK_20:haZv6IeaBII:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn34@2020_1/2020/09/06/03-00-01-382_430e5edd980370fa.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=YXpsr_SK_20:haZv6IeaBII:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn73@2020_6/2020/09/06/02-59-56-347_225b41aeeefb2d23.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn60@2020_6/2020/09/06/02-59-52-353_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=YXpsr_SK_20:haZv6IeaBII:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn75@2020_2/2020/09/06/02-59-47-721_c050333715659470.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/YXpsr_SK_20":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn1@2020_6/2020/09/06/02-59-56-533_2e2595fad2916560.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1599361164613},{"createdTime":"2020-09-06 10:59:24","updatedTime":"2020-09-06 10:59:24","title":"Trump Jr. joins Triller and lashes out against TikTok, claiming the app is 'something that could haunt your kids forever'","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-jr-joins-triller-tiktok-could-haunt-kids-forever-2020-9","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f53de3a7ed0ee001e25dbac?format=jpeg\" alt=\"donald trump jr misinformation\" height=\"497\" width=\"994\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Donald Trump Jr. in a video posted to Triller attacked TikTok and said it might &#34;weaponize&#34; the data of children who use it.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Saul Loeb/AFP via Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Donald Trump Jr., the president's eldest son, in a video Friday targeted TikTok, which is less than two weeks away from facing a ban in the US under his father's executive order.</li>\n<li>In a video posted to Triller, a video-sharing app that has expressed interested in purchasing TikTok, Trump Jr. claimed TikTok could be \"turning on your kid's video, listening in, turning on their mic at any random time not just when they're using the app.\"</li>\n<li>TikTok has repeatedly denied allegations that it provides any of its user data to the Chinese Communist Party, which in August took actions complicating its plans to sell US operations as a result of President Trump's executive orders against it.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>Donald Trump Jr., the eldest son of President Donald Trump, on Friday posted on video-sharing app Triller, peddling unsubstantiated theories that TikTok is turning on users' cameras and microphones even when the app is closed, arguing TikTok is \"something that could haunt your kids forever.\"</p><p>\"When you have an app like TikTok where the Chinese government could be turning on your kid's camera, turning on your kid's video, listening in, turning on their mic at any random time not just when they're using the app,\" Trump Jr. said in his first video on the platform, as first reported by <a href=\"https://www.nbcnews.com/business/business-news/tiktok-could-weaponize-your-kids-data-says-donald-trump-jr-n1239358\">NBC News</a>.</p><p>\"This goes so much further,\" he continued. \"Having access to all your photos and contacts and emails and the spyware that's there. I mean this is something that could haunt your kids forever.\"</p><p>Representatives for TikTok did not immediately return Business Insider's request for comment on Saturday. The social media platform, however, has repeatedly denied allegations that it shares American's user data with Chinese officials.&#160;</p><p>Criticism over TikTok's Chinese ownership has been months-long and bipartisan. Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer, a New York Democrat, last month <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/tiktok-chuck-schumer-us-acqusition-china-2020-\">said that an American company needed to purchase the app so that it was not subject to Chinese law.</a> Late last year, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/us-military-still-posting-tiktok-despite-partial-ban-troops-2020-1\">all branches of the US military banned TikTok usage on government devices</a>. And in July, the campaign of Democratic nominee Joe Biden banned its staffers from using TikTok on both its work and personal devices, <a href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-07-27/biden-campaign-bans-staff-from-trading-stocks-without-approval\">Bloomberg</a> reported.</p><p>In August, the president targeted TikTok in a series of executive orders, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-prohibits-us-companies-from-doing-business-with-tiktok-2020-8\">the first barring any US company from doing business with its Chinese parent company</a>, ByteDance, effectively requiring a sale by September 15. The second executive order, signed on August 14, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-issues-executive-order-to-force-bytedance-tiktok-sale-musically-2020-8\">aimed to invalidate ByteDance's purchase of TikTok in 2017</a>.</p><p>The company has sued the Trump administration, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/tiktok-lawsuit-us-government-trump-ban-due-process-national-security-2020-8\">claiming it did not provide the company due process in enacting the August 6 executive order.&#160;</a></p><p>The Chinese government at the end of August <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/tiktok-sale-disrupted-china-rules-give-self-veto-2020-8\">changed rules that would require TikTok to gain its approval before it sells the algorithm that powers the app</a>, reportedly stalling talks from companies like Microsoft and Oracle, and delivering the latest snag as the company works against President Donald Trump's executive order ordering its sale.</p><p>According to Business Insider, Triller <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/bytedance-china-tiktok-bid-us-rival-triller-2020-9#:~:text=%22Triller%20is%20the%20only%20bidder,one%20source%20told%20Business%20Insider.&text=Triller%20is%20a%20US%2Dbased,mounting%20scrutiny%20around%20the%20world.rld.\">reportedly found China's new rules more favorable for it to purchase TikTok</a>, as it could use its existing technology to power TikTok. The company said it entered a $20 billion bid to purchase TikTok's US, Australia, New Zealand, and India operations, in partnership with London-based investment firm Centricus, according to the report.</p><p>A spokesperson for ByteDance denied that the company had not had discussions with Triller, and said it would &#160;\"not have any in the future,\" Business Insider previously reported.</p><p>Also in his Friday video on Triller, Donald Trump Jr. argued a Chinese company couldn't be trusted to own TikTok because he said, the nation's government lied about the novel coronavirus.</p><p>\"They lied to the world about its virulence,\" he said. \"They lied to the world about the way it was transmitted. They minimized the threat to the world. You think they're going to be good with your data? You think they're going to not weaponize your kids' data eventually against them?\"</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5f53de34e6ff30001d4e74ff?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"d447502ef7d9e72f9377d1104299b1f4","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn40@2020_4/2020/09/06/02-59-44-271_bef739a9817b23e9.webp","destWidth":836,"destHeight":627,"sourceBytes":15190,"destBytes":15190,"author":"insider@insider.com (Connor Perrett)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f53de3a7ed0ee001e25dbac?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn8@2020_6/2020/09/06/02-59-45-245_9eadf1a36bd185f5.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn78@2020_1/2020/09/06/02-59-58-308_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=GOh5mYpXWwo:FBbsqd6oEuI:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn54@2020_5/2020/09/06/02-59-56-116_93243408cc3c57fa.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=GOh5mYpXWwo:FBbsqd6oEuI:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn16@2020_4/2020/09/06/02-59-53-003_0b784059f86b7ade.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn60@2020_6/2020/09/06/02-59-52-353_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=GOh5mYpXWwo:FBbsqd6oEuI:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn46@2020_2/2020/09/06/03-00-00-738_32b1b13243afe01d.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/GOh5mYpXWwo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn16@2020_1/2020/09/06/02-59-55-993_179587e9890834de.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1599361164619},{"createdTime":"2020-09-06 10:59:24","updatedTime":"2020-09-06 10:59:24","title":"These 7 charts from the August jobs report show how far the labor market recovery has come — and how much further it has to go","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/august-jobs-report-chart-analysis-unemployment-recovery-recession-economic-outlook-2020-9","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5ecd22ecf34d0506fb42f7a2?format=jpeg\" alt=\"florida reopening\" height=\"1000\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Johnny Louis/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>The US economy added 1.37 million jobs in August, and the unemployment rate declined to 8.4%, the Labor Department reported Friday.&#160;</li>\n<li>While the report was stronger than economists expected, it also showed that the pace of the labor market recovery from the coronavirus pandemic has continued to slow down.&#160;</li>\n<li>Here are seven charts that break down the report, showing how far the labor market recovery has come and how far there is to go.&#160;</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>The August jobs report yet again showed that while the US labor market is recovering from the shock of the coronavirus pandemic, the pace is slowing and there's still a long way to go to reach pre-pandemic levels.&#160;</p><p>The US economy added 1.4 million jobs in August, and the unemployment rate ticked down to 8.4%, the Labor Department reported Friday. So far, the US economy has recovered 48% of jobs from pre-coronavirus levels.&#160;</p><p>\"Progress is clearly being made but there are still 11.5 million people who are out of a job as a result of the COVID shock,\" said Michelle Meyer, US economist at Bank of America, in a Friday note.&#160;</p><p>And, the overall pace of job gains slowed in August from previous months. \"The private sector only added 1.0 million jobs which shows a deceleration from the recent pace of job creation,\" said Meyer. \"Clearly there is still more work to be done to fully heal the labor market.\"</p><p><em><strong>Read more:</strong> <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/stock-market-sell-off-investing-strategy-how-to-trade-recovery-2020-9\" data-analytics-position=\"2\" data-analytics-module=\"\">A fund manager at a $629 billion firm lays out his strategy for 'making money at the expense of machines' during the stock market's sell-off — and shares 4 sectors he's betting on</a></em></p><p>Provided below are seven charts breaking down the most important data points in the August jobs report.&#160;</p>\n<div id=\"slideshow\">\n\t1. The headline unemployment rate fell to 8.4%, well below economists' expectations.\n\t\n\t<div class=\"insider-raw-embed\"><iframe title=\"Unemployment rate\" aria-label=\"Interactive line chart\" id=\"datawrapper-chart-tzJ45\" src=\"https://datawrapper.dwcdn.net/tzJ45/2/\" scrolling=\"no\" frameborder=\"0\" style=\"width: 0; min-width: 100% ; border: none;\" height=\"450\"></iframe><script type=\"text/javascript\">!function(){\"use strict\";window.addEventListener(\"message\",(function(a){if(void 0!==a.data[\"datawrapper-height\"])for(var e in a.data[\"datawrapper-height\"]){var t=document.getElementById(\"datawrapper-chart-\"+e)||document.querySelector(\"iframe[src*='\"+e+\"']\");t&&(t.style.height=a.data[\"datawrapper-height\"][e]+\"px\")}}))}();\n</script></div><p>The unemployment rate also reached its first single-digit reading of the coronavirus pandemic in August, and is down significantly from the peak of 14.7% in April.&#160;</p><p>Still, the unemployment rate is historically high. It's more than twice the pre-pandemic low of 3.5%.&#160;</p>\n\t2. Nonfarm payroll jobs rose by about 1.4 million in August.\n\t\n\t<div class=\"insider-raw-embed\"><iframe title=\"Nonfarm payroll jobs\" aria-label=\"chart\" id=\"datawrapper-chart-idgNV\" src=\"https://datawrapper.dwcdn.net/idgNV/4/\" scrolling=\"no\" frameborder=\"0\" style=\"width: 0; min-width: 100% ; border: none;\" height=\"450\"></iframe><script type=\"text/javascript\">!function(){\"use strict\";window.addEventListener(\"message\",(function(a){if(void 0!==a.data[\"datawrapper-height\"])for(var e in a.data[\"datawrapper-height\"]){var t=document.getElementById(\"datawrapper-chart-\"+e)||document.querySelector(\"iframe[src*='\"+e+\"']\");t&&(t.style.height=a.data[\"datawrapper-height\"][e]+\"px\")}}))}();\n</script></div><p>The headline payrolls number was slightly above consensus, which estimated that about 1.35 million jobs would be added in the month.&#160;</p><p>The print was boosted by the US Census, which hired about 238,000 temporary workers in August.&#160;</p><p>In addition, private-sector job growth slowed during the month. It was about 1 million in August, down from 1.5 million in July.&#160;</p><p><em><strong>Read more:</strong> <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/us-investing-championship-strategy-matthew-caruso-contender-secret-to-return-2020-8\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">US Investing Championship hopeful Matthew Caruso landed a 382% return in the first half of 2020. He shares the unique twist he's putting on a classic trading strategy &#8212; and 3 stocks he's holding right now.</a></em></p>\n\t3. The labor force participation rate also ticked up in August, but is still below pre-pandemic levels.\n\t\n\t<div class=\"insider-raw-embed\"><iframe title=\"Labor force participation rate\" aria-label=\"Interactive line chart\" id=\"datawrapper-chart-OjlFb\" src=\"https://datawrapper.dwcdn.net/OjlFb/2/\" scrolling=\"no\" frameborder=\"0\" style=\"width: 0; min-width: 100% ; border: none;\" height=\"450\"></iframe><script type=\"text/javascript\">!function(){\"use strict\";window.addEventListener(\"message\",(function(a){if(void 0!==a.data[\"datawrapper-height\"])for(var e in a.data[\"datawrapper-height\"]){var t=document.getElementById(\"datawrapper-chart-\"+e)||document.querySelector(\"iframe[src*='\"+e+\"']\");t&&(t.style.height=a.data[\"datawrapper-height\"][e]+\"px\")}}))}();\n</script></div><p>There are some positive signs that people are indeed returning to work following mass furloughs and layoffs due to the coronavirus pandemic.</p><p>The labor force participation rate, which measures the share of working-age adults that are either employed or actively seeking jobs, increased in August.</p><p>This shows that there are more people either back at work or looking to go back to work as the US economy continues to reopen from virus-related shutdowns earlier in the year.&#160;</p>\n\t4. Similarly, the employment-to-population ratio increased in August, but remains lower than before the pandemic.\n\t\n\t<div class=\"insider-raw-embed\"><iframe title=\"Employment-to-population ratio\" aria-label=\"Interactive line chart\" id=\"datawrapper-chart-GVHJN\" src=\"https://datawrapper.dwcdn.net/GVHJN/1/\" scrolling=\"no\" frameborder=\"0\" style=\"width: 0; min-width: 100% ; border: none;\" height=\"450\"></iframe><script type=\"text/javascript\">!function(){\"use strict\";window.addEventListener(\"message\",(function(a){if(void 0!==a.data[\"datawrapper-height\"])for(var e in a.data[\"datawrapper-height\"]){var t=document.getElementById(\"datawrapper-chart-\"+e)||document.querySelector(\"iframe[src*='\"+e+\"']\");t&&(t.style.height=a.data[\"datawrapper-height\"][e]+\"px\")}}))}();\n</script></div><p>This ratio specifically measures those that have a job as a percentage of the total population, showing that more people are finding their way back into the workforce.&#160;</p><p>\"You had a huge increase in both in the labor force, a huge increase in those employed and a huge decrease in those unemployed,\" Dan North, chief economist for North America at Euler Hermes told Business Insider. There were \"very good signs of health there,\" he added.&#160;</p><p><em><strong>Read more:</strong> <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/stock-market-trading-rules-blueprint-from-market-legend-marty-schwartz-2020-9\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">'I had run $5,000 up to $140,000 in just 2 years': Here are the 7 trading rules stock-market wizard Marty Schwartz leverages to help ensure success</a></em></p>\n\t5. Most industry sectors saw job growth in August, with government and retail trade employment posting particularly large gains.\n\t\n\t<div class=\"insider-raw-embed\"><iframe title=\"Employment changes by sector\" aria-label=\"Bar Chart\" id=\"datawrapper-chart-DCO2T\" src=\"https://datawrapper.dwcdn.net/DCO2T/1/\" scrolling=\"no\" frameborder=\"0\" style=\"width: 0; min-width: 100% ; border: none;\" height=\"653\"></iframe><script type=\"text/javascript\">!function(){\"use strict\";window.addEventListener(\"message\",(function(a){if(void 0!==a.data[\"datawrapper-height\"])for(var e in a.data[\"datawrapper-height\"]){var t=document.getElementById(\"datawrapper-chart-\"+e)||document.querySelector(\"iframe[src*='\"+e+\"']\");t&&(t.style.height=a.data[\"datawrapper-height\"][e]+\"px\")}}))}();\n</script></div><p>While employment grew in most sectors, the overall pace slowed, indicating that so-called \"low-hanging fruit\" jobs might be drying up &#8212; this refers to jobs that workers returned to after temporary layoffs due to the coronavirus pandemic.&#160;</p><p>One example of this is the slowed pace of jobs added back in leisure and hospitality, one of the industries hit hardest by the pandemic and related shutdowns. Even with the employment gains, total jobs are down 2.5 million since February, and the unemployment rate in the sector is 21.3%.&#160;</p><p>It's difficult to see how \"the labor market is going to have a more easy win if that sector &#8212; the one that's most directly affected and constrained by the virus &#8212; is starting to taper off how many jobs it can add,\" Nick Bunker, an economist at Indeed, told Business Insider.&#160;</p><p>In addition, government employment was boosted by temporary hiring for the US Census. Overall employment in the sector remains 831,000 below its February level.&#160;</p>\n\t6. While the number of workers on temporary layoff has dramatically declined, the number of people facing permanent job losses is rising.\n\t\n\t<div class=\"insider-raw-embed\"><iframe title=\"Temporary and permanent layoffs\" aria-label=\"Interactive line chart\" id=\"datawrapper-chart-LIJJ2\" src=\"https://datawrapper.dwcdn.net/LIJJ2/2/\" scrolling=\"no\" frameborder=\"0\" style=\"width: 0; min-width: 100% ; border: none;\" height=\"450\"></iframe><script type=\"text/javascript\">!function(){\"use strict\";window.addEventListener(\"message\",(function(a){if(void 0!==a.data[\"datawrapper-height\"])for(var e in a.data[\"datawrapper-height\"]){var t=document.getElementById(\"datawrapper-chart-\"+e)||document.querySelector(\"iframe[src*='\"+e+\"']\");t&&(t.style.height=a.data[\"datawrapper-height\"][e]+\"px\")}}))}();\n</script></div><p>It's a good thing that temporary layoffs declined, as it shows that workers are returning to their previous jobs.&#160;</p><p>On the flip side, the increase in permanent layoffs is concerning. It's much harder for people to find jobs after a permanent layoff, and if Americans can't go back to work, it means the economic recovery will take a lot longer.&#160;</p><p>\"The first round of shutdowns did indeed create permanent job loss, and people saying 'I don't have a job to go back to,'\" said Dan North, chief economist for North America at Euler Hermes.&#160;</p><p>If there is a resurgence of COVID-19 in the coming months, it could cause more permanent job losses, said North. \"That will be really dangerous for the economy, much more so than the situation we're in now.\"&#160;</p><p><em><strong>Read more:</strong> <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/stocks-to-buy-25-owned-outperforming-women-fund-managers-gs-2020-9\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">GOLDMAN SACHS: Female portfolio managers are outperforming their male counterparts so far in 2020. These are the 25 stocks they own the most compared to men.</a></em></p>\n\t7. Even with the last several months of job gains, there are about 11.5 million fewer Americans on nonfarm payrolls than before the pandemic began, marking a far sharper and deeper decline than in past recessions.\n\t\n\t<div class=\"insider-raw-embed\"><iframe title=\"Job losses in US recessions\" aria-label=\"Interactive line chart\" id=\"datawrapper-chart-zqJ7u\" src=\"https://datawrapper.dwcdn.net/zqJ7u/2/\" scrolling=\"no\" frameborder=\"0\" style=\"width: 0; min-width: 100% ; border: none;\" height=\"450\"></iframe><script type=\"text/javascript\">!function(){\"use strict\";window.addEventListener(\"message\",(function(a){if(void 0!==a.data[\"datawrapper-height\"])for(var e in a.data[\"datawrapper-height\"]){var t=document.getElementById(\"datawrapper-chart-\"+e)||document.querySelector(\"iframe[src*='\"+e+\"']\");t&&(t.style.height=a.data[\"datawrapper-height\"][e]+\"px\")}}))}();\n</script></div><p>There's still a long way for the economic recovery to go before it reaches pre-pandemic levels, and the economic outlook remains uncertain as Americans wait for further government stimulus.&#160;</p><p>Millions of out-of-work Americans had unemployment benefits slashed when the additional $600 per week expired in July, and while some are now getting $300 per week due to an executive order from President Trump, it may last only a few weeks.&#160;</p><p>In August, the Paycheck Protection Program, which likely saved millions of small business jobs also ended. At the same time, Democrats and Republicans remain deadlocked on the next potential coronavirus stimulus package.&#160;</p><p>Hopefully, the August report will reignite the debate, according to North.&#160;</p><p><em><strong>Read more:</strong> <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/stock-market-sell-off-trades-to-make-warning-signs-ms-2020-9\" data-analytics-position=\"3\" data-analytics-module=\"\">Morgan Stanley's wealth management CIO warns there are 'particularly ominous' signs about the state of the stock market's health &#8212; and recommends jumping into these 4 trades during the next major sell-off</a></em></p>\n</div><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a
